Die Caritas hat auf Facebook einen Kassenzettel gepostet

Damit will sie auf eine wichtige Aktion aufmerksam machen

Im Video oben erfahrt ihr mehr Ã¼ber die Aktion

Seit September 2013 kÃ¶nnen Kunden mit den Worten "Aufrunden, bitte" an der Supermarktkasse benachteiligten Menschen in ganz Ã–sterreich helfen. Die Gesamtrechnung wird auf die nÃ¤chsten 10 Cent aufgerundet.

Das gespendete Geld geht dann an die gemeinnÃ¼tzige Organisation â€œCaritasâ€, die Hilfsprojekte in Ã–sterreich unterstÃ¼tzt. Um auf die Aktion wieder aufmerksam zu machen, postet die Caritas auf ihrer Facebook-Seite einen Kassenbon. Ein Betrag von 8,54 Euro wurde auf 8,60 Euro aufgerundet. Das klingt erst einmal nach wenig, aber so wurden bisher schon Ã¼ber 750.000 Euro gespendet.

â€œDeutschland rundet aufâ€

Auch in Deutschland gibt es seit 2012 diese Aktion. Die Spenden flieÃŸen in die Organisation â€œDeutschland rundet aufâ€, die Kinderarmut bekÃ¤mpft. Ãœber 7 Millionen Euro sind so schon zusammengekommen.

Eine tolle Aktion, um das ungeliebte Kupfergeld loszuwerden und gleichzeitig noch fÃ¼r einen guten Zweck zu spenden.

SUMMARY:
Photo by Igor Ovsyannykov on UnsplashThis year India went through one of the single biggest tax reforms since Independence.
The GST is crippling India's craft communities and as always, it's the poor that suffer the most.
It's affected a lot of people in the craft industry.
Photo by Igor Ovsyannykov on UnsplashEleven million people work in the craft industry and many are either semi-literate or illiterate.
On one hand the Indian government champions its craft industry but on the other, it's taxing the very means by which the industry can prosper.
TEXT:
Photo by Igor Ovsyannykov on Unsplash

This year India went through one of the single biggest tax reforms since Independence. Designed to unify the country into a common market, the Goods and Services Tax promises to transform India's economy. But only a few months in, the cracks are beginning to show.

The GST is crippling India's craft communities and as always, it's the poor that suffer the most.

So why does this news bother me? Well, as a retailer of fair trade handloom accessories crafted by artisans in India, it makes sense for me to keep my ear to the ground. But it's more than that. I have a huge respect for those artisans who create such beautiful textiles.

Scouring the news online, I click through sad images of skinny artisans sat by idle handlooms. Handlooms that once filled the room with their clattering sounds, now lie silent. I see protests taking place all over India. Angry fists punching the air. Orchestrated strikes rising up from as far as Andhra Pradesh to Bengal. I read about Kashmiri carpet weavers with no work and sweet shops in Kolkota staging strikes.

It's affected a lot of people in the craft industry. In particular, rural self employed handloom weavers. Previously taxed at 0%, they now have to pay a 5% tax on raw materials. Manufacturing costs have gone up, orders have stopped coming in and rigorous paperwork mixed with confusing processes has disabled the illiterate.



Photo by Igor Ovsyannykov on Unsplash

Eleven million people work in the craft industry and many are either semi-literate or illiterate. They don't have registered businesses or accountants to help file their online returns, which now have to be completed three times a month. With no access to a computer, an accountant or an essential GST number to sell and ship their products, the future looks grim.

Wanting to find out more, I contacted House of Wandering Silk founder Katherine Neumann. As a social enterprise partner, I was keen to find out her thoughts;

The VAT tax system before was a big mess - full of loopholes and different across states and with so many tax brackets. GST helps to streamline and standardise the tax system here and has closed out a lot of the loopholes. But I think it was a mistake to raise taxes on the handloom sector. Some of our partners have had their textiles stuck with them, unable to post, as the couriers are demanding GST numbers to ship their goods. These people shouldn't be required to pay taxes. India has a very low rate of taxpayers, in other words most people and businesses are evading taxes. I think it would make more sense to focus on those who should be paying lots of taxes and make sure they do.

The harsh realities are that many artisans live below the poverty line in sub-standard mud brick housing. The majority are women, which in India brings with it huge challenges of gender, caste and social inequality. Though not reported widely, many weavers have succumbed to suicide, as increasing debt, rising prices of raw materials and shrinking markets push them over the edge. With little access to infrastructure, competition from cheaper machine-made textiles and profiteering middlemen - the GST just seems to be another blow to the already hard life of an artisan.



Photo by Igor Ovsyannykov on Unsplash

The issues haven't affected my business - yet. However I'm concerned about the future of handloom. The handloom sector is the second largest economy in India. Almost 95% of the world's hand-woven cloth is from here. Taking influence from the diverse cultures and regions of India, it's labour intensive methods and skills passed down through generations, has earned the respect of the world. So why isn't it celebrated in India like it is in the luxury market overseas? To see the decline of this industry would be a huge cultural blow to India and to us. As one of the most sustainable and green economies, the Indian government should be pushing this industry globally. It seems ironic that they are not doing more, considering there are many government funded fairs and events promoting weavers and textiles. There's even a National Handloom Day.

On one hand the Indian government champions its craft industry but on the other, it's taxing the very means by which the industry can prosper. It's preventing the poor from even earning enough to survive. By inadvertently targeting the vulnerable, they are alienating talent and potentially contributing to the exodus of rural workers, who would be forced to close their businesses and seek alternative employment in towns and cities.

As a brand that promotes the beauty of textiles and skills of artisans to a global market, I hope the protests don't fall on deaf ears and the movement to bring tax relief to the handloom industry succeeds.

After all, it's part of India's history and heritage. It's part of its DNA.
TITLE: Hanging By A Thread: Why The Introduction Of India's Tax Reforms Is Crippling Craft Communities

SUMMARY:
Jimmy Kimmel launched a new salvo in his feud with Donald Trump, this time questioning the president's intelligence.
Trump responded to reports that Secretary of State Rex Tillerson had called him a "moron" by first dismissing it as "fake news" and then implying he had a higher IQ than Tillerson anyway.
"At this point, I'm not sure Donald Trump could finish the maze on the backs of a Denny's kids' menu," Kimmel said on Tuesday night.
Kimmel also suggested the two should settle the score on pay-per-view.
"I'd pay $100 to watch Rex Tillerson and Donald Trump take IQ tests against each other," he said.
TEXT:
Jimmy Kimmel launched a new salvo in his feud with Donald Trump, this time questioning the president's intelligence.

Trump responded to reports that Secretary of State Rex Tillerson had called him a "moron" by first dismissing it as "fake news" and then implying he had a higher IQ than Tillerson anyway.

Kimmel begged to differ.

"At this point, I'm not sure Donald Trump could finish the maze on the backs of a Denny's kids' menu," Kimmel said on Tuesday night.

Kimmel also suggested the two should settle the score on pay-per-view.

"I'd pay $100 to watch Rex Tillerson and Donald Trump take IQ tests against each other," he said.

See his full takedown in the clip above.
TITLE: Jimmy Kimmel Shuts Down Donald Trump's IQ Boasts

It follows an announcement from the EUâ€™s chief Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, that the UK and EU had reached a â€œdeadlockâ€ in the Brexit negotiations.
Bloomberg The value of the pound plummeted against the euro on Thursday following Michel Barnier's comments.
Barnier told a news conference that negotiators â€œworked in a constructive spiritâ€ and clarified points, but were unable to make â€œany great steps forwardâ€.

TEXT:
The value of the pound plummeted against the euro on Thursday morning after the EUâ€™s chief negotiator said the two sides had reached a â€œdeadlockâ€ in the latest round of Brexit talks.

Sterling dropped to 1.109 against the euro, having been as high as 1.117 earlier.

It follows an announcement from the EUâ€™s chief Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, that the UK and EU had reached a â€œdeadlockâ€ in the Brexit negotiations.

Bloomberg The value of the pound plummeted against the euro on Thursday following Michel Barnier's comments.

Sterling also dropped against the US dollar, from 1.32 to 1.31.

Look at what happened to the pound when Michel Barnier said Brexit talks were deadlocked https://t.co/HEQQ9MDRfz pic.twitter.com/hUcq1MvjuL â€” Bloomberg Brexit (@Brexit) October 12, 2017

Barnier told reporters in Brussels on Thursday that on the issue of the financial settlement, there have â€œbeen no negotiations on this subjectâ€.

â€œOn this question we have reached a state of deadlock which is very disturbing for thousands of project promoters in Europe and itâ€™s disturbing also for taxpayers,â€ he added.

Barnier told a news conference that negotiators â€œworked in a constructive spiritâ€ and clarified points, but were unable to make â€œany great steps forwardâ€.

He added: â€œThere is a new momentum and I remain convinced today that with political will, decisive progress is within our grasp in the next two months.â€

The amount of money the UK will pay to meet financial commitments it made while still a member has been one of the main stumbling blocks in the negotiations.

Barnier said Britain had told the EU that it was not ready to specify how much it believed it should pay.

â€œRegarding that question we are at an impasse, which is very worrying for thousands of projects everywhere in Europe and also worrying for those who contribute,â€ Reuters reports.

Anadolu Agency via Getty Images David Davis (L) and Chief negotiator for the European Union, Michel Barnier (R) hold a joint press conference at the end of the fifth round of negotiation on 'Brexit' talks in Brussels, Belgium.

Barnier said he was still convinced that decisive progress was possible in the next two months given political will.

Brexit Secretary David Davis said he made â€œnot secret of the fact that to provide certainty, we must talk about the futureâ€.

This is just the latest drop in the value of the pound since the UK voted to leave the European Union.

Before the referendum the pound at 1.30.

The lowest that Sterling has dropped since the June 23 referendum was in August this year when it slumped to 1.08.

Bloomberg How the pound has faired against the euro since 2016.

Despite Barnierâ€™s comments, Theresa May insisted that the UK was making good progress in its divorce talks with the EU.

â€œThere has actually been good progress made in these talks, and Michel Barnier himself has recognised that over the coming weeks we will be able to make constructive progress as well,â€ the British Prime Minister said.
TITLE: Pound To Euro Exchange Rate Plummets After EU Brexit Talks Reach â€˜Deadlockâ€™

TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

In a gruesome incident that has come to light on Monday, a Nigerian national was allegedly tied to a post and beaten mercilessly in South Delhi's Malviya Nagar and all of it was caught on camera.

Reports suggest residents in the area claiming that he was caught trying to rob a house in the area, after which he was beaten up by residents of the area.

A video of the incident shows the man pleading for forgiveness as a he is beaten with what looks like a rod.

At one point in the video one can see a man holding up the man's feet while another person hits him on his feet with a rod.

NDTV reports that the victim was allegedly caught inside the home of Krishna Kumar and Kumar's neighbours claimed that he fell while trying to escape.

The report says that he was handed over to the police in a badly wounded state.

The police have told the news channel that action will be taken against the attackers based on evidence from the video.

The video posted by NDTV India shows how badly the man was attacked:

There have been several such incidents against people from African nations in the national capital region.

Students, belonging from African countries, were beaten up in several areas of NCR in March after residents of a Greater Noida society had alleged that a group of African student living there had kidnapped and drugged a teenager who later died.

A raging mob had beaten up helpless students in Greater Noida's Ansal Plaza mall.

The African Heads of Mission posted in New Delhi had strongly condemned the attacks and had called them "xenophobic and racial in nature".

A statement issued after a meeting of the envoys following the incident and dated March 31 said: "As regards the recent unfortunate incident in Greater Noida, the African Heads of Mission strongly condemn the incident and express their deep concern and also take note that these reprehensible events both outstanding and unresolved cases against Africans, were not sufficiently condemned by the Indian authorities. The meeting unanimously agreed that those re-accumulated attacks against Africans are xenophobic and racial in nature."
TITLE: Nigerian National Brutally Assaulted In Delhi's Malviya Nagar On Suspicion Of Theft

Die Brexit-Verhandlungen zwischen der EU und GroÃŸbritannien kommen nicht voran

EU-UnterhÃ¤ndler Barnier beklagt eine "Blockade" der GesprÃ¤che durch die Briten

Die Brexit-Verhandlungen haben ihr erstes Etappenziel klar verfehlt. Es gebe nicht genug Fortschritt, um die wichtige zweite Phase der GesprÃ¤che zu starten, stellte EU-UnterhÃ¤ndler Michel Barnier am Donnerstag fest.

Im Streit Ã¼ber die Schlussrechnung beim EU-Austritt GroÃŸbritanniens sprach Barnier gar von einer "Blockade". Brexit-Minister David Davis betonte hingegen, es gebe "erhebliche Fortschritte". Er appellierte an die EU, die Verhandlungen jetzt auszuweiten.

Der endgÃ¼ltige EU-Austritt der Briten steht bereits fest: Ende MÃ¤rz 2019 will das Land die EuropÃ¤ischen Union verlassen. UrsprÃ¼nglich wollten die UnterhÃ¤ndler wichtige Fragen der Trennung bis Mitte Oktober klÃ¤ren und danach Ã¼ber die kÃ¼nftigen Beziehungen sprechen. In nun mehr fÃ¼nf Verhandlungsrunden gelang das aber nicht.

Barnier hofft auf Fortschritte

EU-ChefunterhÃ¤ndler Michel Barnier. Quelle: dpa

EU-UnterhÃ¤ndler Barnier sagte, er hoffe auf entscheidende Fortschritte in den kommenden zwei Monaten. Gelingt dies nicht, wÃ¼rde ein umfassendes Austrittsabkommen immer unwahrscheinlicher - ein Szenario, das vor allem die Wirtschaft auf beiden Seiten fÃ¼rchtet.

Knackpunkt sind finanzielle Forderungen der EU fÃ¼r gemeinsam eingegangene Verpflichtungen in der mehr als 40-jÃ¤hrigen Mitgliedschaft des Vereinigten KÃ¶nigreichs.

Die britische Premierministerin Theresa May habe zwar versprochen, finanzielle Zusagen einzuhalten, sagte Barnier. In der fÃ¼nften Verhandlungsrunde sei dies seit Montag aber nicht konkret unterfÃ¼ttert worden. "In dieser Frage stecken wir in einer Blockade", kritisierte der EU-Vertreter.

Brexit-Minister Davis stellte klar, dass GroÃŸbritannien die finanziellen Zusagen erst im Zusammenhang mit den kÃ¼nftigen Beziehungen verhandeln wolle. In diesem Punkt sind sich beide Seiten also noch nicht einmal Ã¼ber die Abfolge einig.

Rechte der EU-BÃ¼rger in GroÃŸbritannien

Brexit-Minister David Davis. Quelle: dpa

DarÃ¼ber hinaus ging es auch in dieser Runde um die kÃ¼nftigen Rechte der rund 3,2 Millionen EU-BÃ¼rger in GroÃŸbritannien und der 1,2 Millionen Briten in der Ã¼brigen EU. Hier stellten beide Seiten Fortschritte fest, aber auch noch viele Unstimmigkeiten.

Das gleiche gilt nach Darstellung von Davis und Barnier bei der Frage, wie die kÃ¼nftige EU-Grenze zwischen Irland und dem britischen Nordirland durchlÃ¤ssig gestaltet werden kann.

Davis machte deutlich, dass er die von der EU gewÃ¼nschte Aufteilung in zwei Phasen nicht mehr akzeptiert. Der EU-Gipfel solle nÃ¤chste Woche beschlieÃŸen, Barniers Verhandlungsmandat auszuweiten, sagte er. Dass dies geschieht, gilt als sehr unwahrscheinlich.

Die 27 bleibenden EU-LÃ¤nder geben sich bisher nach auÃŸen sehr einig. Sie sehen die Abfolge vor allem als Hebel, die Finanzforderungen durchzusetzen. Andernfalls wÃ¼rden sofort MilliardenlÃ¶cher im noch bis 2020 laufenden EU-Finanzrahmen klaffen.

"Kein Deal wÃ¤re ein sehr schlechter Deal"

Die zweite Phase der Verhandlungen dÃ¼rfte dann aber noch komplizierter werden - deshalb will man sich dafÃ¼r auch mehr Zeit nehmen. Dabei geht es um die von GroÃŸbritannien gewÃ¼nschte "tiefe und besondere Partnerschaft" - also vor allem ein Handelsabkommen, aber auch die Zusammenarbeit in Sicherheits- und anderen Fragen.

DarÃ¼ber hinaus soll Ã¼ber eine Ãœbergangszeit gesprochen werden, um den Bruch fÃ¼r die Wirtschaft, aber auch fÃ¼r BÃ¼rger und BehÃ¶rden sanfter zu gestalten.

Bis Oktober 2018 soll eigentlich alles in einem umfassenden Austrittsabkommen geregelt sein, das rechtzeitig vor dem Brexit Ende MÃ¤rz 2019 ratifiziert und in Kraft gesetzt werden soll. Gelingt der Ãœbergang in Phase zwei nicht bald, wird dieser Zeitplan zunehmend unrealistisch. Die britische Premierministerin Theresa May vertritt Ã¶ffentlich die Ansicht, kein Abkommen sei besser als ein schlechtes.

Die EU verweist hingegen auf mÃ¶gliche chaotische Folgen - von langen Staus an den Grenzen bis zu hohen EinfuhrzÃ¶llen auf beiden Seiten. "Kein Deal wÃ¤re ein sehr schlechter Deal", sagte ihr UnterhÃ¤ndler Barnier.
TITLE: EU beklagt "Blockade" bei Brexit-Verhandlungen - der Zeitplan gerÃ¤t in Gefahr

Now a sixth instalment, entitled â€˜Hexagonal Phaseâ€™, is set to air next spring on the seriesâ€™ original home of Radio 4.
#HitchhikersGuide returns to @BBCRadio4 for its Hexagonal Phase (with original radio cast) to mark 40th anniversary: https://t.co/OTLV3fG5r5 pic.twitter.com/C6iYMeqABp â€” BBC Press Office (@bbcpress) October 11, 2017The BBC station first broadcast Douglas Adamsâ€™ sci-fi comedy in 1978.

TEXT:
The original cast of â€˜The Hitchhikerâ€™s Guide To The Galaxyâ€™ have reunited to record a brand new episode of the cult sci-fi classic for the seriesâ€™ 40th anniversary.

Itâ€™s been 12 years since fans were treated to a big screen adaption of the show, starring Martin Freeman and Bill Bailey.

Now a sixth instalment, entitled â€˜Hexagonal Phaseâ€™, is set to air next spring on the seriesâ€™ original home of Radio 4.

#HitchhikersGuide returns to @BBCRadio4 for its Hexagonal Phase (with original radio cast) to mark 40th anniversary: https://t.co/OTLV3fG5r5 pic.twitter.com/C6iYMeqABp â€” BBC Press Office (@bbcpress) October 11, 2017

The BBC station first broadcast Douglas Adamsâ€™ sci-fi comedy in 1978. A further four series followed between 1980 and 2005, as well as a hit TV version in 1981.

â€˜Hexagonal Phaseâ€™ has been adapted from Eoin Colferâ€™s spin-off novel â€˜And Another Thingâ€¦â€™, which was commissioned to mark the 30th anniversary of the first novel.

Simon Jones will again play the quintessentially English Arthur Dent, who travels through space and time following the destruction of Earth.

Rex Martin Freeman starred in the 2005 big screen adaption of the classic cult sci-fi comedy.

Speaking about reprising his role, Simon Jones said: â€œIt seems extraordinary that itâ€™s been forty years since we recorded the first pilot episode for BBC Radio; how modest were our expectations then, and how amazing a worldwide phenomenon it became, and continues to be.

â€œI never expected to still be searching for a decent cup of tea and some kind of answer to Life, the Universe and Everything almost a lifetime later.

â€œStill, the dressing-gown and towel may be a little threadbare, like my hair, but my voice, much to my surprise, hasnâ€™t changed a decibel, and despite years in America, I can still talk Arthurâ€™s â€˜indignant-poshâ€™.â€

Samantha BÃ©art, who will co-star in the latest adaptation, tweeted a copy of the new script, captioning it: â€œBack to work.â€
TITLE: â€˜Hitchhikers Guide To The Galaxyâ€™ Original Cast Reunite To Record Brand New Episode Of Cult Sci-Fi Series For 40th Anniversary

FISCALITÃ‰ - Les propriÃ©taires l'ont sans doute dÃ©jÃ  remarquÃ© en la payant chaque annÃ©e. L'Unpi, Union nationale des propriÃ©taires immobiliers, a constatÃ© une hausse de la taxe fonciÃ¨re au cours de la pÃ©riode 2011-2016. Selon les donnÃ©es publiÃ©e ce jeudi 12 octobre (les chiffres commune par commune sont disponibles ici), la moyenne nationale est de 14% soit un peu moins que les 16% de hausse enregistrÃ©s sur la pÃ©riode 2009-2014.

Cela signifie que les municipalitÃ©s Ã©lues en 2014 ont diminuÃ© les efforts demandÃ©s au propriÃ©taires, mÃªme s'il ne faut pas oublier qu'il y a une part dÃ©partementale (cette part a augmentÃ© de 77% dans les Yvelines, 38% dans le Var mais seulement 6,56% dans ceux qui n'ont fait que rÃ©percuter la hausse de la valeur locative dÃ©cidÃ©e par l'Etat) et une autre liÃ©e aux intercommunalitÃ©s dans le calcul du taux de la taxe.

"De toute Ã©vidence, la hausse de la taxe fonciÃ¨re pÃ¨se de plus en plus sur le budget des propriÃ©taires occupants et, concernant les propriÃ©taires bailleurs, sur la rentabilitÃ©", dÃ©nonce l'Unpi qui dit cependant avoir bon espoir d'assister Ã  une modÃ©ration en 2017.

Pour la pÃ©riode, c'est Ã  Lille que la taxe fonciÃ¨re a le plus augmentÃ© (+32,24%) tandis qu'elle a augmentÃ© le moins vite Ã  Saint-Etienne (+6,46%). Dans la prÃ©fecture du RhÃ´ne, la hausse est mÃªme infÃ©rieure Ã  l'augmentation de la valeur locative.

Im Mai 2016 hat Christian Kern seine Amtszeit als Ã¶sterreichischer Bundeskanzler mit einer furiosen Rede angetreten

Er warnte vor einer inhaltslosen Politik und dem Abstieg der Volksparteien

Nun droht dem einstigen HoffnungstrÃ¤ger ein Debakel bei der Wahl - auch, weil er seine eigenen Warnungen ignorierte

Als die Kameras aus sind, ziehen sich die beiden Konkurrenten auf den Studiobalkon zurÃ¼ck.

Gerade eben hatte der Ã¶sterreichische Kanzler Christian Kern im TV-Duell noch bekrÃ¤ftigt, seinen Konkurrenten von der rechten FPÃ–, Heinz-Christian Strache, und ihn wÃ¼rden "Welten trennen".

Nun rauchen beide zusammen und plaudern. Die Szene beschreibt der deutsche Journalist Philip Oltermann fÃ¼r den britischen "Guardian" - und sie steht symbolisch fÃ¼r das, was nach diesem Sonntag in Ã–sterreich geschehen kÃ¶nnte:

Die rechte FPÃ– kÃ¶nnte Teil einer neuen Regierung werden - auch dank der sozialdemokratischen SPÃ– von Kanzler Kern. Explizit ausgeschlossen hat Kern eine Koalition mit den Rechtspopulisten nÃ¤mlich nicht.

Vor rund eineinhalb Jahren, als der Ã–sterreicher die Kanzlerschaft Ã¼bernahm, waren sein Anspruch in der Politik und sein VerhÃ¤ltnis zu den rechten und radikalen KrÃ¤ften im Land noch anders.

Ein Abgleich seiner Antrittsrede von damals und dem Stand jetzt, wenige Tage vor der Wahl des Nationalrats, zeigt, wie sehr die Ã¶sterreichische Bundesregierung versagt hat.

â€Der schrecklich fesche Herr Kernâ€

Im Mai 2016 trat Kern die Nachfolge seines Parteikollegen Werner Faymann an, der nach sinkenden Umfragewerten und innerparteilicher Kritik am restriktiven Kurs in der FlÃ¼chtlingspolitik Konsequenzen zog.

Kern versprach einen Neustart der Beziehungen in der Regierungskoalition und in der Politik allgemein. Der 51-JÃ¤hrige schien der richtige Typ dafÃ¼r zu sein.

Als Quereinsteiger aus der Wirtschaft - von 2010 bis 2016 war Kern Chef der Ã¶sterreichischen Bahn - galt er als HoffnungstrÃ¤ger und als einer, der Dinge anpackt. Der "schrecklich fesche Herr Kern", sei ein "Macher, den die Menschen mÃ¶gen", kommentierte "Spiegel Online" wenige Monate nach Antritt des Politikers.

FÃ¼r viel Aufsehen sorgte schon seine Antrittsrede am 17. Mai 2017. Darin rechnete Kern nicht nur mit den Eliten des Landes ab, sondern formulierte auch eine optimistische Vision fÃ¼r die Zukunft Ã–sterreichs.

Eine deutliche Warnung

Kern prangerte die "Inhaltslosigkeit" der Politik an. Und warnte deutlich:

Wenn wir so weitermachen â€“ und ich habe dabei besonders die Bundesregierung (in Ã–sterreich, Anm. d. Red.) im Auge â€“ wenn wir dieses Schauspiel weiter liefern, ein Schauspiel der Machtversessenheit und der Zukunftsvergessenheit, dann haben wir nur noch wenige Monate bis zum endgÃ¼ltigen Aufprall. Wenige Monate, bis das Vertrauen und die Zustimmung in der BevÃ¶lkerung restlos verbraucht sind.

Dazu gelte es, kurzfristige und langfristige Trendwenden einzuleiten, damit Ã–sterreich wieder ein Land werde, in dem "Aufstieg in der Gesellschaft nicht nur ein leeres Wort ist, und nicht nur wenigen vorbehalten bleibt."

Kern mahnte auch an, dass die Art und Weise der Zusammenarbeit der verkrachten GroÃŸen Koalition aus seiner SPÃ– und der Ã–VP sich dringend Ã¤ndern mÃ¼sse.

Denn er sei davon Ã¼berzeugt: "Wenn wir jetzt nicht kapiert haben, dass das unsere letzte Chance ist, dann werden die beiden GroÃŸparteien nach dieser Regierung von der BildflÃ¤che verschwinden - und wahrscheinlich vÃ¶llig zurecht."

17 Monate spÃ¤ter ist vieles von dem eingetreten, vor dem Kern noch so energisch gewarnt hatte.

Der SchmutzkÃ¼bel



Die Kanzlerkandidaten Christian Kern (SPÃ–), Sebastian Kurz (Ã–VP) und Heinz-Christian Strache (FPÃ–). Quelle: Getty

Zwar sind die Volksparteien nicht von der BildflÃ¤che verschwunden. Die konservative Ã–VP fÃ¼hrt in den Umfragen deutlich mit 33 Prozent. Dahinter folgen jedoch gleich die Rechtspopulisten der FPÃ– mit 27 Prozent.

Kerns SPÃ– ist nach einem HÃ¶henflug nach Amtsantritt des "feschen Kanzlers" auf 23 Prozent abgestÃ¼rzt.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: TV-Duell in Ã–sterreich: Eine Szene zeigt, was dem Land nach der Wahl blÃ¼hen kÃ¶nnt

Ein Grund ist auch: Die Inhaltslosigkeit der Politik, vor der Kern so eindringlich warnte, beherrscht den Wahlkampf in Ã–sterreich.



Der Wettstreit der Parteien gleicht einer Schlammschlacht.

Die sogenannte SchmutzkÃ¼bel-AffÃ¤re Ã¼berdeckt alle Inhalte. Facebook-Seiten Ã¼berzogen den Ã–VP-Kandidaten Kurz mit falschen Anklagen, verbreiteten rassistische und antisemitische Hetze. Kerns Ex-Berater im Wahlkampf, der Israeli Tal Silberstein, soll die Seiten ohne Wissen der SPÃ– organisiert haben.

Ein persÃ¶nlicher Mitarbeiter von Kurz wiederum soll SPÃ–-Zirkeln Geld angeboten haben, um Informationen Ã¼ber die Fake-Facebook-Seiten zu bekommen.

Die AtmosphÃ¤re zwischen der SPÃ– und Ã–VP in der GroÃŸen Koalition in Wien ist vergiftet - und das nicht erst, seit der Schmutz an die Ã–ffentlichkeit dringt. Die Neuwahlen am Sonntag sind das Ergebnis eines monatelangen Streits.

FÃ¼r Eskapaden sorgte etwa immer wieder Ã–VP-Innenminister Wolfgang Sobotka, der Bundeskanzler Kern attackierte - und zusammen mit Kurz fÃ¼r einen Eklat sorgte, als er im Mai eine Sitzung des Ministerrats schwÃ¤nzte.

Aber auch Kern selbst soll an dem schlechten Klima in Ã–sterreichs GroKo seinen Anteil gehabt haben - sagen zumindest seine Kritiker von der Ã–VP. Sie unterstellen ihm einen Dauerwahlkampf und eine stÃ¤ndige Selbstinszenierung.

Und so attestierte die liberale Ã¶sterreichische Tageszeitung "Kurier" Kern nach einem Jahr im Amt im Mai 2017 eine gemischte Bilanz: Der Neustart der eigenen Partei sei ihm gelungen, er habe der SPÃ– wieder ein schÃ¤rferes Profil verschafft.

Doch: "Die 'Stimmung im Land', die Kern vor einem noch 'drehen' wollte, ist am Boden."

Ã–sterreichs "New Deal"

Dabei hat die Ã¶sterreichische Bundesregierung unter Kern durchaus politische Erfolge vorzuweisen. Kern rief in Ã–sterreich einen "New Deal" aus, in Anlehnung an die Wirtschafts- und Sozialreformen von US-PrÃ¤sident Franklin D. Roosevelt in den 1930er Jahren.

Dazu gehÃ¶rte etwa die sogenannte "Aktion 20.000". Mit dem Projekt sollten Langzeitarbeitslose in (gemeinnÃ¼tzige) Jobs gebracht werden. Der Anstieg der Arbeitslosigkeit der Generation Ã¼ber 50 sei dadurch aufgehalten worden, sagte Sozialminister Alois StÃ¶ger (SPÃ–).

TatsÃ¤chlich sinkt die Arbeitslosigkeit in Ã–sterreich seit MÃ¤rz 2017 kontinuierlich. Kerns hat also innenpolitisch Zeichen gesetzt - und Erfolge gefeiert. Doch, dass die Stimmung in Ã–sterreich "am Boden ist", liegt ebenso an ihm.

Denn der "Slim-fit-Kanzler", wie Kern wegen seiner Vorliebe fÃ¼r maÃŸgeschneiderte AnzÃ¼ge genannt wird, hat sich die Themen von der FPÃ– diktieren lassen.

Das rechte Diktat

Der Ã¶sterreichische Politologe Anton Pelinka bezeichnet Kerns Kurs gegenÃ¼ber der Ã¶sterreichischen Zeitung "Der Standard" als "FPÃ– light".

Als Beispiel nennt Pelinka auch die von Kern unterstÃ¼tzte Forderung, Kindern im EU-Ausland die Familienbeihilfe zu kÃ¼rzen.

Oder den Brief des Kanzlers an KommissionsprÃ¤sident Jean-Claude Juncker im April, in dem er forderte, Ã–sterreich vom EU-Umsiedlungsprogramm von Asylbewerbern auszunehmen.

Der Ã¶sterreichische Journalist und Kern-Biograf Robert Misik erklÃ¤rt gegenÃ¼ber dem "Standard": Der Kanzler habe sich von Umfragen beeindrucken lassen, die ihn als zu weit links der Mitte verorteten.

Klar ist auch: Kern ist mit hohen Erwartungen gestartet, womÃ¶glich mit zu hohen. Schwierigkeiten bereitet ihm nun allerdings vor allem ein selbstgeschaffenes Problem: Den umstrittenen Berater Tal Silberstein heuerte Kern selbst als Wahlkampfhelfer an.

Laut Recherchen des Ã¶sterreichischen Magazins "Profil" und der Tageszeitung "Presse" soll Silberstein eine viel zentraler Rolle im Wahlkampf eingenommen haben, als Kern nun im Nachhinein gestehen wolle.

Silberstein habe den Wahlkampf zu einem Zweikampf zwischen Kern und Ã–VP-Herausforder Kurz stilisieren wollen - auch mit schmutzigen Mitteln.

Sollten die Recherchen stimmen, Kern hÃ¤tte Verrat an sich selbst begangen. So oder so: Statt auf seine Inhalte und seinen "Plan fÃ¼r Ã–sterreich" zu setzen, wie er vor eineinhalb Jahren ankÃ¼ndigte, hat er sich auf den Ã¶sterreichischen Intrigantenstadls eingelassen, der die Wiener Politik schon seit Jahren beherrscht.

Den Aufstieg des FPÃ–-Politikers Strache hat er dennoch nicht verhindern kÃ¶nnen - und so seine eigene Macht verspielt.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Der Popstar der Rechten? 3 Ã¶sterreichische Politologen erklÃ¤ren das PhÃ¤nomen Sebastian Kurz

(jg)
TITLE: Vor eineinhalb Jahren warnte Ã–sterreichs Kanzler Kern vor genau den Fehlern, die er nun selbst begeht

TEXT:
A veces parece que la intensidad con la que sentimos no es mÃ¡s que una forma de violencia, una violencia sin forma que nace del interior de uno mismo y se dirige, asimismo e involuntariamente, contra ese mismo interior que uno es. Desde hace unos dÃ­as leo los diarios de Sylvia Plath, publicados por Alianza Editorial tiempo atrÃ¡s, y esta idea se confirma con una recurrencia pasmosa: si su poesÃ­a es como un hermoso charco de tristezas y desequilibrios que resulta indispensable contemplar, sus reflexiones mÃ¡s o menos periÃ³dicas, que van desde 1950 hasta 1962, son un mar inabarcable de sensibilidades en el que merece la pena ahogarse para respirar.

En el imaginario popular, Sylvia Plath estÃ¡ mÃ¡s bien acosada por su suicidio, pues, como suele suceder en estos casos, es mÃ¡s fÃ¡cil tomar la parte por el todo, olvidando asÃ­ que su obra no es sÃ³lo lo que ella hizo hasta que se suicidÃ³, o simplemente un camino de metÃ¡foras para seguir los pasos de su dolor, sino el motivo fundamental de su existencia, su razÃ³n de ser. Sylvia Plath viviÃ³ intensamente en el papel y muriÃ³ como quiso en su cuerpo. Esto no significa que de haberse dado circunstancias mÃ¡s propicias lo hubiese hecho igual, sino tan sÃ³lo que su sensibilidad, su forma de estar en el mundo, no le permitiÃ³ soportar mÃ¡s lo que ella misma era: una herida creadora.

En la belleza de su prosa Ã­ntima podemos descubrir, aquellos y aquellas en los que la sensibilidad es tambiÃ©n una herida, que no estamos solos en la batalla contra la desesperanza y la desilusiÃ³n. Porque si su forma de pensar y su imaginaciÃ³n bastan para obnubilar y atraer, para querer situarnos junto a su sombra, la manera en la que se muestra aquÃ­ carnal y humana la hace mÃ¡s completa, mÃ¡s tÃ¡ctil. Si no pensara, escribe, serÃ­a mucho mÃ¡s feliz; si no tuviera Ã³rganos sexuales, no me encontrarÃ­a todo el tiempo en el lÃ­mite mismo de la exaltaciÃ³n nerviosa y de las lÃ¡grimas. Si estas frases no son el esbozo de cualquier alma que intenta desarrollarse y crecer, difÃ­cilmente podrÃ¡n serlo otras. Pero este es un fragmento que apenas contiene el poderoso sabor de los cientos de pÃ¡ginas en los que vemos cÃ³mo se desenvuelve, entre el dolor y la nada, entre la duda y la angustia, la poeta.

Por eso estos diarios tiene una fuerza especial y devastadora. Porque en ellos se encuentra una vida que aÃºn sigue existiendo con toda su intensidad: la de Sylvia Plath intentando coserse con palabras su profunda herida.

Son muchos los acontecimientos, ideas y preocupaciones que recoge en estos diarios, que son una selecciÃ³n de la amplia cantidad de papeles que dejÃ³ tras su muerte. Funcionan como el complemento perfecto para los que ya estÃ¡n enamorados y entregados a su poesÃ­a: me atreverÃ­a a decir, incluso, que son el canal esencial para comprender sin artificios poÃ©ticos sus ansiedades, el miedo enorme, feo y llorÃ³n, que la obligaba a replantearse un dÃ­a sÃ­ y otro tambiÃ©n cuÃ¡l es el nÃºcleo de la vida, lo que la hace completa o no. Porque cuando ella se decÃ­a tu celda no es tu habitaciÃ³n, sino tÃº misma o tienes miedo de quedarte a solas con tu propio cerebro, estaba mostrando las expansiones y repliegues de su guerra personal con ella misma.

Aunque a veces sea difÃ­cil, es importante acercarse a las personas que se han tomado la molestia de querer ser ellas mismas, porque en sus aciertos y fracasos podemos reconocer los valores y la complejidad que supone intentar dar cumplimiento a las aspiraciones personales; sobre todo a las mÃ¡s profundas y creativas. Por eso estos diarios tiene una fuerza especial y devastadora. Porque en ellos se encuentra una vida que aÃºn sigue existiendo con toda su intensidad: la de Sylvia Plath intentando coserse con palabras su profunda herida.
TITLE: Sylvia Plath: la sensibilidad es una herida creadora

SUMMARY:
The business world is changing...for good.
Whatâ€™s Working: Purpose + Profit, will highlight cutting edge organizations and inspiring leaders who are finding sustainable solutions to many of the world's toughest issues.
From the rise of benefit corporations (b-corps) and impact investing to social entrepreneurs and innovators, this section will feature news articles, profiles, blogs and other editorial content focused on what we can and are doing to create purposeful enterprises that are benefiting people, communities and society-at-large without sacrificing profit.
If you'd like to contribute, please email purposeplusprofit @huffingtonpost.com.
TEXT: The business world is changing...for good. Whatâ€™s Working: Purpose + Profit, will highlight cutting edge organizations and inspiring leaders who are finding sustainable solutions to many of the world's toughest issues. From the rise of benefit corporations (b-corps) and impact investing to social entrepreneurs and innovators, this section will feature news articles, profiles, blogs and other editorial content focused on what we can and are doing to create purposeful enterprises that are benefiting people, communities and society-at-large without sacrificing profit. If you'd like to contribute, please email purposeplusprofit @huffingtonpost.com.
TITLE: What's Working: Purpose + Profit

SUMMARY:
Wildfires have turned entire neighborhoods in Santa Rosa, California, to ash, according to drone footage The Association Press posted Tuesday.
The video shows still-smoldering homes burned to their foundations, blackened trees, and cars that look like they were destroyed in warfare.
Standing out in the rubble are the charred skeletons of refrigerators, patio furniture and barbeque pits.
TEXT:
Wildfires have turned entire neighborhoods in Santa Rosa, California, to ash, according to drone footage The Association Press posted Tuesday.

The video shows still-smoldering homes burned to their foundations, blackened trees, and cars that look like they were destroyed in warfare. Standing out in the rubble are the charred skeletons of refrigerators, patio furniture and barbeque pits.
TITLE: Horrifying Drone Footage Shows Wildfire Devastation In California

Ambassador and former Chief Executive and of Future Cities Catapult, an international centre of expertise on urban innovation.
Augmenting Our Mental Health Chaise longue are old hat in psychology now, Minecraft and PokÃ©mon Go are in.
I'm not being facetious, gaming is now a genuine, credible avenue for exploring new approaches to mental health.
Why Gaming Can Be A Force For Good If ever an industry has been misunderstood, it is gaming.
Secretary of State for HealthThe Breakthrough Medical Technology For Cardiac Conditions It can certainly be a frightening experience, most likely leading you to urgently present at your nearest A&E department.
TEXT:
Gaming For A Good Cause? The number of diagnosed cases of dementia is on the rise, and it is currently estimated that 130 million people will be affected worldwide by 2050. As it stands medical and scientific research can't keep up, which is why a fresh approach to the problem is now a necessity. Game Design Director, GLITCHERS

Green Infrastructure For Cities Over the past year, cities across the world have been buffeted by natural events. Floods ravaged the residents of Mumbai; and tropical storm Harvey left Houston underwater. Cape Town had its worst drought in over a century; and Shanghai, the world's most populous city, experienced its hottest day in recorded history. Ambassador and former Chief Executive and of Future Cities Catapult, an international centre of expertise on urban innovation.

Augmenting Our Mental Health Chaise longue are old hat in psychology now, Minecraft and PokÃ©mon Go are in. I'm not being facetious, gaming is now a genuine, credible avenue for exploring new approaches to mental health. Westminster based political consultant. Associate Director with JBP.

Why Gaming Can Be A Force For Good If ever an industry has been misunderstood, it is gaming. The stereotypical gamer is a teenage boy playing violent games in his bedroom. But the reality could not be further from the truth. The community is close knit, supportive and keenly socially conscious. Founder and CEO, Playmob

The Power of Scale The Plastic Bank created the concept of Social Plastic, a mechanism for transferring more wealth to the world's poor by assuring they receive a consistent, above-market rate for plastic gathered safely from the world's oceans. Founder and CEO of the Plastic Bank, the worldâ€™s only organization to monetize plastic waste.

A Breakthrough Moment For Offshore Wind... But There's More To Come We are delighted and extremely proud to have been awarded a contract to build the world's biggest offshore wind farm - Hornsea Project Two. It's a breakthrough moment for offshore wind in the UK and for us at DONG Energy. Managing Director of DONG Energy UK

How Tech Can Secure The NHS' Place In Our Society And Bring Services Into The Digital Age It's now a little over a decade since Steve Jobs stepped confidently onto a stage in California and projected the world into the smartphone era. Ever since, there's been no shortage of debate about the implications of our ever more connected, always-on digital lifestyles. Technology now governs every aspect of our lives: how we shop, how we work, how we play, even how we vote, have all been transformed by the march of digital. It's brought risk, as well as benefits, not least in its impact on our mental health. But what can't be disputed is its overwhelming power to disrupt traditional ways of working and create new possibilities for consumers. Secretary of State for Health

The Breakthrough Medical Technology For Cardiac Conditions It can certainly be a frightening experience, most likely leading you to urgently present at your nearest A&E department. It's also actually quite common: in the UK, more than 5% of emergency department visits and up to 40% of emergency admissions are as a direct result of chest pain. Professor Ben Varcoe, Chief Scientific Officer, Creavo Medical Technologies

How We Engineer A Solution To The Skills Gap Designed by Royal College of Art graduate Ryan Mario Yasin, Petit Pli employs the Negative Poisson's ratio to allow garments to expand in both directions - enabling them to continuously fit children as they grow. A neat solution to the problem of quickly outgrown clothing, so familiar - and frustrating - to parents. James Dyson Award Manager

The App That Changed My Life Like the thousands of other suffers, my sickle cell anaemia means I have to be really careful about what I eat. I have always tried to stick to eating only fresh fruit, vegetables and meat, and because snacking on the wrong things could have such serious repercussions to my health, package meals have never really been a tempting option. After spending half my life scrutinising food ingredients labels, I decided there must be a smarter way. The solution - Whatsinit?

How Science Is Unlocking The Cancer Medicines Of The Future While there have been major advances in drug development in recent years, systemic treatments like chemotherapy remain the standard of care for most patients. As anyone who has been through chemotherapy knows, it affects the whole body aggressively and causes serious side effects, taking a physical and emotional toll. Head of Medical Affairs at the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry (ABPI)

The Technology That Changes Lives For People With Diabetes - And Why I Think It Should Be Available On The NHS Most people assume the worst thing about living with type one diabetes is having to inject insulin four times a day. I'm not going to lie, that isn't fun. But for me, without doubt, the most frustrating aspect of daily life with a defective pancreas is testing my blood sugar. Former journalist, now Media Relations Officer at the University of Sheffield, who writes about life with type one diabetes.

The Internet Of Things Can Help Bring Electricity To Millions Living In Off-Grid Communities Having access to sustainable energy can help improve people's health and wellbeing, give them better access to education, and empowers people to set up their own businesses. It also gives people access to home comforts that many take for granted - a television, a refrigerator, the ability to charge up a mobile phone or laptop. VP of Market Development, Europe, at Aeris

Building A Sharing Economy With A Social Purpose The commercial sector has been highly successful in exploiting the power of digital technologies to enable people to participate in the 'sharing' economy. We've seen massive investment in new marketplaces to share homes and cars, enabling people to make and save money. Executive Director, Nesta Innovation Lab

The Computer Augmented Surgeon But most people do not realize that the role of robotic assistance in surgery and other forms of medicine is just beginning. The da Vinci was the first robot to significantly impact hundreds of thousands of cases per year, but it is the forerunner of a wave of assistive devices that will be entering the market and the hospital. Chief Technology Officer for the Florida Hospital Nicholson Center and a graduate faculty at the University of Central Florida
TITLE: HuffPost UK Tech For Good: Innovation And Sustainability Across Gadgets, People, Tech, Sustainabilit

Alors, je vous propose quelques Ã©lÃ©ments importants pour dissiper le brouillard et de dÃ©mÃªler le vrai du faux.

Tant que vous serez sensibles Ã  leurs pleurnicheries thÃ©Ã¢trales et que vous les prendrez en pitiÃ©, vous serez piÃ©gÃ©.

TEXT:
Bien que le phÃ©nomÃ¨ne existe depuis toujours, la manipulation mentale est longtemps restÃ©e ignorÃ©e. Petit Ã  petit, depuis une quarantaine annÃ©es, les composantes de ce mÃ©canisme Ã©mergent au grand jour. On entend de plus en plus souvent parler de "manipulation mentale", de "harcÃ¨lement", de "manipulateur" ou de "pervers narcissique" et mÃªme de "manipulateur destructeur". Ces agissements sont dÃ©crits, dÃ©noncÃ©s dans des contextes de plus en plus variÃ©s. Autrefois, les mÃ©dias ne relayaient que les grandes escroqueries financiÃ¨res ou les drames sectaires. Aujourd'hui, on se rend compte que la manipulation existe aussi dans d'autres domaines plus individuels: la famille, le travail, l'Ã©cole ou le voisinage. On commence aussi Ã  dÃ©couvrir que le harcÃ¨lement moral tue, qu'il pousse au suicide et qu'il a un coÃ»t cachÃ© Ã©norme pour la sociÃ©tÃ©, tant en matiÃ¨re de santÃ©, que de productivitÃ©.

Le nuage d'encre de la pieuvre

Mais les manipulateurs ne se laisseront pas faire sans rÃ©agir. C'est pourquoi au fur et Ã  mesure qu'on avance dans la dÃ©couverte du phÃ©nomÃ¨ne, des contre-vÃ©ritÃ©s commencent Ã  Ãªtre distillÃ©es avec l'espoir de recrÃ©er la confusion dans laquelle ils sont Ã  l'abri. Comme une pieuvre masque sa prÃ©sence par son jet d'encre, le manipulateur embrouille les donnÃ©es et crÃ©e dÃ©libÃ©rÃ©ment un brouillard mental dans lequel on ne sait plus ce qui est vrai ou faux, ce qui appartient Ã  l'un et ce qui appartient Ã  l'autre. Par exemple, vous avez surement dÃ©jÃ  entendu â€“et peut-Ãªtre mÃªme relayÃ©- l'argument suivant: "Bah, on est bien tous un peu manipulateur!" C'est totalement faux. Si les humains sont Ã©videmment dans une inter-influence, ce n'est pas de la manipulation, tant qu'on n'a pas l'intention d'utiliser l'autre cyniquement pour arriver Ã  ses fins ou qu'on ne ressent pas un plaisir sadique Ã  voir l'autre souffrir. Alors, je vous propose quelques Ã©lÃ©ments importants pour dissiper le brouillard et de dÃ©mÃªler le vrai du faux.

Un profil Ã©tonnamment standard

Ce qui m'a le plus surprise dans ma pratique de coaching, c'est que depuis 24 ans, mes clients me parlent de la mÃªme personne. Qu'il s'agisse d'un homme ou d'une femme, la personne manipulatrice a toujours les caractÃ©ristiques suivantes:

- Deux visages:

Les manipulateurs ont deux visages. Le premier, trÃ¨s sympathique, affichÃ© pour la galerie et adressÃ© aux gens qu'ils souhaitent endormir, l'autre morose et haineux, rÃ©servÃ© Ã  leur victime et aux gens qu'ils mÃ©prisent ou qu'ils veulent Ã©carter. Le visage sympathique n'est qu'un masque. Quand vous l'aurez compris, vous ne vous laisserez plus rendormir par cette gentillesse de pacotille.

- Quatre ficelles:

La sÃ©duction: Les manipulateurs se montreront charmants et sympathiques jusqu'Ã  ce que vous soyez piÃ©gÃ©s. Ensuite, ils tomberont le masque. Ils peuvent redevenir adorables, ponctuellement, par calcul, pour vous rendormir.

La victimisation: Les manipulateurs sont les gens les plus malheureux de la terre. Ils ont plus souffert que tout le monde et tout le monde est mÃ©chant avec eux. Tant que vous serez sensibles Ã  leurs pleurnicheries thÃ©Ã¢trales et que vous les prendrez en pitiÃ©, vous serez piÃ©gÃ©.

L'intimidation: Irritables, impatients, stressÃ©s et stressant, les manipulateurs vous font vivre sous la pression de l'urgence et la peur de leurs crises de rage. Sournoisement revanchards, ils maitrisent l'art des reprÃ©sailles. Vous apprendrez vite Ã  vous soumettre en croyant ainsi Ã©viter les ennuis.

La culpabilisation: Un manipulateur est une personne totalement immature et irresponsable. Il est donc Ã©vident pour lui que c'est vous qui Ãªtes responsable de tout et que lui-mÃªme est toujours innocent. Quoi qu'il se passe se sera de votre faute. Et comme il est aussi capricieux que versatile, quoi que vous fassiez, Ã§a n'ira jamais. Si vous Ãªtes du genre Ã  vouloir bien faire et Ã  vous remettre facilement en question, vous allez sombrer dans une culpabilitÃ© aussi gÃ©nÃ©ralisÃ©e qu'irrationnelle.

Une destruction en trois temps

De la rencontre Ã  la fin de la relation, le procÃ©der est Ã©galement incroyablement standard et fonctionne en trois pÃ©riodes. Une lune de miel, une descente aux enfers, une mise Ã  mort. Ce rÃ©cit, je l'ai entendu plus de mille fois. Toutes les victimes que j'ai rencontrÃ©es, et je dis bien TOUTES, m'ont dit ces mots Ã©tranges: "J'allais y laisser ma peau!"

PÃ©riode de sÃ©duction: Au dÃ©but de la relation, qu'elle soit amoureuse, amicale ou mÃªme professionnelle, vous avez l'impression d'avoir rencontrÃ© la personne parfaite. (Je mets d'ailleurs en garde les recruteurs sur le piÃ¨ge du candidat parfait.) Comme le manipulateur vous dit exactement ce que vous avez envie d'entendre, vous vivez une pÃ©riode d'euphorie: vous avez toujours su au fond de vous qu'une telle personne existait! HÃ©las, non, elle joue avec vos rÃªves.

HarcÃ¨lement: Un jour, le masque tombe brusquement. Le manipulateur estime qu'il est dans la place et qu'il n'a plus d'effort Ã  faire. Toutes les victimes se souviennent avec prÃ©cision du jour oÃ¹ il a tombÃ© le masque. Elles ont eu l'impression de ne plus avoir affaire Ã  la mÃªme personne. Et Ã©videment, le masque est tombÃ© le dernier jour de la pÃ©riode d'essai, le jour du mariage, parfois hÃ©las, le jour du test de grossesse. Alors, les scÃ¨nes, les critiques, les mÃ©chancetÃ©s vont s'intensifier et deviendront le lot quotidien. A la fin de cette pÃ©riode, la victime est Ã©puisÃ©e, hÃ©bÃ©tÃ©e, dans un Ã©tat de stress permanent. Sa santÃ© commence sÃ©rieusement Ã  se dÃ©grader. Elle se croit folle et dÃ©prime dangereusement.

Destruction: Le manipulateur s'enivre de sa toute-puissance, se grise de ses abus, se drogue de son harcÃ¨lement. Sa victime devient sa came. Comme tous les droguÃ©s, il lui faut une dose de plus en plus forte. DÃ©verser sur vous toute la haine et toute la frustration qu'il porte en lui le soulage passagÃ¨rement. C'est pourquoi un harcÃ¨lement ne s'arrÃªte jamais et ne peut aller qu'en s'aggravant. Vous seul aurez le pouvoir de dire stop... pour sauver votre peau.

Plus jamais victime?

Apprendre Ã  reconnaitre ces Ã©lÃ©ments n'est pas facile. C'est souvent lorsqu'on est sorti d'une telle relation qu'on se rend compte qu'elle Ã©tait profondÃ©ment destructrice. Alors, en faisant le bilan, on se rend compte que tout ce que je viens de dÃ©crire y Ã©tait. La dÃ©monstration devient implacable. Mais comment ne pas replonger? Il reste un Ã©norme sujet Ã  controverse et qui est pourtant dÃ©terminant dans la sortie d'emprise. C'est le niveau de conscience qu'ont les manipulateurs de ce qu'ils font. Tant que vous croirez qu'ils sont inconscients de ce qu'ils font, vous resterez des proies potentielles et leur meilleur avocat, au grand dÃ©triment des autres victimes. Quand vous aurez compris qu'ils sont parfaitement lucides et qu'ils abusent cyniquement de votre humanitÃ©, vous serez dÃ©finitivement libÃ©rÃ©.

Christel Petitcollin - Pourquoi trop penser rend manipulable - Ed. Guy TrÃ©daniel

SUMMARY:
Personal Trainer and CLIF Bar AmbassadorCreating Time For Training Time is one of the biggest barriers to a healthy training process but none of us has enough time in the day.
A-List personal trainer and nutritional expertOur Teens Are 'Ditching Dairy' - A Teenage Time Bomb Waiting to Happen?
Clinical and sports dietitian, expert in functional medicine and personalised nutritionFighting Fake Fitness News Fake news has certainly been a topic of much conversation of late.
Personal Trainer and CLIF Bar AmbassadorBack To School Basics For A Better Lunchbox The old tricks are the best!
Freelance writer, blogger and cyclistHow To Use Your Fitness Tracker To Actually Get Physically Fit Whether you are aiming to lose some pounds, trying to tone up or just trying to maintain your body shape, the effective use of a fitness tracker could be the most sensible decision you will make.
TEXT:
An Open Letter To My Body I am sorry for all the times I have called you ugly, fat and disgusting. I am sorry for all the times I have sat on the floor of my room, crying because I felt that if you were only lighter, that only if you took up less space in the world we would be better and more liked. Tattooed princess dreaming about protein shakes and prince charming.

Transitioning Your Summer Fitness Routine Into Autumn Bright and warm 6am starts, longer evenings and workouts in the park. Summer is the best time of the year to be active and get out of just using the gym. But then autumn creeps in, then winter comes. The days start getting shorter, darker and colder. Personal Trainer and CLIF Bar Ambassador

Creating Time For Training Time is one of the biggest barriers to a healthy training process but none of us has enough time in the day. That's why you need to make time to include training as an integral part of your week, every week. A-List personal trainer and nutritional expert

Our Teens Are 'Ditching Dairy' - A Teenage Time Bomb Waiting to Happen? Worryingly, the trend is greatest in our young generation of 16-24 year olds who are shunning dairy at the fastest rate, despite needing it the most during their strong bone-forming years to prevent health issues such as osteoporosis or thinning bones later in life. Clinical and sports dietitian, expert in functional medicine and personalised nutrition

Fighting Fake Fitness News Fake news has certainly been a topic of much conversation of late. However, fake news is really nothing new. In the fitness industry, some people have been using "fake news" to promote the alleged benefits of their products and/or services for years. Ask anyone and they're sure to be able to name a few wild and crazy fitness fads from years past. Having been in fitness for over 30 years, I've seen more than my fair share. Fitness expert with over 30 years experience in exercise programming, management and education.

Beat The Heat I've recently just been on holiday and managed to get my workouts in every day, in twenty minutes or less, without having to trek off to the gym on my own, miss out on the sun and not do the things I wanted to do. Personal Trainer and CLIF Bar Ambassador

Back To School Basics For A Better Lunchbox The old tricks are the best! Making shapes out of sandwiches, presenting fruit in small colourful containers, adding a fun curly straw to drink their milk with - it all helps to make sure they actually eat everything. After all, children don't get any nutritional benefit from food that never leaves the lunchbox. Clinical and sports dietitian, expert in functional medicine and personalised nutrition

It's Never Too Late To Start Strength Training: Anti-Ageing Benefits From Exercise The majority of the population believes that their ageing process is inevitable. Piling on the fat, losing muscle mass, developing weaker bones and joints are almost now accepted by the mainstream as part of life. Disease and illnesses sadly are becoming just something we associate with ageing and are considered to be part of the whole degenerating process. Co-director of More Than Muscle. I have a passion for all things coaching, educating and fitness writing. www.morethanmuscle.co.uk

The Long Game Of Fitness I know that it can be a struggle to get back in the gym after a break but as long as you prioritise your fitness, it shouldn't be a problem. Keeping fit is your ticket to good health and feeling great about yourself, so it shouldn't be all that difficult to get back into it. A-List personal trainer and nutritional expert

A Spoonful Of Sugar Right, now you're back from the kitchen, (or the counter, if you are in a posh coffee shop) shall we talk about sugar? It's always in the news along with rising obesity levels, Type 2 diabetes and tooth decay. Only this month, Public Health England launched a child obesity plan to tackle the problem head on. Freelance writer, blogger and cyclist

How To Use Your Fitness Tracker To Actually Get Physically Fit Whether you are aiming to lose some pounds, trying to tone up or just trying to maintain your body shape, the effective use of a fitness tracker could be the most sensible decision you will make. However, as with any inanimate object, it won't work by itself. Award-winning blogger and publisher

My Tips On How To Fuel For Outdoor Sports And Adventures Whether you're a runner, cyclist, triathlete or swimmer or you just enjoy the exhilaration of participating in outdoor sports and adventures, you'll benefit from proper fuelling and hydration. Good nutrition will help sustain your energy, increase your endurance, promote recovery and allow you to perform to your full potential. Registered Nutritionist and CLIF Bar Ambassador

I Quit I'd always promised myself that one day I would complete a half marathon. It's never been the right time, never had enough time and never quite wanted the time until this year. I was sick of making excuses and decided the Great North Run would be the place to do it but I had an added incentive in running for a remarkable charity for a fantastic baby boy and his family. Mum, full-time worker and blogger, winner of the 2017 BAPS SEND Newcomer blog award.

Fitbit Ionic: Five Things You Might Have Missed There's a new heart rate monitor on board, which Fitbit is being oddly tight-lipped about. It's not the PurePulse of old, but a new one which uses red LEDs instead of green - and that's a big deal. Co-founder of Wareable, the biggest site dedicated to wearable tech and the connected self.

The Fitness Tracker Market Is Dying - But New Sensors And Complex Devices Could Offer Life After Death Jawbone is dead - as a consumer producer of gadgets anyway - and questions have to be asked about Misfit, which looks worryingly lifeless as we await the delayed Misfit Vapor sports smartwatch nearly a year after its unveiling. Co-founder of Wareable, the biggest site dedicated to wearable tech and the connected self.
TITLE: Diet and Fitness: Advice On Instructors, Fitness Routines, Diet News, Diet Plans And Best Ways To Lo

SUMMARY:
Other countries have woken up to the problem and earlier this year the Australian government pledged to end gambling advertising during live sports events before 8.30pm.
Instead, the UK's media industry (dependent upon gambling advertising) is focusing on equally-destructive aspects such as fixed odds betting terminals.
Recent figures compiled by Nielsen indicate the gambling industry spent Â£312m in 2016 on ads, a 63% rise on the comparable figure for 2012.
Ever since 2005's gambling act, the British gambling industry has been growing at a frightening rate.
Gross gambling yield - the amount gambling firms win from customers - was Â£8.36bn in the year beginning April 2008.
TEXT:
It's a scandal - and yet again those nasty interweb companies are to blame. Children are being encouraged to download apps that encourage them to gamble. Trivial amounts at first but, like the most addictive of drugs, it only takes a little to encourage dependency.

Except this is a rather convenient story for the newspapers to tell and allows them to ignore their own role in the UK's gambling epidemic and the child victims caught up in it.

Lack of transparency is one of the most troubling traits of today's media. It's why that no matter how good the product, levels of trust among the public are lower than ever.

It's something I first considered a few weeks ago when The Times newspaper ran the latest in an occasional - and excellent - series highlighting Britain's gambling epidemic. (The recent Sunday Times 'scoop' about digital downloads is part of this campaign.) Here is the introduction to that Times story about the dangers posed to children:

'Figures show that the industry has spent Â£1.4 billion on advertising since 2012, with online casinos doubling their marketing budgets over the past five years. Britain's biggest charity to help addicts is so concerned about the increasing volume of advertising that it is urging ministers to introduce stricter rules. Kate Lampard, the chairwoman of gambling watchdog GambleAware, says: "With the average age at which children start to watch post-watershed TV unsupervised being 11Â¾, restrictions based on a 9pm watershed may offer little protection."'

Except that there is an advertising issue more troubling than either the watershed or online casinos, as GambleAware and The Times know. It is daytime television, particularly during live sports events, where children are targeted by an astonishing array of advertisements persuading them to use phones, tablets and PCs to gamble away their (and their parents') money.

Just a few days ago, the Local Government Association issued an alarming report which revealed that one in 10 children aged 11-15 follow gambling companies on social media, having been heavily influenced by TV ads during sports broadcasts. Try Googling the newspapers' reporting of that study - the silence is rather deafening.

I conducted a small experiment myself on a recent Saturday afternoon and watched Sky Sports - whose major shareholder Rupert Murdoch also controls NewsUK, the publisher of The Times.

During Sky's live football coverage between noon and 5pm, I counted 64 advertisements that sought to part the consumer from their cash (I ignored plugs for Sky TV). Thirty seven of these were for consumer goods and the other 27 urged people to 'bet now', 'cash out' and, inevitably, 'win'. So more than 42% of adverts selling me a product before the watershed were encouraging me to gamble.

The companies that paid Sky a hefty sum to run these ads - money that will no doubt contribute to the financial health of all of Mr Murdoch's companies - were: Paddy Power, BetFair, Coral, Ladbrokes, Betway, 365, Betstars, William Hill, Sky Bet and Lotto. There was also a 10-minute interview with a footballer wearing a t-shirt emblazoned with Bet Victor, together with the inevitable in-programme logos on clothes, billboards and studio walls.

I didn't time the length of the ads but if we assume each was about 30 seconds, then there was close to a quarter of an hour of gambling adverts that went out in the middle of Saturday afternoon, at a time when children are most likely to be watching television.

Other countries have woken up to the problem and earlier this year the Australian government pledged to end gambling advertising during live sports events before 8.30pm. Instead, the UK's media industry (dependent upon gambling advertising) is focusing on equally-destructive aspects such as fixed odds betting terminals. Pre-watershed advertising is, largely, ignored.

GambleAware's argument which The Times publicised - that the advertising industry must do more to protect society's most vulnerable when they watch TV in the evening - represents only a small part of the story.

Presumably, the watchdog, whose trustees include the bosses of Ladbrokes Coral and Rank - two of Britain's most powerful gambling organisations - has its own interests to protect as well as the consumers'.

Likewise, the Times rather conveniently omits to mention the astonishing success of the Sun Bets gambling website and app, a heavily-publicised off-shoot of its sister paper, The Sun.

Excessive gambling is as great a danger to people's lives as excessive drinking and smoking. When I was growing up in the 1970s and 80s, cigarette companies like Benson & Hedges, Dunhill and Silk Cut were being eased out of sponsoring live events because their glossy products hastened death. I don't know whether I bought cigarettes because of such highly visible daytime advertising but I'm sure it was a contributory factor. I don't know whether my son and his friends think betting is a laugh because people like 'I-gamble-responsibly' Ray Winstone advocate it, but I wouldn't be surprised if watching TV on a Saturday afternoon was also a contributory factor.

Recent figures compiled by Nielsen indicate the gambling industry spent Â£312m in 2016 on ads, a 63% rise on the comparable figure for 2012. Roughly half of this was for television. Ever since 2005's gambling act, the British gambling industry has been growing at a frightening rate. Gross gambling yield - the amount gambling firms win from customers - was Â£8.36bn in the year beginning April 2008. In the year to September 2016, it reached a record Â£13.8bn.

No wonder the Gambling Commission recently revealed that 69% of people think betting is dangerous for family life and that there are now more than 400,000 'problem' gamblers, one in five of whom attempt to kill themselves.

The media - print, advertising, marketing - has an enormous role to play in reporting how gambling affects the fabric of society and real people's lives. But it must do so in a transparent way and look to itself if it wants to uncover the truth, rather than just attack digital media. It's not just The Times - on a recent Friday, I counted 14 adverts on the sports pages of London's Evening Standard, 13 of which promoted gambling.

As for the gambling companies, since they have purloined the word 'responsible' to reshape their consumer narratives, I wonder what would happen if one of the brands took the moral high ground by pledging not to advertise on television before 6pm. Yes, it would lose some penetration in the teenage market but it might also win some respect from the media, politicians and the general public. And, in taking a stand, persuade us that the brand represents something more important than profit. Societal responsibility, for instance.

It would be a gamble but perhaps one worth taking.
TITLE: The Media's Role In Our Gambling Epidemic

SUMMARY:
As one of Britainâ€™s most prestigious institutions, Oxford University is notoriously difficult to get in to.
Now, Oxford has released a set of sample interview questions to ease the minds of thousands of nervous applicants.
â€œThe other part of the mortality rate calculation is of course the age of the population: we would ideally steer the conversation towards a discussion of why a wealthy but older country like Japan might have a higher mortality rate, while a country like Bangladesh â€“ which many people might initially expect to have a high mortality rate due to relative poverty as a country â€“ actually has a relatively lower mortality rate because of its young population.
â€œSimilarly, Britain actually has the second-highest mortality rate because of the age structure of its population: we are a relatively old country and a majority of deaths occur in older people.
Interviewer Jane Hiddleston, of Exeter College, said: â€œThis is a good question as it helps us to see how candidates think about both languages and literature.
TEXT:
As one of Britainâ€™s most prestigious institutions, Oxford University is notoriously difficult to get in to.

Each year, 45,000 people apply for a place in the universityâ€™s hallowed halls, but only around 8,600 are successful.

Now, Oxford has released a set of sample interview questions to ease the minds of thousands of nervous applicants.

Dr Samina Khan, director of admissions and outreach at the university said: â€œInterviews will be an entirely new experience for most students, and we know many prospective applicants are already worried about being in an unfamiliar place and being questioned by people they have not met â€“ so to help students to become familiar with the type of questions they might get asked we release these real examples.

â€œWe want to underscore that every question asked by our tutors has a purpose, and that purpose is to assess how students think about their subject and respond to new information or unfamiliar ideas.â€

Khan added: â€œNo matter what kind of educational background or opportunities you have had, the interview should be an opportunity to present your interest and ability in your chosen subject, since they are not just about reciting what you already know.â€

So, would you make the grade?

zodebala via Getty Images Around 45,000 people apply to study at Oxford University each year

Subject: Law

Q: Should it be illegal to run a red light in the middle of the night on an empty road?

Exeter College lecturer Jon Herring said: â€œThe ability to think normatively is important to the study of law, so we are interested in what candidates think the law ought to be, but more important is their capacity to justify their position.

â€œThis involves being able analyse concepts, critically appraise arguments and the reasoning behind a position, as well as to consider objections and to offer rebuttals to those objections. There isnâ€™t a right or wrong answer to this question; we would be using the example to see how well the candidate could justify their stance.

â€œFor example, a candidate might say that if no one was harmed by running the light, then it wouldnâ€™t hurt to run it so it shouldnâ€™t be illegal. This would be suggesting that the law is based on preventing harm. We might then explore whether this is the only purpose or the dominant purpose of the law, and how that might shape how legal rules need to be constructed, when exceptions might be valid and how effective exceptions could be created.â€

He continued: â€œHere, we would be looking to see how well they can see the problems with their approach, the difficulties inherent in drafting a rule that works in every situation without being too broad. This line of discussion would draw out their capacity to respond to challenges to their position, their mental flexibility, and their ability to think precisely.

â€œAnother candidate might suggest that even if no one is harmed, it is important that laws are respected and we could examine why this is the case. For example, if running lights was only illegal when it was dangerous, this would leave it to each personâ€™s assessment of â€˜dangerousâ€™, so we could never be sure when someone would run a light, leading to chaotic traffic.â€

Herring added: â€œThis question also picks up on ideas about what it means for something to be illegal and citizensâ€™ relationship with the law, whether it can ever be justified to break the law and what might be a sufficient justification. This could lead into more philosophical discussions of what it means for a law to be binding and how legal rules might differ from moral rules or guidelines.

â€œA candidate might begin to consider whether there is something special about â€˜lawâ€™, and we could use this as a way into exploring with them whether the fact that something is illegal is itself a reason not to do something, over and above, perhaps, the harm the rule is aiming to prevent. Candidates might then think about how law makes other peopleâ€™s behaviour more predictable so that we can plan our own actions, or how the law might serve functions like punishing wrongdoing.

â€œAn example might be that because the law makes murder illegal and those who kill are punished, I can expect that I can leave my house and generally not expect to be killed, so this allows me to decide itâ€™s safe to go outside.â€

Subject: Philosophy (Philosophy, Politics and Economics)

Q: â€˜I agree that air transport contributes to harmful climate change. But whether or not I make a given plane journey, the plane will fly anyway. So there is no moral reason for me to not travel by plane.â€™ Is this a convincing argument?

Interviewer Cecile Fabre of Lincoln College said: â€œThe interview is not meant to test candidatesâ€™ knowledge of Philosophy, since more often than not, they have not studied this subject before. Moreover, we are not trying to get them to guess or arrive at â€˜the right answerâ€™.

â€œRather, the interview is about candidatesâ€™ ability to think critically, to deal with counter-examples to the views they put forward, and to draw distinctions between important concepts.â€

She continued: â€œThis answer raises the difficult question of individualsâ€™ responsibility, as individuals, for harmful collective actions. Some candidates might be inclined to dispute the premise that air transport contributes to climate change: thatâ€™s fine, but we would then ask them to accept that premise for the sake of argument. Whether they are able to do that is in itself an important test, since much of philosophical thinking proceeds in this way.

â€œSome candidates might say that the argument is a good one: given that what I do makes no difference, I have no moral reason not to do it. At this point, I would want to know what they consider a moral reason to be (as distinct from or similar to, for example, a practical or prudential reason).â€

Fabre added: â€œI would also push them to think about other cases: for example, the bombing of Dresden (one jet fighter less makes no difference to the collective outcome â€“ so why not go and fight); or voting (why should I vote in a general election, given that my vote makes no difference)?

â€œAre the cases the same? Are they different? If so, are the differences or similarities relevant? That is to say, do those differences and similarities help us think about the original case? Do they help us to work out a view about individual responsibility in those cases?

â€œFor example, in the Dresden case, the individual jet fighters act together as part of an organisation â€“ the air force â€“ whose aim is to bomb Dresden. But we cannot say of companies such as British Airways that they aim to cause climate change. And the air passengers cannot really be described as acting together. Does this make a difference?â€

Subject: Medicine

Q: Put these countries in order by their crude mortality (deaths per thousand of the population): Bangladesh, Japan, South Africa, the UK.

Exeter College interviewer Andrew King, said: â€œInterviews for Medicine aim to gauge candidatesâ€™ understanding of the science underpinning the study of medicine, as well as skills in scientific enquiry. This question invites candidates to think about a public health question and epidemiology that can be approached in many different ways, without necessarily knowing anything about specific mortality rates around the world.

â€œWe would expect the initial discussion to probe the differing causes of death that contribute to mortality rates â€“ such as those â€˜Western diseasesâ€™ heart disease and cancer â€“ and how they compare to those found in developing countries (high infant mortality, infectious diseases, poor nutrition, high rates of HIV etc.).â€

He continued: â€œThe majority of candidates will expect Bangladesh or South Africa to have the highest crude mortality rate, and will be surprised to find that it is in fact Japan.

â€œThe other part of the mortality rate calculation is of course the age of the population: we would ideally steer the conversation towards a discussion of why a wealthy but older country like Japan might have a higher mortality rate, while a country like Bangladesh â€“ which many people might initially expect to have a high mortality rate due to relative poverty as a country â€“ actually has a relatively lower mortality rate because of its young population.

â€œSimilarly, Britain actually has the second-highest mortality rate because of the age structure of its population: we are a relatively old country and a majority of deaths occur in older people. We wouldnâ€™t expect students to get the right answer on their own, and in fact thatâ€™s not the point: the point is to see how they apply their understanding of social and cultural factors in health and illness to a problem of epidemiology.

â€œSome students might already have a detailed knowledge of demography, others might need to be given more relevant information â€“ the point isnâ€™t what they know, itâ€™s what questions they ask to make their conclusions, and how they interpret information to draw those conclusions. We might then go on to discuss how you could make a valid comparison between mortality rates in different countries.â€

Subject: Modern Languages (French)

Q: What do we lose if we only read a foreign work of literature in translation?

Interviewer Jane Hiddleston, of Exeter College, said: â€œThis is a good question as it helps us to see how candidates think about both languages and literature.

â€œThey might be able to tell us about the challenges of translation, about what sorts of things resist literal or straightforward translation from one language to another, and this would give us an indication of how aware they are of how languages work.â€

She continued: â€œThey might also tell us about literary language, and why literary texts in particular use language in ways that make translation problematic. This might lead to a discussion of what is distinct about literary works, and this helps us to see what kind of reader they are more broadly.

â€œWe donâ€™t do this with the expectation that they have already read any particular works, however, but in order to get a sense of why they think it is worth studying literatures in foreign languages.â€

Hiddleston added: â€œThis is an important issue, given that Modern Languages students at Oxford read a lot of literature in the language as part of their course.
TITLE: Oxford University Sample Interview Questions: Would You Make The Cut At Britain's Top Uni?
