Als die Kameras aus sind, ziehen sich die beiden Konkurrenten auf den Studiobalkon zurÃ¼ck.

Gerade eben hatte der Ã¶sterreichische Kanzler Christian Kern im TV-Duell noch bekrÃ¤ftigt, seinen Konkurrenten von der rechten FPÃ–, Heinz-Christian Strache, und ihn wÃ¼rden "Welten trennen".

Nun rauchen beide zusammen und plaudern. Die Szene beschreibt der deutsche Journalist Philip Oltermann fÃ¼r den britischen "Guardian" - und sie steht symbolisch fÃ¼r das, was nach diesem Sonntag in Ã–sterreich geschehen kÃ¶nnte:

Die rechte FPÃ– kÃ¶nnte Teil einer neuen Regierung werden - auch dank der sozialdemokratischen SPÃ– von Kanzler Kern. Explizit ausgeschlossen hat Kern eine Koalition mit den Rechtspopulisten nÃ¤mlich nicht.

Vor rund eineinhalb Jahren, als der Ã–sterreicher die Kanzlerschaft Ã¼bernahm, waren sein Anspruch in der Politik und sein VerhÃ¤ltnis zu den rechten und radikalen KrÃ¤ften im Land noch anders.

Ein Abgleich seiner Antrittsrede von damals und dem Stand jetzt, wenige Tage vor der Wahl des Nationalrats, zeigt, wie sehr die Ã¶sterreichische Bundesregierung versagt hat.

â€Der schrecklich fesche Herr Kernâ€

Im Mai 2016 trat Kern die Nachfolge seines Parteikollegen Werner Faymann an, der nach sinkenden Umfragewerten und innerparteilicher Kritik am restriktiven Kurs in der FlÃ¼chtlingspolitik Konsequenzen zog.

Kern versprach einen Neustart der Beziehungen in der Regierungskoalition und in der Politik allgemein. Der 51-JÃ¤hrige schien der richtige Typ dafÃ¼r zu sein.

Als Quereinsteiger aus der Wirtschaft - von 2010 bis 2016 war Kern Chef der Ã¶sterreichischen Bahn - galt er als HoffnungstrÃ¤ger und als einer, der Dinge anpackt. Der "schrecklich fesche Herr Kern", sei ein "Macher, den die Menschen mÃ¶gen", kommentierte "Spiegel Online" wenige Monate nach Antritt des Politikers.

FÃ¼r viel Aufsehen sorgte schon seine Antrittsrede am 17. Mai 2017. Darin rechnete Kern nicht nur mit den Eliten des Landes ab, sondern formulierte auch eine optimistische Vision fÃ¼r die Zukunft Ã–sterreichs.

Eine deutliche Warnung

Kern prangerte die "Inhaltslosigkeit" der Politik an. Und warnte deutlich:

Wenn wir so weitermachen â€“ und ich habe dabei besonders die Bundesregierung (in Ã–sterreich, Anm. d. Red.) im Auge â€“ wenn wir dieses Schauspiel weiter liefern, ein Schauspiel der Machtversessenheit und der Zukunftsvergessenheit, dann haben wir nur noch wenige Monate bis zum endgÃ¼ltigen Aufprall. Wenige Monate, bis das Vertrauen und die Zustimmung in der BevÃ¶lkerung restlos verbraucht sind.

Dazu gelte es, kurzfristige und langfristige Trendwenden einzuleiten, damit Ã–sterreich wieder ein Land werde, in dem "Aufstieg in der Gesellschaft nicht nur ein leeres Wort ist, und nicht nur wenigen vorbehalten bleibt."

Kern mahnte auch an, dass die Art und Weise der Zusammenarbeit der verkrachten GroÃŸen Koalition aus seiner SPÃ– und der Ã–VP sich dringend Ã¤ndern mÃ¼sse.

Denn er sei davon Ã¼berzeugt: "Wenn wir jetzt nicht kapiert haben, dass das unsere letzte Chance ist, dann werden die beiden GroÃŸparteien nach dieser Regierung von der BildflÃ¤che verschwinden - und wahrscheinlich vÃ¶llig zurecht."

17 Monate spÃ¤ter ist vieles von dem eingetreten, vor dem Kern noch so energisch gewarnt hatte.

Der SchmutzkÃ¼bel



Die Kanzlerkandidaten Christian Kern (SPÃ–), Sebastian Kurz (Ã–VP) und Heinz-Christian Strache (FPÃ–). Quelle: Getty

Zwar sind die Volksparteien nicht von der BildflÃ¤che verschwunden. Die konservative Ã–VP fÃ¼hrt in den Umfragen deutlich mit 33 Prozent. Dahinter folgen jedoch gleich die Rechtspopulisten der FPÃ– mit 27 Prozent.

Kerns SPÃ– ist nach einem HÃ¶henflug nach Amtsantritt des "feschen Kanzlers" auf 23 Prozent abgestÃ¼rzt.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: TV-Duell in Ã–sterreich: Eine Szene zeigt, was dem Land nach der Wahl blÃ¼hen kÃ¶nnt

Ein Grund ist auch: Die Inhaltslosigkeit der Politik, vor der Kern so eindringlich warnte, beherrscht den Wahlkampf in Ã–sterreich.



Der Wettstreit der Parteien gleicht einer Schlammschlacht.

Die sogenannte SchmutzkÃ¼bel-AffÃ¤re Ã¼berdeckt alle Inhalte. Facebook-Seiten Ã¼berzogen den Ã–VP-Kandidaten Kurz mit falschen Anklagen, verbreiteten rassistische und antisemitische Hetze. Kerns Ex-Berater im Wahlkampf, der Israeli Tal Silberstein, soll die Seiten ohne Wissen der SPÃ– organisiert haben.

Ein persÃ¶nlicher Mitarbeiter von Kurz wiederum soll SPÃ–-Zirkeln Geld angeboten haben, um Informationen Ã¼ber die Fake-Facebook-Seiten zu bekommen.

Die AtmosphÃ¤re zwischen der SPÃ– und Ã–VP in der GroÃŸen Koalition in Wien ist vergiftet - und das nicht erst, seit der Schmutz an die Ã–ffentlichkeit dringt. Die Neuwahlen am Sonntag sind das Ergebnis eines monatelangen Streits.

FÃ¼r Eskapaden sorgte etwa immer wieder Ã–VP-Innenminister Wolfgang Sobotka, der Bundeskanzler Kern attackierte - und zusammen mit Kurz fÃ¼r einen Eklat sorgte, als er im Mai eine Sitzung des Ministerrats schwÃ¤nzte.

Aber auch Kern selbst soll an dem schlechten Klima in Ã–sterreichs GroKo seinen Anteil gehabt haben - sagen zumindest seine Kritiker von der Ã–VP. Sie unterstellen ihm einen Dauerwahlkampf und eine stÃ¤ndige Selbstinszenierung.

Und so attestierte die liberale Ã¶sterreichische Tageszeitung "Kurier" Kern nach einem Jahr im Amt im Mai 2017 eine gemischte Bilanz: Der Neustart der eigenen Partei sei ihm gelungen, er habe der SPÃ– wieder ein schÃ¤rferes Profil verschafft.

Doch: "Die 'Stimmung im Land', die Kern vor einem noch 'drehen' wollte, ist am Boden."

Ã–sterreichs "New Deal"

Dabei hat die Ã¶sterreichische Bundesregierung unter Kern durchaus politische Erfolge vorzuweisen. Kern rief in Ã–sterreich einen "New Deal" aus, in Anlehnung an die Wirtschafts- und Sozialreformen von US-PrÃ¤sident Franklin D. Roosevelt in den 1930er Jahren.

Dazu gehÃ¶rte etwa die sogenannte "Aktion 20.000". Mit dem Projekt sollten Langzeitarbeitslose in (gemeinnÃ¼tzige) Jobs gebracht werden. Der Anstieg der Arbeitslosigkeit der Generation Ã¼ber 50 sei dadurch aufgehalten worden, sagte Sozialminister Alois StÃ¶ger (SPÃ–).

TatsÃ¤chlich sinkt die Arbeitslosigkeit in Ã–sterreich seit MÃ¤rz 2017 kontinuierlich. Kerns hat also innenpolitisch Zeichen gesetzt - und Erfolge gefeiert. Doch, dass die Stimmung in Ã–sterreich "am Boden ist", liegt ebenso an ihm.

Denn der "Slim-fit-Kanzler", wie Kern wegen seiner Vorliebe fÃ¼r maÃŸgeschneiderte AnzÃ¼ge genannt wird, hat sich die Themen von der FPÃ– diktieren lassen.

Das rechte Diktat

Der Ã¶sterreichische Politologe Anton Pelinka bezeichnet Kerns Kurs gegenÃ¼ber der Ã¶sterreichischen Zeitung "Der Standard" als "FPÃ– light".

Als Beispiel nennt Pelinka auch die von Kern unterstÃ¼tzte Forderung, Kindern im EU-Ausland die Familienbeihilfe zu kÃ¼rzen.

Oder den Brief des Kanzlers an KommissionsprÃ¤sident Jean-Claude Juncker im April, in dem er forderte, Ã–sterreich vom EU-Umsiedlungsprogramm von Asylbewerbern auszunehmen.

Der Ã¶sterreichische Journalist und Kern-Biograf Robert Misik erklÃ¤rt gegenÃ¼ber dem "Standard": Der Kanzler habe sich von Umfragen beeindrucken lassen, die ihn als zu weit links der Mitte verorteten.

Klar ist auch: Kern ist mit hohen Erwartungen gestartet, womÃ¶glich mit zu hohen. Schwierigkeiten bereitet ihm nun allerdings vor allem ein selbstgeschaffenes Problem: Den umstrittenen Berater Tal Silberstein heuerte Kern selbst als Wahlkampfhelfer an.

Laut Recherchen des Ã¶sterreichischen Magazins "Profil" und der Tageszeitung "Presse" soll Silberstein eine viel zentraler Rolle im Wahlkampf eingenommen haben, als Kern nun im Nachhinein gestehen wolle.

Silberstein habe den Wahlkampf zu einem Zweikampf zwischen Kern und Ã–VP-Herausforder Kurz stilisieren wollen - auch mit schmutzigen Mitteln.

Sollten die Recherchen stimmen, Kern hÃ¤tte Verrat an sich selbst begangen. So oder so: Statt auf seine Inhalte und seinen "Plan fÃ¼r Ã–sterreich" zu setzen, wie er vor eineinhalb Jahren ankÃ¼ndigte, hat er sich auf den Ã¶sterreichischen Intrigantenstadls eingelassen, der die Wiener Politik schon seit Jahren beherrscht.

Den Aufstieg des FPÃ–-Politikers Strache hat er dennoch nicht verhindern kÃ¶nnen - und so seine eigene Macht verspielt.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Der Popstar der Rechten? 3 Ã¶sterreichische Politologen erklÃ¤ren das PhÃ¤nomen Sebastian Kurz

(jg)
TITLE: Vor eineinhalb Jahren warnte Ã–sterreichs Kanzler Kern vor genau den Fehlern, die er nun selbst begeht

SUMMARY:
Portrait Mode is designed to take better photos of the things you love.
Portrait Mode was introduced with the 7 Plus but what's new is the introduction of Portrait Lighting.
Your subject's face spotlit against a deep black background; Stage Light Mono.
The one tricky thing to get used to with Portrait Mode is that it's a lot more 'zoomed in'.
It's also suggested that when using Stage Lighting, try shooting a photo slightly below your subject's face level.
TEXT:
Portrait Mode is designed to take better photos of the things you love. Like people. And cake.

Let's face it: what do you look for when you're in the market for a new smartphone? Sure, you may consider the storage space or the speed but when it comes down to it, the first question most people ask is 'how good is the camera?'.

It was the first question we asked when the iPhone 8 Plus was released a few weeks back and so we've been having a play to fill you in.

Portrait Mode was introduced with the 7 Plus but what's new is the introduction of Portrait Lighting. It pimps out the feature even further, but as a recap, Portrait Mode essentially lets you take cool portraits (hence the name) of a subject.

What it does is makes the the person or thing is in focus and the background or non important matter is out of focus. The result is a pic that looks super professional, like it was taken on a DSLR.

Now with the addition of Portrait Lighting you can play around with the brightness and shade even further to get a really good shot.

There are five lighting modes:

Natural Light . Your subject's face in sharp focus against a blurred background;

. Your subject's face in sharp focus against a blurred background; Studio Light . A clean look with your subject's face brightly lit;

. A clean look with your subject's face brightly lit; Contour Light . Dramatic shadows with highlights and lowlights;

. Dramatic shadows with highlights and lowlights; Stage Light . Your subject's face spotlit against a deep black background;

. Your subject's face spotlit against a deep black background; Stage Light Mono. Like Stage, but in classic black-and-white.

I snapped this pic of my friend Deni really quickly while walking down the street.

The one tricky thing to get used to with Portrait Mode is that it's a lot more 'zoomed in'. This is because the subject is meant to be a certain distance from you (fairly close but not too much), and then the background a certain distance from the subject, for the best result. This takes a little getting used to but definitely produces the best images.

Apple suggests shooting against a non-solid background to get the most out of the depth effect, so try to position your subject against a busy background or a colourful setting. It's also suggested that when using Stage Lighting, try shooting a photo slightly below your subject's face level.

These extra effects make this smartphone the ideal camera for parents, proud pet owners or anyone who enjoys taking photos, really.

It also has a really impressive video offering. It suggested you take video in landscape to get the full effect and there's a whole bunch of new features when it comes to filming, too. They welcome 4k video (which means it's faster and better quality) and they have improved on the slo-mo feature as well as the optical zoom -- the dual-lens camera means you can now get videos with optical zoom at 2x, so zooming in isn't totally grainy.

Apple suggest these camera tips:
TITLE: iPhone 8 Plus Camera: We Put It To The Test

SUMMARY:
Hate crimes targeting mosques and other Muslim places of worship across the UK more than doubled between 2016 and 2017.
Police forces recorded 110 hate crimes directed at mosques between March and July this year, up from just 47 over the same period in 2016, a Press Association investigation has found.
Racist abuse and threats to â€œbomb the mosqueâ€ feature heavily among the hate crimes, as do incidents of offenders smashing windows on buildings and parked cars.
Violent crime against individuals more than doubled from five recorded crimes against worshippers at mosques in 2016 to 11 crimes in 2017.
Crimes recorded as vandalism or criminal damage increased from 12 in 2016 to 15 in 2017.
TEXT:
Hate crimes targeting mosques and other Muslim places of worship across the UK more than doubled between 2016 and 2017.

Police forces recorded 110 hate crimes directed at mosques between March and July this year, up from just 47 over the same period in 2016, a Press Association investigation has found.

Racist abuse and threats to â€œbomb the mosqueâ€ feature heavily among the hate crimes, as do incidents of offenders smashing windows on buildings and parked cars.

Other records include offensive graffiti sprayed on to buildings, violent assaults on worshippers, two cases of arson and two cases of individuals leaving bacon on door handles at mosques.

Shadow home secretary Diane Abbott called the figures â€œdeeply troublingâ€.

PA Archive/PA Images Shadow home secretary Diane Abbott called the figures 'deeply troubling'

â€œAttacks on any religious group or minority are abominable,â€ she said, adding: â€œThese anti-Muslim attacks will be condemned by all decent people.â€

The data was obtained by the Press Association through Freedom of Information requests to UK police forces. The figures, based on 42 responses from 45 forces, also show:

25 forces saw a year-on-year increase in hate crimes directed at mosques, with the biggest rise reported by Greater Manchester Police (nine crimes, up from zero) and Londonâ€™s Metropolitan Police (17 crimes, up from eight). Threats, harassment or other intimidating behaviour more than tripled, from 14 crimes in 2016 to 49 in 2017. Violent crime against individuals more than doubled from five recorded crimes against worshippers at mosques in 2016 to 11 crimes in 2017. Crimes recorded as vandalism or criminal damage increased from 12 in 2016 to 15 in 2017.

Britain endured a number of terror attacks claimed by Islamic State over the period in which the crimes were recorded, at London Bridge, Westminster and Manchester.

The figures come to light within weeks of separate incidents in which an imam and surgeon who treated Manchester bombing victims was stabbed outside a mosque in Cheshire and a 14-year-old boy was stabbed multiple times in the face and neck outside a mosque in Birmingham.

Other high-profile cases of hate crime at mosques this year include the Finsbury Park terror attack in June, a Manchester mosque gutted by fire in an arson attack in July and the sending of a white powder and bomb threats to three mosques across London in July.

More than 50 places of worship, almost half of them mosques, applied for the most recent round of anti-hate crime funding from the Government, which ended in June.

Applications for funding, intended to provide security measures, were made available to all places of worship in April and May but extended into June after terror attacks at the start of the summer.

Abbott called on the Home Office to publish data on hate crimes against all places of worship â€œas a matter of courseâ€ after â€œworrying reports of attacks on synagogues as well as mosquesâ€.

She said: â€œPoliticians have a particular responsibility in the language they use, the policies they advocate and the climate they create.

â€œThere should be a unanimous message that violence against any section of our society is unacceptable.â€

Tell Mama, a charity who monitor and record anti-Muslim incidents, said â€œsadly these figures have not come as a shockâ€.

The groupâ€™s director, Iman Aâ€™tta, told HuffPost UK that between June 2013 and May 2017 it had recorded 160 incidents against mosques.

â€œAs anti-Muslim hatred has sadly become more vocal and noticeable, mosques are seen as the visible symbol of local Muslim communities and are therefore targeted. However, the impact of the wider Muslim community using the mosque is significant.â€

Tell Mama told HuffPost that terrorism is a â€œmajor driverâ€ for anti-Muslim attacks, but added there were other factors such as â€œinflammatory media headlines and far right extremism and rhetoricâ€.

â€œHowever, the largest impact on Muslim communities is through terrorism and that canâ€™t be denied since some seem to believe that the media is the major cause of anti-Muslim attacks.

Inflammatory headlines may play a role, but they do not come anywhere near the real world impacts that Islamist terrorism causes. Sadly, British Muslims are then caught and squeezed between those who use their faith to murder and those who target them and those who use such situations to play to exclusionary mindsets.â€

A Home Office spokesman said: â€œAll forms of hate crime are completely unacceptable and the UK has some of the strongest laws in the world to tackle it.â€

A report by Hope not Hate in August highlighted that Britonsâ€™ attitudes towards Muslims and Islam had â€œworsenedâ€ with more than half of all respondents to a new survey believing the religion â€œposes a threatâ€ to the West.

Tell Mama A graphic from Tell Mama shows how hate crimes spike in the UK after terror attacks

â€œThe fear and hostility displayed towards Muslims is deeply worrying, despite most people claiming that they stand firm against extremistsâ€™ attempt to conflate their heinous actions with that of an entire religion,â€ Hope not Hate (HnH) chief executive Nick Lowles said of the findingâ€™s of the charityâ€™s Fear And Hope 2017 report.
TITLE: Hate Crimes Targeting Mosques In UK More Than Doubles In A Year

SUMMARY:
Philip Hammond is planning to deliver a â€œsafety-firstâ€ budget with no giveaways for younger voters, HuffPost UK has learned.
Treasury sources insisted the Budget process is still ongoing, and no firm decisions have been made.
One MP told HuffPost UK: â€œThe truth of the Budget is that the OBR downgraded our productivity, and itâ€™s going to be a safety-first Budget.
When asked if it would be a â€œsafety firstâ€ Budget, the MP said: â€œI hope not.
The capping of tuition fees at Â£9,250 was branded â€œdesperateâ€ by Labour â€“ who have vowed to abolish the charge entiterly.
TEXT:
Philip Hammond is planning to deliver a â€œsafety-firstâ€ budget with no giveaways for younger voters, HuffPost UK has learned.

The Chancellor is set to ignore calls from colleagues who want to see the public spending taps turned on in his November statement.

Last month, the Chancellor urged his colleagues to send him ideas on how to attract the millions of under 47s who shunned the Tories in the General Election.

Messages on housing and education costs seemed to be getting through to Hammond, with the Tories using their Party Conference to announce extra cash for the Help to Buy scheme, a freeze in tuition fees and more money for social housing.

However, HuffPost UK has been told Hammond is holding private meetings with Tory MPs, and they are being warned is is unlikely there will be headline-grabbing announcements in November as a result of pessimistic economic forecasts by the Office for Budget Responsibility.

Treasury sources insisted the Budget process is still ongoing, and no firm decisions have been made.

One MP told HuffPost UK: â€œThe truth of the Budget is that the OBR downgraded our productivity, and itâ€™s going to be a safety-first Budget.

â€œHeâ€™s pretty determined to keep to the fiscal rules â€“ thatâ€™s where we are on it.

The MP added: â€œMaybe now is the time to be cautious â€“ the OBR put a kibosh on anything else.â€

Another MP who gave a presentation on ideas for the Budget â€“ which included areas where savings could be made alongside increased spending â€“ told HuffPost UK they would be frustrated if the Chancellor was just going through the motions.

When asked if it would be a â€œsafety firstâ€ Budget, the MP said: â€œI hope not. Why else would he be getting us to make presentations?â€

Since Hammondâ€™s call for ideas at a meeting of backbench Tory MPs in September, the OBR has revised down its prediction of the UKâ€™s productivity.

In March, the OBR predicted productivity in the UK would grow by 1.7% - giving the Chancellor an extra Â£26billion for the public finances.

After the review, the OBR discovered it had over-estimated the UKâ€™s productivity for the past seven years.

It has been calculated as much as two-thirds of the Â£26billion fund â€“ which had been put aside as a Brexit war-chest - might not materalise.

The Toriesâ€™ conference announcements on housing and tuition fees were met with a muted response by many.

The free-market think tank The Adam Smith Institute described the extra Â£10billion being ploughed into the Help to Buy as â€œlike throwing petrol on to a bonfire,â€ while the Institute for Public Policy Research said the scheme not only pushed up property prices but only benefited those who can afford to buy homes anyway.

The capping of tuition fees at Â£9,250 was branded â€œdesperateâ€ by Labour â€“ who have vowed to abolish the charge entiterly.

Financial journalist Martin Lewis, founder of MoneySavingExpert.com, welcomed the raising of the level graduates would begin repayments from Â£21,000 to Â£25,000.
TITLE: Philip Hammond Planning A 'Safety-First' Budget With No Giveaways

TEXT:
Die Vierte Industrielle Revolution - Industrie 4.0 - ist die Konsequenz aus den verÃ¤nderten Rahmenbedingungen der Produktion in Deutschland und Europa. Ein herausragendes Ziel stellt die Sicherung der WettbewerbsfÃ¤higkeit der deutschen und europÃ¤ischen Industrie im internationalen Wettbewerb der Lieferketten dar.

Viele Unternehmen beschÃ¤ftigen sich intensiv mit dem Thema Industrie 4.0 und damit, wie sie die verfÃ¼gbaren Technologien gewinnbringend fÃ¼r sich nutzen kÃ¶nnen. Das ist wichtig und richtig. Jedoch wird dabei die QualitÃ¤t der Daten oft vernachlÃ¤ssigt, obwohl gerade diese Daten die hochautomatisierten Prozesse in der Industrie 4.0 steuern.

Head of Food Innovation and FoodTech METRO GROUP

Ich werde den Tag nie vergessen, als ich das erste Mal in einem Exoskelett stand. Seit neuneinhalb Jahren hatte ich nicht mehr gesehen, wie meine Beine laufen. Bei dem Anblick hatte ich TrÃ¤nen in den Augen.

Haben wir in Deutschland ein Problem? Gesunde Skepsis ist kein Problem, sondern unerlÃ¤sslich fÃ¼r Forschung, Innovation und Fortschritt. Aber wenn viele neue Ideen erst gar nicht ausprobiert werden, dann mÃ¼ssen wir etwas Ã¤ndern.

Doktorand der University of Bolton, Ã–konom, Mitglied der SPD

Die Welt wird sich Ã¤ndern. Und zwar gewaltig. Zwar befinden wir uns, noch, in zwei verschiedenen Welten: Auf der einen Seite Taxis, Zeitungen und der Atlas im Handschuhfach, auf der anderen Seite befindet sich Uber, Twitter und Google Maps.

Es ist Irrsinn zu glauben, oder sagen wir vorsichtiger, es spricht gerade nicht fÃ¼r hohe Intelligenz anzunehmen, dass Fakten fÃ¼r sich sprechen, dass also Fakten dies und das beim Betrachter nahelegen zu glauben, worauf er dann sein Wissen stÃ¼tzt.

Obwohl die Technik noch in den Kinderschuhen steckt, wird Augmented Reality als einer der grÃ¶ÃŸten Zukunftstrends gesehen. Welche Auswirkungen hat die Technik auf unseren Alltag und welche Risiken hinsichtlich Datenschutz gibt es?

Area Sales Vice President DACH and Eastern Europe, Collaboration-Experte, Blogger

"Die Technik streikt mal wieder" ist ein hÃ¤ufig gehÃ¶rter Satz in deutschen BÃ¼ros. Das Problem kennt jeder: WÃ¤hrend einer Besprechung will der Sprecher eine PrÃ¤sentation oder Excel-Datei mit den Kollegen teilen.

Falls es dieses Mal mit der Familienkarosse in die Ferien geht, gilt es einige Tipps fÃ¼r einen sorglosen Sommerurlaub zu beherzigen.

In den letzten Monaten sind zwei wichtige Dinge im Hinblick auf das Internet der Dinge (IoT) passiert: Zum einen haben viele Unternehmen erkannt, dass das IoT kein Hype ist, der sich Ã¼berholen wird und zum anderen haben viele nunmehr die Vorteile fÃ¼r sich und ihre Unternehmen erkannt.

Digitale Dienste haben in stark urbanisierten Regionen lÃ¤ngst Einzug gehalten. Konzepte, die sogenannte Smart Cities hervorbringen sind aktuell in aller Munde und schon vielerorts in der Praxis umgesetzt.
TITLE: Technologie

ADVERTISEMENTAUSTIN -- A 3-year-old girl in suburban Dallas is missing after her father said he punished her for not drinking her milk by telling her to stand outside by herself at night near an alley behind her home, police said on Monday.
Wesley Mathews, 37, has been arrested for suspected child endangerment for the treatment of his daughter, Sherin.
"Mathews said he directed his daughter to stand near a large tree at approximately 3 a.m. (on Saturday) because she wouldn't drink her milk," an arrest affidavit said.

Mathews told police that he had seen coyotes in the alley near where he told his daughter to stand, the affidavit said.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

AUSTIN -- A 3-year-old girl in suburban Dallas is missing after her father said he punished her for not drinking her milk by telling her to stand outside by herself at night near an alley behind her home, police said on Monday.

Wesley Mathews, 37, has been arrested for suspected child endangerment for the treatment of his daughter, Sherin. He was taken into custody on Saturday after reporting the incident to authorities and has been released on bond, according to police in Richardson, north of Dallas.

Mathews did not immediately respond to a request seeking comment.

"Mathews said he directed his daughter to stand near a large tree at approximately 3 a.m. (on Saturday) because she wouldn't drink her milk," an arrest affidavit said.

The father told police he checked on her about 15 minutes later and she was gone, the affidavit said.

About five hours after sending her outside, Mathews called police to report her missing, a police spokesman said.

Mathews told police that he had seen coyotes in the alley near where he told his daughter to stand, the affidavit said.

Sherin was born in India and had been adopted by Mathews' family. She suffered from malnourishment before arriving in the United States and is on a special diet, said Sergeant Kevin Perlich, a spokesman for the Richardson Police Department.
TITLE: Adopted Indian-Origin Girl Goes Missing In Dallas After Being Turned Out Of Her Home At 3 AM As Punishment

SANTÃ‰ - Les effets indÃ©sirables signalÃ©s depuis l'arrivÃ©e du nouveau Levothyrox sont dus Ã  "un dÃ©sÃ©quilibre thyroÃ¯dien" causÃ© par le changement de traitement et non Ã  la nouvelle formule elle-mÃªme, selon les premiers rÃ©sultats de l'enquÃªte de pharmacovigilance publiÃ©s mercredi 11 octobre par l'Agence du mÃ©dicament ANSM.

"Tous les effets indÃ©sirables tÃ©moignent d'un dÃ©sÃ©quilibre thyroÃ¯dien en lien avec le changement de traitement; aucun effet indÃ©sirable d'un type nouveau, qui serait spÃ©cifique de la seule nouvelle formule, n'a Ã©tÃ© retrouvÃ©", explique l'ANSM dans un communiquÃ©.

"Tout changement de spÃ©cialitÃ© ou de formule peut modifier l'Ã©quilibre hormonal et nÃ©cessiter un rÃ©ajustement du dosage" qui peut prendre "un certain dÃ©lai", poursuit l'Agence.

Au 15 septembre, "14.633 signalements ont Ã©tÃ© reÃ§us par les centres rÃ©gionaux de pharmacovigilance (CRPV)", selon l'ANSM.

"Sur ce total, les cas rapportÃ©s par les patients comme graves, c'est-Ã -dire dÃ©clarÃ©s comme ayant des consÃ©quences sur la vie familiale, professionnelle ou sociale, et les cas les plus documentÃ©s, soit 5.062 cas, ont pu Ãªtre enregistrÃ©s prioritairement dans la base nationale de pharmacovigilance (BNPV)", poursuit-elle.

Sur ces 5062 cas, quatre sont des dÃ©cÃ¨s, mais "le lien avec Levothyrox n'est pas Ã©tabli", est-il prÃ©cisÃ© dans le rapport de l'enquÃªte, mis en ligne sur le site de l'ANSM.

Le nombre de signalements d'effet indÃ©sirables est inÃ©dit

"Le recueil des signalements et l'enregistrement dans la BNPV se poursuivent et feront l'objet de publications ultÃ©rieures", prÃ©cise l'ANSM en soulignant que "les 14.633 signalements (...) reprÃ©sentent 0,6% des 2,6 millions de patients traitÃ©s par Levothyrox nouvelle formule".

"Le nombre de signalement d'effets indÃ©sirables avec Levothyrox nouvelle formule est inÃ©dit, avec un possible effet amplificateur du portail de signalement et des rÃ©seaux sociaux", relÃ¨ve le rapport.

Les effets les plus frÃ©quemment rapportÃ©s sont la fatigue, les maux de tÃªte, l'insomnie, les vertiges, les douleurs articulaires et musculaires et la chute de cheveux.

Les 5062 cas analysÃ©s concernent Ã  90,7% des femmes (9,3% d'hommes).

Le rapport s'interroge sur les cas de "certains patients qui prÃ©sentent Ã  la fois des signes d'hypo ou d'hyperthyroÃ¯die".

C'est l'une des raisons pour lesquelles ses auteurs souhaitent "que soit mis en place un groupe de travail constituÃ© de professionnels de santÃ©, pharmacovigilants et patients afin de poursuivre les investigations".

Une alternative au Levothyrox disponible le 16 octobre

La nouvelle formule du Levothyrox a Ã©tÃ© rÃ©clamÃ©e par l'ANSM au laboratoire Merck en 2012 afin, selon elle, de rendre le produit plus stable dans le temps. Le changement ne porte pas sur le principe actif mais sur d'autres substances, les excipients.

Face Ã  la colÃ¨re de patients signalant des effets secondaires, la ministre de la SantÃ© AgnÃ¨s Buzyn avait annoncÃ© le 15 septembre le retour sous quinze jours de l'ancienne formule avant l'arrivÃ©e de mÃ©dicaments alternatifs.

L'ancienne formule est arrivÃ©e dans les pharmacies le 2 octobre (sous le nom d'Euthyrox), mais pour une durÃ©e et dans des quantitÃ©s limitÃ©es.

AprÃ¨s cette solution transitoire, l'ANSM a annoncÃ© mercredi que le L-Thyroxin Henning (laboratoire Sanofi), destinÃ© Ã  offrir une alternative aux patients qui ne supportent pas le nouveau Levothyrox, serait disponible le 16 octobre (et Ã  partir du 23 dans les territoires d'Outre-Mer selon le laboratoire).

Enfin, un autre mÃ©dicament sera disponible Ã  partir de novembre. Jusqu'Ã  cette crise, le Levothyrox Ã©tait en situation de quasi-monopole en France.

De Mariana Mazza Ã  Denis Villeneuve, en passant par Ingrid Saint-Pierre, Kim ThÃºy, Louis-JosÃ© Houde, Samian, Robert Lepage et tant d'autres, la journaliste culturelle Ã‰milie Perreault rÃ©vÃ¨le l'influence parfois insoupÃ§onnÃ©e des artistes dans la vie du public, dans le livre Faire Å“uvre utile.

As-tu travaillÃ© sur ce livre, parce que tu as dÃ©jÃ  doutÃ© de l'utilitÃ© du mÃ©tier de journaliste culturel?

Je ne me suis jamais remise en question en me disant que mon travail ne servait Ã  rien. Par contre, aprÃ¨s avoir rencontrÃ© tous les gens pour le livre, j'ai rÃ©alisÃ© Ã  quel point la portÃ©e de l'art Ã©tait plus importante que je le croyais. Cela dit, j'ai une personnalitÃ© un peu nonchalante et j'ai tendance Ã  dire qu'on ne sauve pas des vies. En rÃ©flÃ©chissant Ã  cette formule, j'ai rÃ©alisÃ© que mon travail sert Ã  quelque chose. Par exemple, le lendemain des attentats au MÃ©tropolis, je parlais d'un nouvel album et je me demandais c'Ã©tait quoi le rapport de faire Ã§a. Mais je pense qu'on a besoin de sortir de cette violence et cet Ã©vÃ©nement dont on parle depuis trois heures. Ce n'est pas futile.

Tu as commencÃ© ta carriÃ¨re en 2007 au Grand Journal de TQS. Pratiques-tu ton mÃ©tier pour les mÃªmes raisons 10 ans plus tard?

Au dÃ©part, j'Ã©tais plus une passionnÃ©e des arts qui voulait voir plein de spectacles. Aujourd'hui, je me concentre sur le thrill de faire dÃ©couvrir des choses. Je me vois comme une curatrice de contenu. L'offre culturelle est tellement vaste que Ã§a ne sert Ã  rien de parler de tout. Je prÃ©fÃ¨re choisir et prendre le temps de communiquer aux auditeurs ce que j'aime. Je ne vais pas perdre mon temps prÃ©cieux en ondes Ã  expliquer pourquoi une piÃ¨ce dans un petit thÃ©Ã¢tre m'a dÃ©plu. En mÃªme temps, je ne suis pas une courroie de transmission qui sert Ã  plugger les artistes en disant que tout le monde est beau et fin. Quand un spectacle trÃ¨s attendu est dÃ©cevant, je dois le dire. Mais je prÃ©fÃ¨re aider les gens Ã  dÃ©couvrir la culture.

Tu racontes dans le livre qu'en voyant Guy Nadon dans Variations Ã©nigmatique, Ã  l'adolescence, tu as dÃ©cidÃ© de devenir Â«spectatrice professionnelleÂ». Est-ce qu'une Å“uvre a dÃ©jÃ  eu l'effet de rÃ©parer un morceau de ta vie, comme c'est le cas de plusieurs de tes intervenants?

Le monologue de Sophie Cadieux dans la piÃ¨ce Cette fille-lÃ . Je suis sortie de lÃ  avec l'impression de me rÃ©concilier avec une partie de mon adolescence. Je n'Ã©tais vraiment pas malheureuse, mais j'Ã©tais dans la gang du milieu, ni la plus cool ni la plus rejet, et j'avais en tÃªte qu'il fallait qu'on se tienne. Le personnage de Sophie raconte une histoire d'intimidation ultra intense et elle n'avait rien fait. Elle Ã©tait amie avec les bully et, sans y avoir participÃ©, elle se questionnait sur pourquoi elle n'avait rien fait. Je suis sortie de lÃ  en me disant que j'avais sÃ»rement fait des affaires d'une grande immaturitÃ© au secondaire, qui avaient blessÃ© des gens, que j'en prenais conscience, et que j'Ã©tais dÃ©sormais une adulte capable de faire mieux.

De quelle faÃ§on as-tu rÃ©coltÃ© ces anecdotes inÃ©dites?

Quand je rencontrais des artistes dans le cadre de mon travail, je terminais les entrevues en leur demandant s'ils avaient ce genre d'expÃ©rience. Et parfois, je partais Ã  la pÃªche en Ã©pluchant les commentaires sur les pages Facebook de certains artistes. C'Ã©tait un travail de Colombo.

Est-ce que c'Ã©tait rafraichissant de faire des entrevues avec des artistes sans rien promouvoir et de parler Ã  des gens du public?

Tout Ã  fait! Ã‡a allumait vraiment les artistes. Ce sont des choses qu'ils n'ont pas toujours eu le temps de verbaliser. Et j'adore interviewer les gens du public. Je trouvais Ã§a tripant d'entendre leurs histoires.

Sentais-tu que les artistes avaient eux aussi doutÃ© de l'utilitÃ© de leur travail un jour?

C'est une question Ã  laquelle ils pensent tous. Les gens peuvent Ãªtre trÃ¨s durs envers le milieu artistique. Peut-Ãªtre parce que certaines personnes envient les artistes de faire ce qu'ils veulent de leur vie. On les traite de Â«maudits artistesÂ» et de Â«tÃ©teux de subventionsÂ», alors que des entreprises comme Bombardier sont largement subventionnÃ©es, sans que les gens rÃ©agissent autant. Peut-Ãªtre que c'est plus confrontant de savoir qu'un musicien est payÃ© Ã  gratter sa guitare. Alors, les artistes ont une perception parfois nÃ©gative de leur travail. Dans le livre, Jean-Michel Blais raconte qu'il a arrÃªtÃ© de jouer du piano pendant un an, en se disant que c'Ã©tait une affaire de bourgeois, et il est parti Ã  l'Ã©tranger pour travailler dans un orphelinat. Mais quand il a recommencÃ© Ã  jouer, un homme lui a dit Â«Ã§a fait 14 mois que je ne vais pas bien et ce soir, durant ton spectacle, c'Ã©tait la premiÃ¨re fois que je pensais Ã  autre chose qu'Ã  ma maladieÂ». Ã‡a remet les choses en perspectives!

Quelle histoire t'a le plus touchÃ©e?

J'ai au moins huit rÃ©ponses Ã  Ã§a! C'est sÃ»r que l'histoire du pÃ¨re qui a oubliÃ© son enfant dans sa voiture et qui a Ã©tÃ© touchÃ© par le livre Naufrages de Biz m'a marquÃ©e. Je l'ai rencontrÃ© un 22 dÃ©cembre. Le 25, j'Ã©tais chez mes beaux-parents et je devais absolument Ã©crire son histoire. Il fallait qu'elle sorte de moi, sinon je n'aurais pas passÃ© un beau temps des FÃªtes. J'aime aussi celle de Denis Villeneuve et du policier qui regarde ses films pour dÃ©crocher, aprÃ¨s ses journÃ©es de travail de merde dans un coin trÃ¨s dur en Saskatchewan. C'est un exemple moins spectaculaire, mais Ã§a illustre vraiment bien l'idÃ©e de faire Å“uvre utile.

Laquelle gÃ©nÃ¨re le plus de commentaires des lecteurs jusqu'Ã  prÃ©sent?

Celle de la maman qui s'est reconnue dans un Ã©pisode de la tÃ©lÃ©sÃ©rie Ruptures (NDR : celui oÃ¹ des parents d'un enfant souffrant d'un trouble du spectre de l'autisme sont en dÃ©tresse). Elle s'est reconnue dans leur histoire. Elle a rÃ©alisÃ© qu'elle s'oubliait, elle aussi. Plusieurs personnes qui sont elles-mÃªmes des parents m'en ont parlÃ©. Peut-Ãªtre parce que plus de lecteurs avaient vu l'Ã©mission. Je pense d'ailleurs que le livre donne envie Ã  beaucoup de gens de dÃ©couvrir les chansons, les livres, les piÃ¨ces, les toiles ou les films des artistes dont il est question.

Ã‰milie Perreault sera prÃ©sente au Salon du livre de l'Estrie, le samedi 14 octobre 2017.

Aber warum kÃ¼ssen sich Menschen dann eigentlich so gerne mit Zunge?
Denn unbewusst nehmen wir die Hormone unseres Kusspartners wahr.
Shelly Volsche, Professorin fÃ¼r kulturelle Anthropologie an der University of Las Vegas im US-Bundesstaat Nevada fand heraus, dass Menschen, die keine ZungenkÃ¼sse kennen, stattdessen an ihren Gesichtern knabbern oder diese aneinander kuscheln.

TEXT:
Forscher haben verschiedene ErklÃ¤rungen gefunden, warum Menschen sich mit Zunge kÃ¼ssen

Die am weitesten verbreitete lautet: Die Partner testen unterbewusst, ob sie zueinander passen

Im Video oben erklÃ¤ren wir euch, wie das biologisch gesehen funktioniert

Beim Zungenkuss tauschen Menschen Speichel miteinander aus und noch dazu etwa 80 Millionen verschiedene Bakterien. Das klingt alles andere als appetitlich und schon gar nicht romantisch. Aber warum kÃ¼ssen sich Menschen dann eigentlich so gerne mit Zunge?

Forscher haben dafÃ¼r verschiedene ErklÃ¤rungen gefunden. Die am weitesten verbreitete lautet: Beim KÃ¼ssen kÃ¶nnen wir einschÃ¤tzen, ob die andere Person gesund und fruchtbar ist. Denn unbewusst nehmen wir die Hormone unseres Kusspartners wahr. Daraus leiten wir ab, ob der andere Mensch zu uns passt.

Vor allem Testosteron ist gut aus dem Speichel des Partners zu erkennen. Das geschieht Ã¼ber Nase und Mund. Die Anthropologin Helen Fisher vermutet, dass MÃ¤nner beim KÃ¼ssen ihr Testosteron an die Frau Ã¼bertragen wollen, um deren Sexualtrieb zu erhÃ¶hen.

MÃ¶glicherweise ist es nur eine Angewohnheit

Biologisch notwendig ist der Zungenkuss jedoch nicht. Shelly Volsche, Professorin fÃ¼r kulturelle Anthropologie an der University of Las Vegas im US-Bundesstaat Nevada fand heraus, dass Menschen, die keine ZungenkÃ¼sse kennen, stattdessen an ihren Gesichtern knabbern oder diese aneinander kuscheln.

Das Team um die Professorin stellte fest, dass es den Zungenkuss gerade einmal in 46 Prozent aller menschlichen Kulturen gibt - und nicht, wie die Forscher erwartet hatten, in 90 Prozent.

MÃ¶glicherweise kÃ¼ssen sich viele Menschen also nur mit Zunge, weil es eine kulturelle Angewohnheit geworden ist. Oder - und diese ErklÃ¤rung ist ein bisschen schÃ¶ner - einfach nur, um zu zeigen, wie sehr sie sich mÃ¶gen.

SUMMARY:
PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Memories Of Summer In The Cinque Terre To be suddenly transported away from the daily grind to this magical place, and to be able to experience it together, was an incredibly special experience.
London-based photographer and blogger at skyeoneill.comPROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Disneyland Paris - My Best Holiday Moment You might think a visit to Nepal or a climb on Kilimanjaro would've been more appropriate for the best holiday moment blog post.
London-based lifestyle influencer, eatweartravel.com PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Wonderful, Wonderful Copenhagen With Family This year however, have decided to be a little more organised with our long weekends - and have MADE time to leave London, (and paused all the weekend clubs!)
Travel journalist, blogger at English Mum PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Peruvian Nostalgia: A Happy Travel Moment It's those little things, the five-minute moments and the spontaneous detours you'll never forget that are the best thing about holidays for me.
Irish Travel Blogger.
TEXT:
PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Memories Of Summer In The Cinque Terre To be suddenly transported away from the daily grind to this magical place, and to be able to experience it together, was an incredibly special experience. London-based photographer and blogger at skyeoneill.com

PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Disneyland Paris - My Best Holiday Moment You might think a visit to Nepal or a climb on Kilimanjaro would've been more appropriate for the best holiday moment blog post. For me, it was the emotion of a lost childhood recaptured in three days. It was the child in me finally seeing a dream come true. London-based lifestyle influencer, eatweartravel.com PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Wonderful, Wonderful Copenhagen With Family This year however, have decided to be a little more organised with our long weekends - and have MADE time to leave London, (and paused all the weekend clubs!) and jump on a plane to mainland Europe - to places we've never been before... London-based creative communicator, writer, and designer PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS How Mickey Mouse Changed My Life Spotting beautiful Cinderella Castle for the first time, pretty, pastel and huge at the end of bustling Main Street USA, we're already grabbing each other's hands, laughing and breathless with disbelief. Travel journalist, blogger at English Mum PROMOTED BY BRITISH AIRWAYS HOLIDAYS Peruvian Nostalgia: A Happy Travel Moment It's those little things, the five-minute moments and the spontaneous detours you'll never forget that are the best thing about holidays for me. Surround yourself with holiday memories and whenever you get a chance, go and make more! Travel blogger at Flash Anthology

Why I Hate The Phrase 'Gap Year' The amount of times I've heard people say to me; "do it why you're young", as if the only time that we should open ourselves up to new possibilities is when we're still young enough to enjoy them, before age, and responsibility bears down on us, and we can no longer afford to take a break from our lives. Writer & journalist

48 Hours In... St Lucia Everything about St Lucia is green. From her lushly vegetated peaks undulating across the teardrop shaped island, to her twinkling emerald waters, it's a Caribbean paradise chock-full of geological marvels. Arts, lifestyle and socio-political writer

Traversing The Rockies - Week 4 (D28-30) After 10km, and a river crossing made making us unavoidably wet, we lost the path. Multiple small rivers and bogs had us pretty much soaked. One river crossing had to be made across a log and while Stan managed it with relative ease, I obviously fell off and into fast flowing river up to my hips. Lucy is a London based Doctor setting out to traverse the Canadian Rocky Mountains on the Great Divide Trail- 2 people, 60 days, 1600km.

Is This Ireland's Best Kept Secret? I thought I knew this part of Ireland pretty well until we arrived in Glengarriff and I quickly realised this is a part of my home county I have failed to explore. The view from our hotel upon check in was magical, the soft evening light reflecting on the bay. Irish Travel Blogger. Skyscanner addict.

Traversing The Rockies - Week Four (D25-27) After a warm night, and consequently an abundance of mozzies we started out along the Brazeau River. Expecting torrential rain from Diane's sat phone weather report, we donned our waterproofs at the first raindrops but this proved to be a big mistake with the upcoming climb! Lucy is a London based Doctor setting out to traverse the Canadian Rocky Mountains on the Great Divide Trail- 2 people, 60 days, 1600km.

Chapter 2: Fear And Judgement What I have to regularly remind myself is that people will judge you whether you worry about their opinions or not, so you may as well do what you want to do. Plus, when you think about it, worrying about the opinion of others is actually incredibly self-indulgent because it's based on the assumption that you are important enough to others that they even care about what you're up to. Presenter, DJ, writer, and secret hopeless romantic

Yes, I Take Full Responsibility For This Disease I Can't Control... It has crossed my mind many times that it would be much easier to just not tell people I have epilepsy. But there is always that chance of a seizure, and the risk of something going wrong - or someone doing something wrong - is reduced if we all talk about epilepsy a little bit more and encourage people with epilepsy to do more. If I've decided I can take the risk, you can too. Writer with a tongue-testing name. Condensing the world into frantic words.

The Time Of My Life Losing my wife and soul mate Katie is the most difficult thing I have ever had to face. It is a reality I had never imagined and should never have needed to comprehend, but in many ways, I was fortunate. I don't enjoy writing that, but there is a truth to it. Blogger, cyclist, runner, triathlete, widower, traveler, animal lover.

Quintessential British Retreats: Cliveden House Hotel And Spa, Berkshire It its past glory as a private country house estate, it's said that no one would turn down an invitation to Cliveden. In its 350-year history, Cliveden has hosted every British monarch since George I and is most famous as the home of the Astors and the setting for the scandal of the Profumo Affair. Reviews and recommendations of handpicked luxury spa hotels, resorts and wellness retreats around the globe.

Chapter 1: Going Travelling "Holy fuck!", I thought as I walked through airport security, away from a waving Charlotte as I fought back tears. It seemed ironic that in walking into airport security, I was leaving behind my own. "What the fu*king fu*k am I doing?" Presenter, DJ, writer, and secret hopeless romantic

EU-Kommission soll entmachtet werden

Volkswirt Dullien, Professor an der Hochschule fÃ¼r Technik und Wirtschaft in Berlin, erklÃ¤rt, dass fÃ¼r SchÃ¤uble der ESM kÃ¼nftig eine zentrale Rolle spielen soll. Dullien betont: "Dieser Ansatz lÃ¤uft auf eine Entmachtung der EU-Kommission und einer StÃ¤rkung des ESM heraus."



AuffÃ¤llig ist aus Sicht Dulliens, "dass es weltweit keinen WÃ¤hrungsraum gibt, der nach den Vorstellungen SchÃ¤ubles funktioniert." Er bezweifelt deshalb, dass die VorschlÃ¤ge "zu einem sinnvollen Funktionieren der Euro-Zone fÃ¼hren" werden.

Macron wird das Duell verlieren

Das Ziel von Frankreichs Staatschef dagegen: Mit einem eigenen Budget fÃ¼r den Euroraum will er Ã¶ffentliche Investitionen zu tÃ¤tigen. Und so verhindern, dass Drittstaaten - wie in der Griechenland-Krise - massiv die Investitionen der betroffenen LÃ¤nder beschneiden und damit die Krise weiter verstÃ¤rken.



Macron werde sich mit seinen VorschlÃ¤gen aber nicht durchsetzen, glaubt Dullien:

â–º Einerseits habe Deutschland faktisch ein Veto-Recht bei Reformen der Euro-Zone.

â–º Andererseits habe Berlin aufgrund der besseren wirtschaftlichen Lage und guter Staatsfinanzen eine stÃ¤rkere Verhandlungsposition.

Der Volkswirt hÃ¤lt es aber fÃ¼r unwahrscheinlich, dass Frankreich einem Mechanismus der Schuldenrestrukturierung zustimmen wird.



Kommt es in Deutschland tatsÃ¤chlich zu einer Jamaika-Koalition mit einem FDP- oder einem CDU-Finanzminister - wonach es derzeit aussieht - "wÃ¼rde es in den kommenden Jahren keinen Fortschritt bei der Reform der Euro-Zone geben", kritisiert Dullien.

Sollte die Euro-Krise wieder aufflammen, sind mÃ¶glicherweise keine ausreichenden Vorkehrungen getroffen, um diese sinnvoll abzufedern. Im Extremfall kÃ¶nnte die Euro-Zone sogar auseinanderbrechen, warnt Dullien - mit verheerenden Folgen fÃ¼r die Export-Nation Deutschland.

TEXT:
The interview questions about genital touching conducted by OMGYes were very specific: What amount of pressure do you prefer? (from being touched very lightly to medium and hard pressure); What shape or style of motion do you prefer? (â€œSide to side, up and down, diagonal, circular, tall ovals, wide ovals, pushing/pressing in one spot, pulsating/rapid pushing in one spot,â€ etc.); Where do you prefer to be touched on your vulva/vagina? (â€œDirectly on clitoris, on the skin around clitoris, avoid touching clitoris directly, occasionally brushing over clitoris but not applying pressure to it,â€ etc.); And, lastly, what preference of touch do you prefer? (fingers, hands, mouth, etc.).

According to the studyâ€™s findings, two thirds of respondents preferred direct clitoral stimulation with most reporting that they also like stimulation just around the clitoris.

When it comes to preferred shapes and styles of genital touching, 63 percent of women said they like up and down motions and 51 percent of women said they liked circular movements. A good amount of women (41 percent) preferred just one style of touch instead of multiple. Researchers also found that most women prefer light or medium pressure, with 16 percent reported that they liked all types of pressure during stimulation.

â€œWomen might find it helpful to think about these different dimensions of genital touch or stimulation when exploring their sexual response during solo or partnered sexual play,â€ the study reads. â€œAnd therapists and educators might find these dimensions helpful in making specific suggestions to couples. Having these four dimensions of touch in mind may give individuals or couples more direction or concrete ideas to experiment with that go beyond broad encouragement to simply â€˜go explore and see what you like.â€™â€

This article has been updated with more information about the 2014-2015 OMGYes video chat interviews. The headline has been changed to better reflect the content of those interviews.
TITLE: Women Reveal The Specific Movements That Make Them Orgasm

SUMMARY:
Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury, Labour MP for Feltham and HestonWho Would Win In A Fight: Parliament Or The U.S. Congress?
But it does limit the life of a Parliament to five years.
In the 18th century, Britain's Parliament redefined modern democracy; in the 21st, it can do so again.
Head, ACCA UKWomen Our Parliament Still Needs You!
Photo: 50:50 Parliament the 21st Century Suffragettes demanding political equality So the 2017 General Election is over.
TEXT:
Brexit: Under The Cover Of Darkness The government should be open with the British people and make public the information they have to allow for a full and factual debate that covers both the risks and benefits of leaving the European Union and informs the debate about our priorities for Brexit negotiations. It is their responsibility and duty to do so. Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury, Labour MP for Feltham and Heston

Who Would Win In A Fight: Parliament Or The U.S. Congress? Let's assume that they do not have any weapons, and we're talking about a fist fight... A place to share knowledge and better understand the world

Why I Am Supporting The International Week Of The Deaf This is a community which is underappreciated and often underrepresented and that is why this week we must celebrate the achievements of the deaf community who are often not recognised enough. It is vital that we give deaf people the right support to enable the full inclusion of sign language in everyday life. Labour MP for Brent Central

How Long Until The Next General Election? It Could Be Longer Than You Think The FTPA (as anyone who has got this far probably knows) means Parliament will sit for a fixed 5-year term rather than the Prime Minister of the day calling a General Election when it suits them (yes, yes, I know). But it does limit the life of a Parliament to five years. Except that under the Withdrawal Bill, a minister could argue that the Brexit process is still incomplete... Officially Endorsed by the President of the United States... I wish that were a good thing

Lord Neuberger's Salutary Warning Many recent bad court decisions cry out for revocation, but I wonder whether the current British government is even aware of the existence of this nuclear option, let alone courageous enough to use it. Barrister at Law, Sometime Fellow of St John's College, Cambridge

Scrapping Tuition Fees Is Regressive, We Need Reform And To Bring Back Grants The current system needs change: bring back grants, keep interest rates to inflation and explore more ways to reform the progressive system we have now. If income tax needs to be raised to fund the grants, go ahead, but abolishing tuition fees is taking two steps back after moving an inch forward. Lib Dem campaigner in Cambridge, bodyman for Susan van de Ven. Toby Ziegler wannabe.

Want To Help Those Struggling To Find Secure Work, Prime Minister? Back My Bill It's going to be tough work, but I'm excited and driven by the opportunity to make things a bit better for people. I hope you will get behind me and lobby your own MP to back my Bill. If you want to share your experiences of unpaid trial shifts, or just give me your views on the Bill then visit my website - www.stewartmcdonald.scot - and respond to my online consultation today. SNP MP for Glasgow South

We Must All Echo Theresa May's Sense Of Duty And Public Service To Get Brexit Right I'm glad the Prime Minister decided to tackle what's been going on behind her back. Not for her sake, but for everyone else's. It's safe to say that Theresa May will not be remembered as a brilliant politician, but what she has going for her is a great sense of duty and public service. And don't knock it as some consolation prize. Right now, it's what the country needs. Conservative peer and former Leader of the House of Lords

This Is Not The Political Silly Season So far from the Summer being the political 'silly season' it will be critical to pay attention to what happens this year. Your promised 'digital detox' sitting on a beach will have to wait. Instead, look forward to checking Twitter, news sites and your digital subscriptions. Public affairs consultant at Bircham Dyson Bell

Why Can't May Cosy Up To Trump Like Macron Did? What I find fascinating is the difference in tone many of these publications took when covering Theresa May's visit to Washington in January. Then, a leader of a large European country with a surprisingly fragile economy cosying up to Trump was seen as desperate. Now, it's being portrayed as a bromance. Why? Student journalist, blogger and contributor to The National Student

Politicians Can't Agree On Brexit - Give The People A Say The rallying cry of 'take back control,' which inspired so many voters, will not be realised within the constraints of our Parliamentary democracy. More ambition is required. In the 18th century, Britain's Parliament redefined modern democracy; in the 21st, it can do so again. Rob J Adam is an independent journalist and researcher.

Charities Should Seize The Opportunity Offered By The Parliamentary Arithmetic Let's hope that charities and others will act and not stand aside. I have confidence that there is an opportunity for social action at a local and national level on an unprecedented scale with the result that there will be change - and that this change will be for the better. Independent strategic advisor

Government Needs To Listen To Business On Brexit As Downing Street discovered the hard way, a shielded and closed door approach will not work on an issue that affects so many in many different ways. An inclusive approach is what is needed to create a cohesive Brexit plan that gets the support of business and society alike. Now is the time for government to listen. Head, ACCA UK

Women Our Parliament Still Needs You! Photo: 50:50 Parliament the 21st Century Suffragettes demanding political equality So the 2017 General Election is over. There are 12 more women at ... Founder of the 50:50 Parliament Campaign
TITLE: Parliament

Benita, MarÃ­a Guadalupe y Rosario caminan por las calles de Chilapa, cabecera del municipio del mismo nombre en el convulso estado de Guerrero.

Todas las historias tienen en comÃºn que las vÃ­ctimas son hombres, en edad productiva, y que, en la mayorÃ­a de los casos, son indÃ­genas y de escasos recursos econÃ³micos.

Todos, ademÃ¡s, no han sido investigados adecuadamente por las autoridades competentes y han sido las propias familias quienes han jalado los hilos de las averiguaciones de los hechos que "uno nunca cree que le van a pasar a uno".

Vista de la avenida principal de Chilapa.

UNO BUSCA CON 'LA MAÃ‘A'

JesÃºs Pineda MejÃ­a, de profesiÃ³n optometrista, desapareciÃ³ el 19 de julio de 2016. "Yo lo vi baÃ±ado, cambiado y todo, lo vi listo para irse a trabajar. Yo regreso como a las 10 am y mi trabajador me dice 'doÃ±a Rosa, estÃ¡n avisando que a JesÃºs su hijo lo levantaron' -- cuenta su madre Rosario MejÃ­a y en un punto en que se le quiebra la voz--, le digo eso no es cierto, y seguÃ­ haciendo mis cosas, es algo que da miedo, nervios y son las cosas que uno no cree que le van a pasar a uno.

LA DESAPARICIÃ“N FORZADA SE HACE EVIDENTE

El Centro Regional de Defensa de Derechos Humanos JosÃ© Ma. Morelos y PavÃ³n AC, el cual se ha dedicado a documentar el contexto violento de Chilapa y Zitlala Guerrero, seÃ±ala que la desapariciÃ³n forzada se hizo evidente tras la incursiÃ³n de presuntos policÃ­as comunitarios que entre el 9 y 14 de mayo de 2015 detuvieron, y desaparecieron, a al menos 16 hombres pese a la presencia de la GendarmerÃ­a, el EjÃ©rcito, la PolicÃ­a Federal y municipal.

En Chilapa, por ejemplo, desde principios de enero comenzaron a conformar un padrÃ³n de vÃ­ctimas y, hasta ahora, los familiares de desaparecidos siguen sin recibir apoyo econÃ³mico, denuncia el Centro Morelos.

NO SABEMOS NADA DE NINGUNO DE LOS DOS

Esmeralda HuaxtitlÃ¡n Sixtos estudiaba la carrera de enfermerÃ­a en el Conalep y tenÃ­a 35 aÃ±os cuando desapareciÃ³ al ir a buscar a su hijo Erick, del que tampoco se sabÃ­a su paradero. Erick Geovanni GarcÃ­a HuaxtitlÃ¡n tenÃ­a 18 aÃ±os aquel 20 de octubre de un aÃ±o atrÃ¡s cuando ya no se supo mÃ¡s de ninguno de ellos.

"Ã‰l (Erick) iba a dejar normalmente a su mamÃ¡ en la moto, pero de Ã©l ya no supimos en toda la tarde. Mi hermana regresa entre las 8 o 9 de la noche y pregunta a su otro hijo por su hermano, Ã©ste le dice que no lo habÃ­a visto en todo el dÃ­a. Le empezÃ³ a marcar a su telÃ©fono y ya no le contestaba. Cerca de las 11 de la noche, saliÃ³ a buscar a su hijo mayor, a esas horas ella saliÃ³ y ya no regresÃ³. Y hasta ahora, no sabemos nada de ninguno de los dos", cuenta sin evitar el llanto la hermana de Esmeralda.

Fue hasta un mes despuÃ©s de la desapariciÃ³n que la familia acudiÃ³ a denunciar.

AndÃ¡bamos dedicados a investigar con vecinos y familiares y no tuvimos respuesta y pues entre miedo y preocupaciÃ³n se nos pasaron los dÃ­as; cuando denunciamos, nos daban largas y siguiÃ³ transcurriendo el tiempo, hicimos la denuncia pero hasta despuÃ©s de un mes, por miedo, coraje, y la inseguridad, porque estando en una situaciÃ³n asÃ­, a veces la misma familia te dice que es tu problema y te las arregles como puedas."

MÃS SEGURIDAD, MÃS VÃCTIMAS

El 27 de enero de 2016 en la regiÃ³n se implementÃ³ un megaoperativo con mÃ¡s de 3 mil elementos del EjÃ©rcito, la Marina, la PolicÃ­a Federal y la estatal, a fin de disminuir la cifra de secuestros y homicidios.

Si embargo, ese mismo aÃ±o se contabilizaron sÃ³lo en Chilapa y Zitlala 205 asesinatos, 41 desaparecidos, 26 heridos en hechos violentos, ocho secuestros y se hallaron 56 cuerpos en fosas clandestinas.

De la cifra de muertos destaca que 23 fueron decapitados, 68 asesinados con arma de fuego, seis calcinados, 16 desmembrados y 33 perdieron la vida durante enfrentamientos.

TENÃA UNA SEMANA EN EL NUEVO TRABAJO Y LO MATARON CON OCHO TIROS

Kevin Castro DomÃ­nguez acabada de cumplir 18 aÃ±os, era estudiante del Colegio de Bachilleres, hacÃ­a danza folclÃ³rica y reciÃ©n habÃ­a integrado un grupo de apoyo a personas con adicciones.

Tras dejar un empleo en una tienda Oxxo, entrÃ³ a trabajar a un centro botanero. Llevaba tres dÃ­as atendiendo el lugar cuando, por la noche, llegÃ³ una camioneta con hombres armados, se estacionÃ³ delante del negocio y dos hombres balearon el lugar.

"A dos clientes les dieron un balazo a cada uno, tomaron a mi hijo, lo agarraron de los cabellos â€“se deduce por la forma en que quedÃ³ el cuerpoâ€” le dieron ocho balazos y no se morÃ­a, se muriÃ³ en el hospital, yo creo esperaba a que yo llegara", cuenta su padre Lamberto Castro.

INVESTIGACIÃ“N DE PROPIA MANO

La desapariciÃ³n de su hijo JosÃºe Molina RodrÃ­guez, de 30 aÃ±os, llevÃ³ a MarÃ­a Guadalupe RodrÃ­guez Narciso a convertirse en una obsesiva investigadora del caso de su hijo ante la omisiÃ³n de las autoridades y en la aguerrida cabeza de una organizaciÃ³n dedicada a la bÃºsqueda de personas.

Hay una complicidad inmensa, grande, desde las altas autoridades hasta el Ãºltimo policÃ­a y la verdad sÃ­ estamos en una situaciÃ³n crÃ­tica y delicadÃ­sima." MarÃ­a Guadalupe RodrÃ­guez Narciso.

El colectivo que tambiÃ©n comanda estÃ¡ investigando los casos de la gente viva, "porque aquÃ­ todo mundo busca muertos, busca tumbas, pero de los vivos no nos preocupamos, cuando hay gente viva secuestrada, gente que estÃ¡ al servicio de la delincuencia."

MarÃ­a cuenta que un joven que buscaba a su hermano en la sierra, encontrÃ³ en una barranca de Chichihualco, muchos cadÃ¡veres, pero tambiÃ©n gente viva en varios puntos de la sierra que presumiblemente es obligada a trabajar para grupos de la delincuencia organizada procesando la droga.

"Empiezo a rastrear esa informaciÃ³n y la llevo a la PGR para investigar a esa gente, para bajar a esa gente viva, porque ahÃ­ podrÃ­a estar mi hijo, los hijos de los compaÃ±eros. Me cerraron las puertas, recurro a mi Ministerio PÃºblico de PGR, para que tambiÃ©n protegieran al muchacho, pero incluso ya nos estaban criminalizando diciendo que pertenecÃ­amos al grupo de Los Rojos para que no nos hicieran caso.

"Ã‰l contÃ³ lo que sabÃ­a, hablÃ³ sobre un autobÃºs que no aparecÃ­a donde supuestamente irÃ­an los estudiantes normalistas de Ayotzinapa y que bajÃ³ de la sierra; por eso turnaron el caso a la FiscalÃ­a de los 43, le tomaron su declaraciÃ³n, su denuncia, sin darle medidas de seguridad. La FiscalÃ­a de los 43 declinÃ³ la competencia a SEIDO y Ã©sta la regresÃ³ a la delegaciÃ³n PGR de Chilpancingo, donde estÃ¡n coludidos", narra la activista.

El joven, que habÃ­a declarado en mayo de este aÃ±o, desapareciÃ³ en julio. No se sabe nada de Ã©l.

De ahÃ­ lo que pasÃ³ es que el testigo desapareciÃ³, y estaba muy dispuesto a entrar a la sierra, a ir de guÃ­a y a seÃ±alar los puntos donde tenÃ­an a la gente." MarÃ­a Guadalupe RodrÃ­guez Narciso.

AsÃ­, continÃºan las narraciones de los familiares de los desaparecidos de Chilapa, con leves variantes y con el comÃºn denominador de investigaciones mal llevadas y la colusiÃ³n de las autoridades. Y tras ellos, el sismo del 19 de septiembre de 2017 y, con Ã©l, otra vez el silencio sobre estas vÃ­ctimas.
TITLE: Chilapa, el municipio secuestrado: â€œAquÃ­ todo mundo busca muertos, no gente vivaâ€

Speaking at the public event, Kumar said, "This nation should not tolerate them as part of India."
"This nation should not tolerate them as part of India."
Thorat as the head of the ICSSR, an autonomous body established by the Indian government in 1969 to promote social studies research.
The Hindu further reported that Kumar had also claimed that Rajput king Prithviraj Chauhan beat Ghori 17 times but did not kill him.
TEXT:
COXS BAZAR, BANGLADESH OCTOBER 11: 4-year-old Rohingya kid Shehna starts journey from Myanmar on the shoulder of his father, to the refugee camp at Balukhali in Coxs Bazar, Bangladesh on October 11, 2017. (Photo by Stringer/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images)

ADVERTISEMENT

Even as thousands of Rohingya Muslims are fleeing Myanmar to escape violence and persecution at the hands of the country's military and police, the chief of India's premier body on social sciences believes they should not be tolerated in India.

The Hindu today reported on the remarks made by Braj Bihari Kumar, who heads the Indian Council of Social Science Research (ICSSR), at a seminar recently organized by the Indian Council of Historical Research (ICHR).

Speaking at the public event, Kumar said, "This nation should not tolerate them as part of India."

"This nation should not tolerate them as part of India."

Earlier this year, Kumar succeeded prominent academic S.K. Thorat as the head of the ICSSR, an autonomous body established by the Indian government in 1969 to promote social studies research.

Kumar, 76, served has the editor of two journals, Dialogue and Chintan Srijan, published by Astha Bharati, a non-profit organisation dedicated to promoting "India's unity and integrity."

The online news outlet, Scroll, has previously reported on the opinions that Kumar has professed over the course of years, including, "There is none in India, who has suffered more due to intolerance than Narendra Modi."

Kumar's remarks come at a time when the Modi government is making a legal case to deport Rohingya Muslim refugees from India, branding them as national security threat. The central government's position has been condemned by human rights activists and lawyers who argue that even those who are not citizens are guaranteed protection under the Indian Constitution when they are on Indian soil.

"There is none in India, who has suffered more due to intolerance than Narendra Modi."

Speaking at the ICHR event, Kumar said, "We should like to know about the Rohingyas also. What is their record? In 1943, when war was going on between the British and the Japanese, the British government of Burma supplied arms and ammunitions to the Rohingyas to fight against the Japanese, and the Rohingyas turned the gun towards the Buddhists," he said.

"How can Burmese forget such enemies? They are not fools like Indians. The Burmese remember their enemies,"" Kumar continued. "My point is that we can't placate illegal migrants. We should not do it. This nation should not tolerate them as a part of India."

The Hindu further reported that Kumar had also claimed that Rajput king Prithviraj Chauhan beat Ghori 17 times but did not kill him. The newspaper pointed out that history tells us there were only two battles.

Also on HuffPost India:
TITLE: India Should Not Tolerate Rohingya Muslims, Says Chief Of Premier Social Sciences Body

If you're looking for a spiritual pilgrimage, then look no further than these remarkable houses of worship around the globe.
From the red rocks of Arizona to the bustling streets of Moscow, these sacred sites are sure to inspire some wanderlust:

SUMMARY:
Both of these qualities are abundantly evident in her new novella, When the Moon Shines By Day, published recently by Speaking Tiger (Hardcover, â‚¹399), which reads like a chilling commentary on our time.
The India that Sahgal sets her story in reminds us, with alarming familiarity, of the one we live in the here and now â€” except it's descended into a worse dystopia.
Much like Sahgal, earlier this year, Prayaag Akbar brought alive the crises of being alive in this moment with a terrifying clarity in his novel, Leila.
The aroma of pekoe orange blossom tea at the ladies' book club gets fouled by the stink of violence, repeated sagas of bloodlust and massacre.
In spite of the rough edges and choppy jump-cuts, Sahgal's wit and humanity glitters occasionally, especially in Rohner's bawdy wisecracks.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

At 90, Nayantara Sahgal stands tall among writers in India for her courage of conviction and belief in the secular spirit of the nation enshrined by the leaders who brought it into being. Both of these qualities are abundantly evident in her new novella, When the Moon Shines By Day, published recently by Speaking Tiger (Hardcover, â‚¹399), which reads like a chilling commentary on our time.

Although only 167 pages long, the story is packed with ideas, most of which Sahgal highlighted two years ago when she returned the Sahitya Akademi award in the wake of the murder of rationalist MM Kalburgi. Setting an example with her symbolic gesture, she opened the floodgates of dissent among intellectuals across the country, writing in a range of languages, who joined her in returning their awards to protest against vicious attacks on India's age-old tradition of debate, discussion and dissent.

The silencing of anti-establishment voices, brutally brought home by the recent murder of journalist Gauri Lankesh for instance, is captured with a lacerating irony by the title itself. Deceptively poetic, the phrase is evoked by the protagonist, Rehana, to explain to her friends her reason to continue working with Asians Against Torture, a human-rights organisation: "Because people are tortured for refusing to agree the moon shines by day and the sun by night..." The barbaric premonitions this admission opens up are borne out by the plot, which, in spite of its episodic fragments, conjures up a vision of pure hell.

The India that Sahgal sets her story in reminds us, with alarming familiarity, of the one we live in the here and now â€” except it's descended into a worse dystopia. The trappings of anarchy are cemented ever more firmly: books are banned, paintings destroyed and people get killed on the suspicion of carrying a suitcase made of cowhide, presided over by the all-pervasive eye of the Director of Cultural Transformation.

The latter's views on the vandalism of history are unambiguous. "We cannot forget the pain of invasions," he informs a gallery owner on hearing a complaint of rampant hooliganism at a show, "the Turks, Mongols, Mughals, foreigners who interrupted our Hindu history." Wiping out "that painful memory and returning our nation by all possible means to its racial and religious purity" is, in his book, a matter of "plain justice".

If such passages strike as too unadorned, they also ring uncomfortably true, hitting home the heady reality of conflicts and confusions contemporary India is immersed in. Much like Sahgal, earlier this year, Prayaag Akbar brought alive the crises of being alive in this moment with a terrifying clarity in his novel, Leila. In a keenly-imagined dystopia, towards which present-day India seems to be inexorably hurtling, Akbar framed a story of an outcaste searching for her daughter and husband for nearly two decades, who were wrenched from her by the might of a police state, bent on preserving religious purity by condemning intermarriage.

In Sahgal's story, terror percolates into the genteel drawing-room conversations of Rehana and her friends, who gather for a book club, holding on to the vestiges of art and literature at a time neither can provide much consolation. Characters like Kamlesh, a bureaucrat with an interest in Mughal history, especially in the alleged depravities of Shah Jahan, including his incestuous relationship with his daughter, or Franz Rohner, a German historian of the Third Reich, act as foils to their title-tattle. The aroma of pekoe orange blossom tea at the ladies' book club gets fouled by the stink of violence, repeated sagas of bloodlust and massacre.

Exposed to the horrors of a dictatorial regime through her work with victims of torture, Rehana is the fiery conscience that shines through the darkness in which the novel is plunged. Even as she witnesses her lover Zamir's turbulent predicament for his religion and 'subversive' writing, the disappearance of her father's books on medieval history from public holdings, and the bottomless cruelty of everyday life, she manages to retain a humane curiosity about the world around her.

Rehana's friendship with Rohner is Sahgal's point of entry into larger historical questions about the fate of totalitarian regimes, comparing these with the ones in Europe of the 1930s and 40s. Such parallels may appear a bit stretched and Sahgal's detour into the past somewhat didactic, but the timing of the novel ameliorates such aesthetic grudges. In spite of the rough edges and choppy jump-cuts, Sahgal's wit and humanity glitters occasionally, especially in Rohner's bawdy wisecracks.

"Are they not the man who mounts his woman with no please-may-I, gallops to glory, rolls of his mount and snores himself to sleep?" he says, memorably, on being asked his opinion about revolutions, saving a punch for the end. "And the woman? Ah, the woman! She lies awake plotting how to kill him."

Also on HuffPost
TITLE: Book Review: 'When The Moon Shines By Day' By Nayantara Sahgal

SUMMARY:
Nick Clegg has said Nigel Farage should be the â€œrole modelâ€ for committed Remain voters who want to see the UK rejoin the EU.
In his new book, How To Stop Brexit, due to be published on Thursday, Clegg said Farageâ€™s â€œsheer bloody-minded refusal to give upâ€ on achieving Brexit should be seen as an â€œinspirationâ€.
And in an extract of the book published on HuffPost UK on Thursday, Clegg said the â€œsilver liningâ€ of the Brexit vote â€œmay lead to the conditions in which the UK could be reintegrated into a reformed EUâ€.
â€œBritain has enjoyed a special status throughout our time as a member of the EU and, should we choose to, we could do so once again.
It would be a logical continuation of what we have previously achieved on so many occasions,â€ he said.
TEXT:
Nick Clegg has said Nigel Farage should be the â€œrole modelâ€ for committed Remain voters who want to see the UK rejoin the EU.

The former deputy prime minister said while Britain was on course to leave the EU in March 2019, there was no reason that had to be the end of the â€œdreamâ€.

In his new book, How To Stop Brexit, due to be published on Thursday, Clegg said Farageâ€™s â€œsheer bloody-minded refusal to give upâ€ on achieving Brexit should be seen as an â€œinspirationâ€.

And in an extract of the book published on HuffPost UK on Thursday, Clegg said the â€œsilver liningâ€ of the Brexit vote â€œmay lead to the conditions in which the UK could be reintegrated into a reformed EUâ€.

â€œBritain has enjoyed a special status throughout our time as a member of the EU and, should we choose to, we could do so once again. It would be a logical continuation of what we have previously achieved on so many occasions,â€ he said.

â€œCrucially, this task â€“ of reuniting the UK with the EU, but on an altered and reformed basis â€“ will be made all the more possible because the rest of the EU is beginning to redesign its entire structure itself.

â€œThe Brexit vote was a major catalyst in pushing EU governments to accept that change can no longer be avoided.â€

Clegg adds: â€œYet just at the point that Brexit appears to make us more of an island than ever, it could paradoxically lead to changes in the EU that will offer us a way back in.â€

FREDERICK FLORIN via Getty Images Nick Clegg says Remain voters should learn from Nigel Farage

In his book, the former Lib Dem leader argues voters who want to see the UK return to the EU should learn from Tory eurosceptics who spent years battling against the odds to achieve what had long seemed impossible.

â€œThe battalion of greying Conservative MPs you have never heard of; the shady financiers of the Brexit elite; the loopy rantings of Paul Dacre; those obscure campaign groups and the obsessive scribblers of angry letters â€” all these people fought relentlessly for Brexit, over many years, long before the term â€˜Brexitâ€™ had even been invented,â€ he said.

â€œThey were often subject to ridicule and frequently occupied the outer fringes of mainstream politics, but if they hadnâ€™t endlessly chipped away, then the political avalanche of the referendum would never have happened. At times it must have seemed as if nobody was listening. At times nobody was listening. In the end, however, they got their way.â€
TITLE: Nigel Farage Should Be A Role Model For Remain Voters Who Want To Rejoin The EU, Says Nick Clegg
