SUMMARY:
The tropical storm was named a hurricane overnight and the US National Hurricane Centre has warned it could strengthen over the coming days.
The remnants of the hurricane is expected to reach the UK on Monday, coinciding with the 30th anniversary of the Great Storm.
#Ophelia has become the 10th consecutive Atlantic tropical storm to attain hurricane strength this season.
It will coincide with the 30th anniversary of the Great Storm of 1987, which hit southern England overnight on October 15.
â€œAfter that, indications are that by that point it will then have weakened and be no longer a hurricane or tropical storm, it will be extratropical.
TEXT:
Gusts of up to 70mph and wet weather could batter Britainâ€™s shores as Hurricane Ophelia crosses the Atlantic Ocean in the coming days, despite other parts of the country basking in the heatwave approaching from Spain this weekend.

The tropical storm was named a hurricane overnight and the US National Hurricane Centre has warned it could strengthen over the coming days.

The remnants of the hurricane is expected to reach the UK on Monday, coinciding with the 30th anniversary of the Great Storm.

The Met Office has warned that the unsettled weather could cause disruption.

#Ophelia has become the 10th consecutive Atlantic tropical storm to attain hurricane strength this season. Moving slowly SW of the Azores. pic.twitter.com/QcrDDwP0Uu â€” Met Office Storms (@metofficestorms) October 11, 2017

The west of the country will see the worst of the weather, with winds of between 60mph and 70mph forecast.

Ophelia is the tenth consecutive Atlantic tropical story to attain hurricane strength this season, the Met Office said.

It will coincide with the 30th anniversary of the Great Storm of 1987, which hit southern England overnight on October 15. The storm caused damage estimated at Â£1 billion and claimed 18 lives.

The Met Office said that the Great Storm of October 15 and 16, 1987, was a â€œwake-up callâ€ for weather service providers and helped to identify gaps in severe weather forecasting capability.

#30yearsago people were woken by the #greatstorm, How would we forecast and communicate about a similar weather event today? pic.twitter.com/SjS4CRVpwr â€” Met Office (@metoffice) October 11, 2017

Met Office forecaster Alex Burkhill said: â€œOphelia became a hurricane overnight and the forecast track takes it eastwards towards Iberia for the weekend.

â€œAfter that, indications are that by that point it will then have weakened and be no longer a hurricane or tropical storm, it will be extratropical.

â€œBut then it will continue its way towards the British Isles, probably reaching us very early next week.â€

Burkhill said cold sea temperatures mean Ophelia will not be strong enough to be categorised as a hurricane when it hits Britain.

But he added: â€œItâ€™s definitely something that we are keeping an eye on, for the possibility of some disruptive weather early next week.â€

The unsettled weather looks likely to continue into Tuesday due to a separate band of low pressure, and will remain changeable throughout the rest of the week.

Despite the weather warnings for next week, some parts of the UK are set to experience a rise in temperatures this weekend, with some areas in the south east of the country experiencing 24C (75F).

The balmy weather is thanks to scorching temperatures in the Mediterranean.
TITLE: Hurricane Ophelia's Tail Due To Hit UK On Anniversary Of The Great Storm

grandriver via Getty Images

Ã€ un peu plus de deux semaines de l'Ã©chÃ©ance prÃ©vue par la loi spÃ©ciale qui avait mis fin Ã  la grÃ¨ve dans l'industrie de la construction, les nÃ©gociations viennent d'avorter dans le secteur rÃ©sidentiel, a appris La Presse canadienne.

AprÃ¨s des pourparlers avec l'Alliance syndicale tenus jusqu'en soirÃ©e mercredi, la partie patronale qui nÃ©gocie pour ce secteur, l'Association des professionnels de la construction et de l'habitation du QuÃ©bec (APCHQ), a claquÃ© la porte, a-t-elle confirmÃ© jeudi matin.

Au cours d'une entrevue, le vice-prÃ©sident DÃ©veloppement stratÃ©gique et communications de l'APCHQ, FranÃ§ois-William Simard, a reprochÃ© Ã  l'Alliance syndicale d'avoir reniÃ© sa parole, parce qu'elle aurait refusÃ© de signer une entente qui avait Ã©tÃ© convenue entre les parties Ã  la fin de la journÃ©e.

Â«Mercredi, on a nÃ©gociÃ© toute la journÃ©e. Il y a plusieurs contre-offres qui ont Ã©tÃ© faites de part et d'autre. Ce qui est le plus intÃ©ressant, c'est qu'on a acceptÃ© la derniÃ¨re contre-offre de la partie syndicaleÂ», a affirmÃ© M. Simard.

Â«On dit que le ridicule ne tue pas, et bien heureusement, parce que c'est invraisemblable ce qui s'est passÃ©: ils ont refusÃ© de signer une entente de principe sur leur propre offreÂ», en affirmant qu'ils voulaient consulter ensuite leur fiscaliste pour bien Ã©valuer leur offre, a relatÃ© M. Simard.

Estimant qu'elle perdait alors son temps, l'APCHQ s'est retirÃ©e de la table de nÃ©gociation et elle a demandÃ© au gouvernement de mettre fin Ã  la mÃ©diation qui avait Ã©tÃ© entreprise dans son secteur.

Â«On a le sentiment malheureusement qu'on nous a fait perdre notre temps. Il n'y a aucune volontÃ© de rÃ©gler finalementÂ», a laissÃ© tomber le porte-parole patronal.

La loi spÃ©ciale qui avait Ã©tÃ© adoptÃ©e pour mettre fin Ã  la grÃ¨ve, le 30 mai dernier, donne aux parties jusqu'au 30 octobre pour s'entendre, Ã  dÃ©faut de quoi les questions non rÃ©solues seront soumises Ã  l'arbitrage.

Dans le secteur rÃ©sidentiel, c'est donc la question salariale qui sera soumise Ã  l'arbitrage, puisque les autres clauses avaient fait l'objet d'une entente, a indiquÃ© M. Simard.

Le temps presse donc pour l'ensemble de l'industrie, en vue de renouveler les conventions collectives qui concernent quelque 165 000 ouvriers dans l'ensemble du QuÃ©bec.

Une entente de principe complÃ¨te Ã©tait tout de mÃªme intervenue, Ã  la fin de septembre, dans le secteur du gÃ©nie civil et voirie, entre l'Alliance syndicale et l'Association des constructeurs de routes et grands travaux.

En plus du rÃ©sidentiel, deux autres secteurs de l'industrie n'ont pas encore rÃ©glÃ©, Ã  savoir l'industriel, de mÃªme que le commercial-institutionnel. Les conventions collectives dans ces deux secteurs sont nÃ©gociÃ©es entre l'Alliance syndicale et l'Association de la construction du QuÃ©bec.

L'APCHQ compte 17 000 membres entrepreneurs.

Quant Ã  l'Alliance syndicale, elle regroupe les cinq organisations syndicales de l'industrie, Ã  savoir la FTQ-Construction, le Conseil provincial du QuÃ©bec des mÃ©tiers de la construction (International), le Syndicat quÃ©bÃ©cois de la construction, la CSD-Construction et la CSN-Construction.
TITLE: Les nÃ©gociations avortent dans la construction rÃ©sidentielle au QuÃ©bec

SUMMARY:
A devoted One Direction fan found herself in hospital with a collapsed lung after screaming at one of the bandâ€™s concerts.
Following x-rays the doctors diagnosed the girl with pneumothorax, which is the term given when air builds up between the outside of your lung and the inside of your ribcage.
This is also known as a collapsed lung.
Finally, doctors identified rogue air in a third place, near the back of the throat, and diagnosed her with pneumoretropharyngeum.
In some more extreme cases, patients may need lung surgery.â€100 Pictures Of One Direction
TEXT:
A devoted One Direction fan found herself in hospital with a collapsed lung after screaming at one of the bandâ€™s concerts.

The unnamed 16-year-old, who has since recovered, went to hospital in Texas when she felt short of breath the next day.

A series of tests lead doctors to diagnose her with three separate conditions, which they believed could be linked to her overzealous cheering.

Her story recently appeared as a case study in the Journal of Emergency Medicine.

EMPICS Entertainment

The doctors noted that while the girl was breathing quickly, her breathing sounded normal.

However, they noticed signs of crepitus - a cracking or clicking sensation that occurs under the skin - when they pressed down around her neck and chest.

Speaking to Live Science, report author Dr J. Mack Slaughter Jr. described the sensation as â€œfeeling Rice Krispiesâ€.

Following x-rays the doctors diagnosed the girl with pneumothorax, which is the term given when air builds up between the outside of your lung and the inside of your ribcage. This is also known as a collapsed lung.

After further examination she was also diagnosed with pneumomediastinum, which is when abnormal gas or air is contained within the mediastinum (the space in the chest between the lung sacs).

Finally, doctors identified rogue air in a third place, near the back of the throat, and diagnosed her with pneumoretropharyngeum.

The team said there was no evidence to suggest an underlying lung condition caused the three problems and noted that shouting could have prompted the damage, although this was impossible to conclude for certain.

â€œSpontaneous pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum, and pneumoretropharyngeum are uncommon diagnoses individually, and furthermore, the combination of all three diagnoses has yet to be described in medical literature,â€ they said in the report.

Commenting on the case study, GP Dr Clare Morrison, from online doctor service MedExpress, said itâ€™s important to remember the girlâ€™s experience is extremely rare.

â€œI cannot think of another time when lungs have collapsed due to screaming at a pop concert - but thereâ€™s a first time for everything,â€ she told HuffPost UK.

â€œSo itâ€™s important not to panic and for parents to get too judicious.â€

She said smokers and recreational drug users have a higher chance of a pneumothorax - or lung collapse - than the general popualation.

â€œAlso, if youâ€™re suffering from a condition like asthma or pneumonia, your chances increase,â€ she added.

She pointed out that symptoms of a collapsed lung include:

Chest tightness

Tiredness

Rapid heart rate

Nasal flaring

Blue-coloured skin

â€œA small pneumothorax will likely go away on its own - you could only need oxygen treatment and rest,â€ Dr Morrison added.

â€œOften a needle will be used to pull the air out from around the lung so it can expand fully. If the pneumothorax is large, a chest tube will be placed between the ribs into the space around the lungs to help with draining the air and allow the lung to re-expand.

â€œIn such an instance, you could need to stay in hospital. In some more extreme cases, patients may need lung surgery.â€

100 Pictures Of One Direction
TITLE: One Direction Fan Diagnosed With Collapsed Lung After Overzealous Screaming At Concert

SUMMARY:
Soon, you won't need me to nourish you in a way only I can do.
Today, tomorrow and every day, as long as I live, I will love you and cherish you.
When you were born, it grew: it grew, and it grew, and it grew!
In the words of the subtly ingenious Robert Munsch, "As long as I'm living my baby you'll be."
Happy Birthday, baby girl!
TEXT:
To my littlest love, on your first birthday:

Tomorrow you turn one and my heart feels as though it could explode. In all honesty, I have dreaded this day. This year has flown by, each month faster than the last, each day a blur. I tried to stop, or at least stall time repeatedly. Tomorrow is a milestone for us both, and one that I celebrate for you, but mourn for me. Tomorrow you will be considered a toddler, and my baby days are over. You are my last baby.

You have grown so much this year despite my best efforts to slow you down. I begged you to stay little, but you grew anyway. I pleaded with you to stay curled up on my chest, as you rolled off. I longed for you to stay still, as you crawled away and played with your toys instead. I was convinced I was all you'd ever need, but you found comfort and entertainment in your siblings, your daddy, the nanny... and #allthesnacks.

Tomorrow, you are one. But, here I sit, in the shadow of your bedroom window nursing you to sleep. I stare at your cheek, the outline of your ear, your fine wisps of hair, your eyelashes. My heart aches knowing these days are numbered. "I will breastfeed until they are one," I said about each of my babies. Tomorrow, you are one. I am officially abandoning that idea â€” I am not ready; and neither are you. We have made up the rules as we go, changing them along the way! You have given me grace, sweet baby. You have done everything slower than your brother and sister, and for that I am endlessly grateful.

Tomorrow, you are one. Soon, you won't need me to cuddle you to sleep. Soon, you won't need me to comfort you in the night. Soon, you won't need me to nourish you in a way only I can do. Soon, you will walk, and you will run. Baby girl, soon, you will fly! You will chase after your brother and sister, and then your dreams. Soon, you will be your own person, doing your own things. I will be your biggest cheerleader, your endless supporter.

Tomorrow, you are one. Today, tomorrow and every day, as long as I live, I will love you and cherish you. You have added so much love and joy to our family. I never knew something was missing, until you filled the space. I never knew I had so much love to share until you and your brother and sister taught me the infinite ability of my heart to grow. When you were born, it grew: it grew, and it grew, and it grew! So today, filled with love to the point of explosion, I know it has the ability to grow a little more.

Tomorrow, you are one.

Tomorrow. You. Are. One. I still can't believe it.

But today, you are not yet one. Today, you are still my baby.

In the words of the subtly ingenious Robert Munsch, "As long as I'm living my baby you'll be."

Happy Birthday, baby girl!

Love always,

Mom.

Follow HuffPost Canada Blogs on Facebook

Also on HuffPost:
TITLE: To My Last Baby, On Your 1st Birthday

KnÃ¶pfe oder NÃ¤hte, kleine StÃ¶ÃŸe. Dinge, die uns im Alltag begleiten und passieren kÃ¶nnen, stellen fÃ¼r Alinas Haut eine enorme Gefahr da. Eine unbedachte Bewegung, ein Moment der Unachtsamkeit â€“ und schon reiÃŸt ihre Haut auf. â€Unser Leben ist ein einziges Aufpassenâ€œ, sagt Alinas Mutter, Michaela Schierholz. Michaela Schierholz vertraut nicht nur Maggy, sie sieht auch, wie das Reiten ihre Tochter verÃ¤ndert hat. Alinas Gleichgewichtssinn hat sich deutlich verbessert. Sondern generell. â€Maggy ist einfach tollâ€œ, sagt Alina. Das zarte MÃ¤dchen und das massige Kaltblut. Ein Bild voller GegensÃ¤tze â€“ und voller Liebe.

Sie alle vereint, dass sie ein Leben leben, das sich zu einem groÃŸen Teil in Arztpraxen, KrankenhÃ¤usern und bei Physiotherapeuten abspielt. Einen Moment der Freiheit, in dem sie den Augenblick genieÃŸen â€“ und ihre Krankheiten keine Rolle spielen.

Auch Reitlehrerin Petra MÃ¤chold sieht, dass sich Alina in den vergangenen anderthalb Jahren verÃ¤ndert hat. â€Ihre ganze KÃ¶rperhaltung war zusammengekauert. Sie hatte permanent Angst, sich zu stoÃŸen.â€œ Wer heute sehe, wie selbstbewusst und gerade Alina auf dem Pferd sitzt, kÃ¶nne sich kaum vorstellen, dass sie einmal anders gewesen ist. Was Alina beim Reiten am meisten SpaÃŸ macht? â€Galoppieren natÃ¼rlich! Da fÃ¼hl ich mich so herrlich frei.â€œ

Das einzige Manko: Hippotherapien werden nicht von Krankenkassen Ã¼bernommen. Weil laut Bundesministerium fÃ¼r Gesundheit â€ein therapeutischer Nutzen der Hippotherapie nicht nachgewiesen ist und die Therapie daher als nicht verordnungsfÃ¤higes Heilmittel zu fÃ¼hren istâ€œ. Das heiÃŸt: Betroffene, die diesen Weg der Therapie gehen wollen, mÃ¼ssen ihn aus eigener Tasche bezahlen oder versuchen, ihn Ã¼ber Spenden zu finanzieren.

Gutes tun und die Gesellschaft stÃ¤rken

Die Deutsche Fernsehlotterie hat den Aufbau des heilpÃ¤dagogischen Reitens in Frohnau mit rund 93.000 Euro gefÃ¶rdert. Auf du-bist-ein-gewinn.de stellt die Soziallotterie dieses und viele weitere tolle Projekte vor, die zeigen, wie sich Menschen fÃ¼r HilfsbedÃ¼rftige einsetzen und so unsere Gesellschaft stÃ¤rken. SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTDirected by Raja Krishna Menon, who previously directed the Akshay Kumar blockbusterAirlift, Chef, is a film about Roshan Kalra, an Indian chef, working abroad.
Although Chef is a modern slice-of-life film it offers much more.
For example, we are told how a young Roshan had run away from his house with the dream of becoming a cook and struggled to survive until he finally fulfilled his dream.
Chef is a cute little film about life, and what it takes to follow one's dreams.
Saif Ali Khan shines in this flawed film marred by occasional pacing issues.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

Directed by Raja Krishna Menon, who previously directed the Akshay Kumar blockbusterAirlift, Chef, is a film about Roshan Kalra, an Indian chef, working abroad. Roshan gets fired for assaulting a White man who had complained about the quality of food served. The chef who has a son back in India travels to Kochi to spend some time with him and learns that his ex-wife, a professional dancer, is dating a rich landlord. What ensues is a journey of self-realization for Roshan as he tries to start afresh while desperately trying to mend his old relationships. With a cast that also includes Padmapriya Janakiraman, Sobhita Dhulipala, Svar Kamble, Milind Soman, and Chandan Roy Sanyal, Chef is a remake of a 2014 American film of the same name, directed by Jon Favreau.

Although Chef is a modern slice-of-life film it offers much more. Without relying heavily on flashbacks, the movie succeeds in presenting us with the back stories of the key characters. For example, we are told how a young Roshan had run away from his house with the dream of becoming a cook and struggled to survive until he finally fulfilled his dream. This is achieved quite effectively through voiceovers, dialogues, and without any flashbacks. It is precisely what a film likeJab Harry Met Sejallacked. Today, Bollywood films are breaking free of the conventions while experimenting with more unconventional narrative tropes.

Chef is a cute little film about life, and what it takes to follow one's dreams. Saif Ali Khan shines in this flawed film marred by occasional pacing issues. The acting is solid all around. Chef features some memorable performances from the likes of Padmapriya Janakiraman, Svar Kamble, and Milind Soman. The film features a cameo from a promising young actor named Abhishek Kumar who is quite active on the Delhi theatre circuit, certainly one to look out for. Perhaps, the only weakling in the acting department is actress Sobhita Dhulipala who fails to match the intensity she exuded inRaman Raghav 2.0. The screenplay is rather weak but the direction and cinematography more or less make up for what the film lacks in the writing department. Chef is not your run-of-the-mill commercial entertainer but it is certainly a film that has enough to keep one engaged for the most part.

A version of this review was first published in A Potpourri of Vestiges.

The opinions expressed in this post are the personal views of the author. They do not necessarily reflect the views of HuffPost India. Any omissions or errors are the author's and HuffPost India does not assume any liability or responsibility for them.
TITLE: 'Chef': Saif Ali Khan Adds Spice And Zest To A Slice-Of-Life Film

Truss: â€œWell, Iâ€™d encourage people to visit the job centre, go in and get the advice.â€

Neil: â€œRight, but these people have got kids to look after, they canâ€™t afford nannies or help to look after them. Phoning might be the only way. Theyâ€™ve got people visiting, the plumber, whatever, just the normal things of life, so getting on the phone is quite important.

â€œIf itâ€™s a landline, it is cheaper but many people donâ€™t have landlines. If youâ€™re counting the pennies, you save the rental from a landline, and get as cheap as possible a landline deal. And you are charging them 55p a minute! Why are you doing it?

Truss: (Pause) ... â€œThis is what Iâ€™m saying. We are moving to a new way of supporting people. It is much more interventionist, much more about helping people get into work...â€

Nobody else is paying 6% interest these days when the basic rate is 0.5%, and now you are charging people on welfare 55p a minute!â€

TEXT:
Die Brexit-Verhandlungen zwischen der EU und GroÃŸbritannien kommen nicht voran

EU-UnterhÃ¤ndler Barnier beklagt eine "Blockade" der GesprÃ¤che durch die Briten

Der angestrebte Zeitplan gerÃ¤t in Gefahr

Die Brexit-Verhandlungen haben ihr erstes Etappenziel klar verfehlt. Es gebe nicht genug Fortschritt, um die wichtige zweite Phase der GesprÃ¤che zu starten, stellte EU-UnterhÃ¤ndler Michel Barnier am Donnerstag fest.

Die britische Premierministerin Theresa May habe zwar versprochen, finanzielle Zusagen einzuhalten, sagte Barnier. In der fÃ¼nften Verhandlungsrunde sei dies seit Montag aber nicht konkret unterfÃ¼ttert worden. "In dieser Frage stecken wir in einer Blockade", kritisierte der EU-Vertreter.

Brexit-Minister Davis stellte klar, dass GroÃŸbritannien die finanziellen Zusagen erst im Zusammenhang mit den kÃ¼nftigen Beziehungen verhandeln wolle. In diesem Punkt sind sich beide Seiten also noch nicht einmal Ã¼ber die Abfolge einig.

Rechte der EU-BÃ¼rger in GroÃŸbritannien

Brexit-Minister David Davis. Quelle: dpa

DarÃ¼ber hinaus ging es auch in dieser Runde um die kÃ¼nftigen Rechte der rund 3,2 Millionen EU-BÃ¼rger in GroÃŸbritannien und der 1,2 Millionen Briten in der Ã¼brigen EU. Hier stellten beide Seiten Fortschritte fest, aber auch noch viele Unstimmigkeiten.

Das gleiche gilt nach Darstellung von Davis und Barnier bei der Frage, wie die kÃ¼nftige EU-Grenze zwischen Irland und dem britischen Nordirland durchlÃ¤ssig gestaltet werden kann.

Davis machte deutlich, dass er die von der EU gewÃ¼nschte Aufteilung in zwei Phasen nicht mehr akzeptiert. Der EU-Gipfel solle nÃ¤chste Woche beschlieÃŸen, Barniers Verhandlungsmandat auszuweiten, sagte er. Dass dies geschieht, gilt als sehr unwahrscheinlich.

Die 27 bleibenden EU-LÃ¤nder geben sich bisher nach auÃŸen sehr einig. Sie sehen die Abfolge vor allem als Hebel, die Finanzforderungen durchzusetzen. Andernfalls wÃ¼rden sofort MilliardenlÃ¶cher im noch bis 2020 laufenden EU-Finanzrahmen klaffen.

"Kein Deal wÃ¤re ein sehr schlechter Deal"

Die zweite Phase der Verhandlungen dÃ¼rfte dann aber noch komplizierter werden - deshalb will man sich dafÃ¼r auch mehr Zeit nehmen. Dabei geht es um die von GroÃŸbritannien gewÃ¼nschte "tiefe und besondere Partnerschaft" - also vor allem ein Handelsabkommen, aber auch die Zusammenarbeit in Sicherheits- und anderen Fragen.

DarÃ¼ber hinaus soll Ã¼ber eine Ãœbergangszeit gesprochen werden, um den Bruch fÃ¼r die Wirtschaft, aber auch fÃ¼r BÃ¼rger und BehÃ¶rden sanfter zu gestalten.

Bis Oktober 2018 soll eigentlich alles in einem umfassenden Austrittsabkommen geregelt sein, das rechtzeitig vor dem Brexit Ende MÃ¤rz 2019 ratifiziert und in Kraft gesetzt werden soll. Gelingt der Ãœbergang in Phase zwei nicht bald, wird dieser Zeitplan zunehmend unrealistisch. Die britische Premierministerin Theresa May vertritt Ã¶ffentlich die Ansicht, kein Abkommen sei besser als ein schlechtes.

Die EU verweist hingegen auf mÃ¶gliche chaotische Folgen - von langen Staus an den Grenzen bis zu hohen EinfuhrzÃ¶llen auf beiden Seiten. "Kein Deal wÃ¤re ein sehr schlechter Deal", sagte ihr UnterhÃ¤ndler Barnier.
TITLE: EU beklagt "Blockade" bei Brexit-Verhandlungen - der Zeitplan gerÃ¤t in Gefahr

TEXT:
POLITIQUE - Et si c'Ã©tait Ã§a le symbole de gauche que recherche la majoritÃ©? Supprimer les allocations familiales pour les plus riches afin de les redistribuer aux plus modestes.

Depuis que son gouvernement a confirmÃ© la suppression de l'ISF, Emmanuel Macron a dÃ©sormais l'Ã©tiquette "prÃ©sident des riches" qui lui est collÃ©e dans le dos. Ses troupes cherchent donc le moyen de gauchiser l'image et certains imaginent que le budget de la SÃ©curitÃ© sociale (PLFSS) est le bon prÃ©texte pour rÃ©Ã©quilibrer celle donnÃ©e par le projet de loi de finances.

L'idÃ©e est simple: continuer Ã  donner 32,87 euros par mois Ã  un foyer qui gagne environ 8000 euros par mois (65 euros quand on gagne environ 6000 euros) n'a aucun sens alors que cette somme reprÃ©sente beaucoup pour une personne au Smic. "C'est une bonne question", a convenu Edouard Philippe ce mercredi 11 octobre au soir lors de l'Ã©change qu'il fait chaque semaine avec des internautes sur Facebook.

Olivier VÃ©ran met les pieds dans le plat

C'est Olivier Veran, ex-dÃ©putÃ© PS et rapporteur spÃ©cial de la commission des affaires sociales qui a lancÃ© le dÃ©bat en premier. Il veut poursuivre le travail engagÃ© par FranÃ§ois Hollande et Marisol Touraine qui ont diminuÃ© le montant versÃ© aux familles les plus riches, soulevant alors de grandes interrogations et une levÃ©e de bouclier, essentiellement Ã  droite. Dans Le Figaro, fin septembre, le dÃ©putÃ© de l'IsÃ¨re a affirmÃ© vouloir supprimer les allocs pour ceux qui touchent plus de 6000 euros par mois pour les redistribuer aux familles modestes, en particulier pour les familles monoparentales.

Il ajoutait aussitÃ´t qu'il n'est cependant pas question de mettre ce sujet en dÃ©bat dans le PLFSS mais se dit favorable Ã  une rÃ©flexion sur le sujet.

Seulement, selon les informations du HuffPost, la suppression de cette universalitÃ© Ã©tait bien prÃ©vue dans la premiÃ¨re mouture du PLFSS prÃ©parÃ©e durant l'Ã©tÃ© par Bercy. Une option rejetÃ©e par Emmanuel Macron qui ne veut pas se lancer dans un tel chantier au dÃ©tour d'un dÃ©bat budgÃ©taire. C'est ce qu'il a rappelÃ© lundi 9 octobre lors d'une rÃ©union Ã  l'ElysÃ©e avec les membres En Marche de la commission des Affaires sociales. Et qu'Edouard Philippe a rÃ©pÃ©tÃ© ce mercredi soir. "On va se poser cette question, mais aprÃ¨s un vrai bon dÃ©bat, et pas simplement le soir au dÃ©tour d'un amendement budgÃ©taire qui n'aurait pas Ã©tÃ© complÃ¨tement mesurÃ© dans ses implications", a confirmÃ© le premier ministre.

"Pas autant un symbole de gauche que cela"

"Nous sommes ouverts au dÃ©bat, c'est pourquoi j'ai initiÃ© une mission sur la refonte plus globale de la politique de la famille et pas seulement le versement des allocations familiales", prÃ©cise Brigitte Bourguignon, la prÃ©sidente de la Commission des Affaires sociales. La crÃ©ation de cette mission qui rÃ©flÃ©chira par exemple Ã  la question du quotient familial a Ã©tÃ© officialisÃ©e il y a quelques jours.

Mais pourquoi donc, une telle hostilitÃ© alors mÃªme qu'Emmanuel Macron n'est pas opposÃ© par principe Ã  la suppression des allocations familiales pour les plus riches et que Bruno Le Maire a fait part de son ouverture sur le sujet?

"Ce n'est pas autant un symbole de gauche que cela, rÃ©pond un bon connaisseur du dossier. A la gauche de la gauche, on y est opposÃ© car revenir sur l'universalitÃ© des allocs, c'est revenir sur le consensus de 1945 qui a prÃ©valu Ã  la crÃ©ation de la SÃ©curitÃ© sociale et qui fait que tout le monde a droit aux allocations, en partie pour encourager Ã  la natalitÃ©".

Ne pas toucher Ã  l'universalitÃ© des allocations est en effet la position que dÃ©fendait par exemple Pierre Laurent, le patron du PCF lors du dÃ©bat initiÃ© par le gouvernement prÃ©cÃ©dent. Ce mercredi encore c'est SÃ©golÃ¨ne Royal qui faisait par de son hostilitÃ© alors mÃªme qu'elle appartenait au gouvernement qui a ouvert la brÃ¨che.

Un amendement prÃ©sentÃ© par des "kamikazes"?

Lancer le dÃ©bat dÃ¨s maintenant, ce serait courir le risque d'ouvrir un front des mÃ©contentements Ã  droite, oÃ¹ la fronde conservatrice promet d'Ãªtre importante, mais aussi Ã  gauche ce qui rÃ©duirait considÃ©rablement l'effet recherchÃ©.

Pourtant, malgrÃ© les mises en garde des deux tÃªtes de l'exÃ©cutif, Le HuffPost a appris que plusieurs parlementaires de La RÃ©publique en marche ne comptent pas suivre Ã  la lettre la consigne prÃ©sidentielle. Un amendement devrait bien Ãªtre dÃ©posÃ© par une poignÃ©e de dÃ©putÃ©s qui veulent aborder la question dÃ¨s cet automne. "Ce sont des kamikazes, dÃ©plorent-on en haut lieu. Je pense que nous arriverons Ã  ramener certains Ã  la raison mais il y a tellement de brÃ¨ches que Ã§a parait impossible de toutes les colmater."

En clair, le dÃ©bat que le gouvernement espÃ©rait reporter de quelques mois pourrait bien avoir lieu dans les prochains jours.

Ã€ voir Ã©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: La fin des allocations familiales pour les plus riches, la bombe que le gouvernement veut retarder

POLITIQUE - Emmanuel Macron a annoncÃ© mercredi 11 octobre qu'il lÃ©gifÃ©rerait par ordonnances pour rÃ©Ã©quilibrer les contrats commerciaux entre agriculteurs et distributeurs, Ã  condition qu'ils rÃ©organisent leurs filiÃ¨res de production, dans un discours trÃ¨s attendu visant Ã  augmenter le revenu des paysans en crise. "Nous modifierons la loi pour inverser la formation du prix qui partira du coÃ»t de production" a dÃ©clarÃ© le chef de l'Etat Ã  mi-parcours des Etats gÃ©nÃ©raux de l'alimentation, Ã  Rungis.

L'ambition du prÃ©sident est de trouver les moyens de mettre un terme Ã  la paupÃ©risation de la profession agricole, tout en rÃ©pondant Ã  la forte nÃ©cessitÃ© de transformation du secteur pour rÃ©pondre aux attentes sociÃ©tales et environnementales des FranÃ§ais. "Nous devons repenser collectivement une nouvelle France agricole" a-t-il lancÃ© aux agriculteurs, industriels, distributeurs et Ã©lus rÃ©unis sur le marchÃ© de gros de Rungis.

La loi devrait Ãªtre prÃ©sentÃ©e et adoptÃ©e via des ordonnances "au premier semestre 2018" a dit le prÃ©sident de la RÃ©publique, en souhaitant une "transformation profonde" du secteur, et en exigeant que chaque filiÃ¨re de production agricole (lait, viande, cÃ©rÃ©ales, etc..) lui prÃ©sente "d'ici la fin de l'annÃ©e" sa "stratÃ©gie".

"Nous ne devons pas avoir une approche uniforme", il continuera d'y avoir une "pluralitÃ© productive", et des "dynamiques rÃ©gionales" qui doivent rester fortes, a-t-il ajoutÃ© en citant le bio, les labels, les rÃ©gions, et notamment les "territoires ultramarins", qui seront "accompagnÃ©s" dans cette transformation. "Je souhaite que la distribution et les industriels participent" Ã  ce travail, a-t-il prÃ©cisÃ©.

"ArrÃªt" de certaines productions

Sur le plan technique, la dÃ©cision de relever le seuil de revente Ã  perte (SRP) de la grande distribution, trÃ¨s attendue par les agriculteurs, dÃ©pendra du bouclage des stratÃ©gies de chaque filiÃ¨re. Le seuil de revente Ã  perte est le prix minimum en dessous duquel les distributeurs n'ont pas le droit de vendre.

Le prÃ©sident a rÃ©affirmÃ© son engagement de campagne d'atteindre "50% de produits bio ou locaux d'ici 2022 en restauration collective", un objectif qui va permettre de modeler, selon lui, les schÃ©mas de production en France et relancer l'agriculture et l'agroalimentaire. "Vous devez vous organiser dans les territoires pour changer les modÃ¨les productifs", a-t-il dit.

Ce changement de paradigme passe par un "arrÃªt" de certaines productions, qui ne correspondent plus au goÃ»t des consommateurs et ne s'inscrivent pas dans la concurrence internationale. Emmanuel Macron s'est engagÃ© Ã  clarifier le droit Ã  la concurrence, les agriculteurs Ã©tant tÃ©tanisÃ©s par le risque d'Ãªtre accusÃ©s d'entente commerciale comme c'est arrivÃ© par exemple pour "le cartel des endives".

Il a aussi cherchÃ© Ã  rassurer les Ã©leveurs et producteurs de viande bovine, inquiets des nÃ©gociations commerciales en cours avec les pays du Mercosur en AmÃ©rique Latine, en indiquant que selon lui cette nÃ©gociation ne pouvait pas aboutir sur la base d'un mandat donnÃ© en 1999.

Ã€ l'adresse des associations de consommateurs, il s'est engagÃ© Ã  ce que le Ceta, l'accord de libre Ã©change conclu entre l'UE et le Canada et entrÃ© provisoirement en application le 21 septembre, respecte les normes europÃ©ennes de santÃ© et d'environnement.

Sur l'herbicide glyphosate, il s'est engagÃ© Ã  ne pas laisser les agriculteurs "sans solution", mais a rÃ©affirmÃ© l'objectif de "transformer le modÃ¨le agricole dans lequel nous nous sommes enferrÃ©s" et qui "n'est pas durable".

ADVERTISEMENTGANDHINAGAR -- The Gujarat High Court on Monday commuted the death sentence to 11 convicts, in connection with the 2002 Godhra train burning case, into life imprisonment.
On 1 March, 2011, the special SIT (Special Investigation Team) had convicted 31 people under the Indian Penal Code (IPC) sections related to murder, attempt to murder and criminal conspiracy.
Around 58 people lost their lives when the S-6 coach of Sabarmati Express was torched at the Godhra Railway Station on 27 February, 2002.

TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

GANDHINAGAR -- The Gujarat High Court on Monday commuted the death sentence to 11 convicts, in connection with the 2002 Godhra train burning case, into life imprisonment.

On 1 March, 2011, the special SIT (Special Investigation Team) had convicted 31 people under the Indian Penal Code (IPC) sections related to murder, attempt to murder and criminal conspiracy. It had acquitted 63.

Out of these 31, 11 people were sentenced to death. 20 were sentenced to life imprisonment.

Those acquitted included the prime accused, Maulana Umarji, the then president of Godhra Municipality, Mohammad Hussain Kalota, Mohammad Ansari and Nanumiya Chaudhary of Gangapur, Uttar Pradesh.

Around 58 people lost their lives when the S-6 coach of Sabarmati Express was torched at the Godhra Railway Station on 27 February, 2002. The incident had triggered large-scale riots in Gujarat in which around, reportedly, 1,000 people were killed.

The Nanavati Commission appointed by the Gujarat Government into the Godhra incident had concluded that the fire in the S-6 coach of the Sabarmati Express was not an accident and that it was set ablaze.

The Gujarat High Court completed hearings on the case in 2015.

Last week, the Gujarat High Court gave the then Chief Minister Narendra Modi and 60 others a clean chit in the case, citing lack of "prosecutable evidence" against them.

Also on HuffPost India:
TITLE: Godhra Train Burning Case: Gujarat HC Commutes Death Sentence Of 11 Convicts Into Life Imprisonment

Samir Hussein via Getty Images Kate Winslet and Idris Elba pose in the winners room at the EE British Academy Film Awards at The Royal Opera House on Feb. 14, 2016, in London, England.

SUMMARY:
Many Australians have fond memories of drinking slushies after school on a sweltering afternoon.
Well, picture that but with an adult twist -- wine slushies made with fruit.
These simple, colourful boozy slushies are easy to make and are the perfect answer to a hot, sunny day.
To make wine slushies all you need is wine (duh), frozen fruit and a blender or food processor.
You can even use a variety of frozen fruits and create layered rainbow wine slushies -- try strawberry for red, oranges for orange, mango for yellow, kiwi for green, blueberries for blue, and blackberries for purple.
TEXT:
Many Australians have fond memories of drinking slushies after school on a sweltering afternoon. Well, picture that but with an adult twist -- wine slushies made with fruit.

These simple, colourful boozy slushies are easy to make and are the perfect answer to a hot, sunny day.

To make wine slushies all you need is wine (duh), frozen fruit and a blender or food processor. Simply whizz it all up and serve in a glass or jar. You can even use a variety of frozen fruits and create layered rainbow wine slushies -- try strawberry for red, oranges for orange, mango for yellow, kiwi for green, blueberries for blue, and blackberries for purple.

White wine and rosÃ© work best for these slushes, but play around with wines with different fruit aromas or even spirits if it's that time of day.

Check out the video above and below for more summer spiked slushie recipes.

TEXT:
Education in emergencies continues to be neglected globally, despite world leaders pledging there would be â€˜No Lost Generationâ€™ of children as a result of the Syrian crisis.

As part of Theirworldâ€™s #YouPromised campaign, the charity provided video cameras to four Syrian refugee children who have not been to school since the start of the war, to document their daily lives over six months and highlight why urgent action is needed.

Asmah was married at just 12-years-old, to her 30-year-old neighbour. She is now 15. She suffers from post traumatic stress disorder from her time in Syria. Since fleeing the war-torn country, she has resettled in Turkey with her husband and two small children.

This is her story.
TITLE: Syrian Child Bride Documents Her Life As A New Mother

SUMMARY:
Itâ€™s been more than fifty years since the landmark Loving v. Virginia case invalidated laws banning interracial marriage in the U.S.
These days, interracial relationships are incredibly common.
According to Pew research, about 17 percent of new marriages and 20 percent of cohabiting relationships are interracial or interethnic.
The numbers of interracial unions may be rising, but couples in the relationships still encounter a lot of questions â€• and some of them are straight-up rude.
Below, interracial couples share 10 questions and misconceptions theyâ€™re sick of hearing.
TEXT:
Itâ€™s been more than fifty years since the landmark Loving v. Virginia case invalidated laws banning interracial marriage in the U.S.

These days, interracial relationships are incredibly common. According to Pew research, about 17 percent of new marriages and 20 percent of cohabiting relationships are interracial or interethnic. And about one-quarter of Americans have a close relative in an interracial marriage.

The numbers of interracial unions may be rising, but couples in the relationships still encounter a lot of questions â€• and some of them are straight-up rude. Below, interracial couples share 10 questions and misconceptions theyâ€™re sick of hearing.

1. â€œYou donâ€™t date within your own race?â€

â€œI get asked this question frequently from other members of my community and it frustrates me. Yes, I have dated black men and Iâ€™ve dated other minorities as well. I donâ€™t have a preference when it comes to the color of my partnerâ€™s skin; I looked more for compatibility and personality when I was single â€• something I wish other people would take the time to learn. All that matters at the end of the day is that you and your partner see eye-to-eye on most of the important issues in this life. I know race can affect peopleâ€™s opinions on those topics, but for us â€• and probably for others in most interracial relationships â€• it never becomes a big problem.â€ â€• Vladimir Sabajo, who lives in New York City and runs the YouTube channel VladixDean with his partner Dean Carter

Vladimir Sabajo Dean and Vladimir

2. â€œIs your home life different because of your differences?â€

â€œWeâ€™re not your average heteronormative couple, but we still interact with each other in almost the same manner. We have shared interests, we share cleaning responsibilities around the house, and we even have the occasional disagreement just like any two people living in close quarters. The fact that we are both men and are both from different racial backgrounds does not affect our daily life as much as most people assume. For instance, we both hold steady jobs but many people assume that because Iâ€™m white and feminine, that Vladimir takes care of me financially. Itâ€™s a mindset that is rooted in both misogyny and racism: Itâ€™s based on the idea that black skin equates to hypermasculinity and that white skin equates to fragility. This kind of thinking dehumanizes both parties and creates unnecessary stereotypes that can be damaging to relationships.â€ â€• Dean Carter

3. â€œWow, you look so exotic.â€

â€œDo you really need to double take every time we hold hands? We donâ€™t feel like we look that shocking, and weâ€™re certainly not interesting enough to be gawked at in public. The stunned staring is really unnecessary, and honestly pretty disturbing when youâ€™re on the receiving end of it. Weâ€™re not on display, weâ€™re just a couple.â€ â€• Ariana Offray, who lives in Los Angeles, California and runs the YouTube channel Ariana Raw with her partner Hannah Glover

Ariana Offray Ariana and Hannah

4. â€œAre the cultural differences a problem?â€

â€œCultural differences arenâ€™t a negative thing. Weâ€™ve found that theyâ€™ve made our relationship stronger and helped us grow as individuals. They havenâ€™t torn us apart.â€ â€• Bethany Struble, who lives in Los Angeles California with her partner Peter Adrian Sudarso and runs the YouTube channel Bethany Struble Vlogs

Peter Adrian Sudarso Peter and Bethany

5. â€œWhat do you have in common?â€

â€œWeâ€™re of different races but one of the main reasons we get on so well as a couple is because of how similar we are. We have similar values, mindsets and interests. If anything, being in an interracial relationship actually shows you how likeminded you are to someone of a different race.â€ â€• Kimmy Kimani, who lives in the U.K. and runs the YouTube channel James and Kimmy with her partner James Alexander Hobbs

Kimmy Kimani James and Kimmy

6. â€œDo you want kids who look like you?â€

â€œPeople (even within our own families sometimes) ask us if we will adopt babies that â€˜looks like us.â€² Thing is, we are already an â€˜unconventionalâ€™ family and we are aware that our family will look different anyway. Hence we do not care for the ethnicity of our children. They will be loved and welcomed like any other child would be in any other family.â€ â€• David Levesque, who lives in Toronto, Canada and runs the YouTube channel HueDavid with his husband Huey Tran

Photo courtesy of David Levesque David and Huey

7. â€œAre you going to have babies? Mixed babies always look cute.â€

â€œYes, our kids will be cute if we so chose to have them but thatâ€™s because all babies are cute. Our baby being â€˜mixedâ€™ doesnâ€™t make them any cuter than someone elseâ€™s child.â€ â€• Harsh Patel, who lives in New Jersey and runs the YouTube channel Harsh and Des with his partner DesTynee Covington

Harsh Patel Harsh and Des

8. â€œYouâ€™re married to a white man. Does he make more money than you? â€

â€œFirst off, thanks for assuming that I would marry a man based off his income. Second, do you think a man of another race is not capable of making a lot of money? Third, do you think white men are so undesirable that the only way Iâ€™d be interested was if they were wealthy? This is by far the worst question Iâ€™ve been asked about being in an interracial marriage because itâ€™s loaded with not only one but many insults. I married this man because I love him...end of story.â€ â€• Jackie Iadonisi, who lives in Los Angeles with her husband Nick Iadonisi and runs the YouTube channel Jackieâ€™s Adventures

Jackie Iadonisi Jackie and Nick

9. â€œDonâ€™t you deal with so much prejudice?â€

â€œYes, we live in a globalized world now, but not everyone is open to the idea that two different worlds could come together in the name of love. This is hard, but we donâ€™t take it personally when other family members need a moment to digest our relationship. Weâ€™ve learned that some might be overly joyed and fascinated by an interracial couple, while others might take longer to accept or have their prejudices dissolved.â€ â€• Henrik Stenberg, who lives in Sweden and runs the YouTube channel Henrik and Rachel with his partner Rachel Otieno

Henrik Stenberg Henrik and Rachel

10. â€œIsnâ€™t it so hard dealing with different backgrounds?â€

â€œAt the end of the day, our differences are not a big a deal. We are in a relationship, just like everyone else. Itâ€™s really no different. In some ways, itâ€™s harder and in some ways, easier, but thatâ€™s mostly because of who we are as people, not necessarily what backgrounds we come from. The same way you may not like being stared at and questioned about your lifestyle (or personal life), neither do we. We do understand that we stand out visually, but at the same time, realize we are people doing people stuff...just like you. It might not be that exciting or exotic to hear but really, itâ€™s the truth.â€ â€• Wendy Joseph, who lives in New Jersey with her partner Daniel Hennessey and runs the YouTube Channel Wendyâ€™s Curls
TITLE: 10 Things Interracial Couples Wish You'd Stop Asking Them

SUMMARY:
Justice Bell sums up the mood as regards to Malcolm Roberts' legal argument: "What are we getting out of this?"
The QC for the anti-immigration party argued to the High Court's full bench, there should not be a distinction between Australian born citizens and Australian immigrants or foreign born Australians, that being born overseas was almost irrelevant.
Malcolm Roberts is arguing that it's un-Australian to uphold Australia's Constitution - "but, it's the vibe, it's Mabo"!
Justice Virginia Bell asked, "is it your submission that Senator Roberts is a natural born Australian?
High Court #citizenship7, Day 3.
TEXT:
CANBERRA -- One Nation senator Malcolm Roberts has argued the anti-immigration dual citizenship case against him and his possible breach of the Constitution is "un-Australian" as he tested the patience of the High Court in stating he was "entitled to put out of his mind that he was a British citizen".

In what does not bode well for the senator in this citizen by descent case, the Justices have been repeatedly questioning relevance, "where this argument is taking us?", "what are we getting out of this?" and "can you bring us up to date?"

Justice Bell sums up the mood as regards to Malcolm Roberts' legal argument: "What are we getting out of this?" #Citizenship7 â€” Adam Gartrell (@adamgartrell) October 12, 2017

Now remember, the High Court has previously found, under cross examination, Roberts -- who was born in India in 1955 to a Welsh father and an Australian mother -- was a dual-British citizen when he nominated and was elected in 2016.

This is already a technical breach of Section 44 of the Constitution, but the full bench of the High Court is still to rule on the case of Roberts as well as the six other federal politicians; Barnaby Joyce, Matt Canavan, Fiona Nash, Nick Xenophon, Larissa Waters and Scott Ludlam.

Roberts is attending the High Court on Thursday and his legal representative, Robert Newlinds QC, quickly argued that the previous cross-examination of the senator had "misfired" and there has been "nonsense arguments" and then, essentially described the potential for kicking him out of parliament for being an Australian immigrant as "un-Australian".

The QC for the anti-immigration party argued to the High Court's full bench, there should not be a distinction between Australian born citizens and Australian immigrants or foreign born Australians, that being born overseas was almost irrelevant.

Malcolm Roberts is arguing that it's un-Australian to uphold Australia's Constitution - "but, it's the vibe, it's Mabo"! #Citizenship7 pic.twitter.com/I00Df0F8Ue â€” Tony Lomas (@TonyLomas) October 12, 2017

Anything else for Newlinds was "a fundamentally un-Australian notion".

What was he? Well it was put that it does not matter that he was born in India, in fact, it was a "dangerous distraction".

"We are here because he father is welsh, No one is suggesting he was an India".

Justice Virginia Bell asked, "is it your submission that Senator Roberts is a natural born Australian? Newlinds flung his hands in the air and responded, "he is a natural born Indian, whatever that means".

The Commonwealth argues politicians born overseas should have been aware there was a risk they were dual citizens.

But Roberts lawyer then claimed that the UK was not a foreign power, or at least has only been one since 1986, but this change in view had happened without "flag-waving and clarion calls." His assertion was that Roberts was a British subject, but also Australian.

Newlinds says the UK didn't become a foreign power until 1986, suggested in previous High Court cases #Citizenship7 â€” Matthew Doran (@MattDoran91) October 12, 2017

The key here, for Roberts and his team, was that Roberts father came to Australia in 1962 as a British citizen and became an Australian solely by "setting up a domicile".

That, it is argued how things were done back in the day for British subjects.

The other back in the day argument was that body politic - or general Australian population - in the 1970s did not view Britain a "foreign power", so Roberts was "entitled to put of his mind that he was a British citizen."

The senator, Newlinds said, always thought he was an Australian and in 1994 his dad came home with a citizenship certificate and he "did not think it was a big deal" and he did not get any extra rights or duties.

Newlinds saying the moment Roberts got a citizenship certificate, he didn't gain any extra rights or duties #Citizenship7 â€” Matthew Doran (@MattDoran91) October 12, 2017

The argument exasperated the justices who urged a hurry on during the third and final day of hearings into the dual citizenship statuses.

How does this take us to 2016, when Roberts nominated for parliament while knowing he was a dual citizen?

Justice Bell wanted to know.

"Putting to inside what people may or may not have thought, we are to determine this on the facts that have been found. It is just unclear to me where this argument is taking us?" she asked.

Roberts put that It would be different Roberts had stood for nomination in 1987, but, Justice Bell, said in exasperation, "we are dealing with a nomination in 2016?"

High Court #citizenship7, Day 3. Malcolm Roberts' counsel rebuts "nonsense" arguments; & bench gives Xenophon hope https://t.co/rkI8VR5HCW â€” Katie Walsh (@katiepwalsh) October 12, 2017

It was tendered he knew prior to 1974 that he was a British citizen, but Newlinds said Roberts did not know in 2016 he was British citizen, but he had the "wit to think he might be".

"His state of mind was embedded and set in 1974 and it doesn't change," nNewlinds told the court.

It is then, he argued, that Roberts took "reasonable steps" to renounce citizenship. It just happened to be after he nominated and had tried email accounts that were non-existent.

The Justices want to get to 2016. At one point, it was put "we are in 1898, we have a long way to (get to 2016)."

The Chief Justice Susan Kiefel stated in frustration, "I don't understand the relevance to the case," "what are we getting out of this?" and "can you bring us up to date?"

Newlinds is trying to mix Roberts's "state of mind" or the view he is "entitled to" with a recounting of history, we will find out if he has managed to take the Justices there.
TITLE: It Is 'Un-Australian'! The Testing High Court Testimony Of Malcolm Roberts

SUMMARY:
But what about the things that people might feel less comfortable disclosing on those first few dates, such as the state of their mental health or any underlying conditions they may be dealing with in private.
Because with an estimated 1 in 6 people in the UK experiencing a common mental health problem every week, according to The Mental Health Foundation, this is a conversation that lots of people need to be having.
How soon should you discuss your mental health?
â€œYou could start by discussing your relationship with your own mental health, how youâ€™ve learned to live with the condition and what makes you feel better,â€ says Bloomfield.
Dr Bhagat says: â€œUltimately, only you are responsible for your behaviour and for managing your mental health.
TEXT:
For anyone starting out in a new relationship, there are bound to be lots of things you donâ€™t know about your partner - their favourite hobbies, the foods they hate, and any unsavoury bathroom habits (yes, we know).

But what about the things that people might feel less comfortable disclosing on those first few dates, such as the state of their mental health or any underlying conditions they may be dealing with in private.

Because with an estimated 1 in 6 people in the UK experiencing a common mental health problem every week, according to The Mental Health Foundation, this is a conversation that lots of people need to be having.

But at what point should you start sharing? And what reaction can you expect?

kupicoo via Getty Images

Dr Anshumen Bhagat, GP and founder of the doctor-on-demand app GPDQ, says: â€œHealthy relationships are built on trust and honesty. If a relationship is getting serious, it would be important to continue deepening that trust by sharing who you really are with your partner, including mental health.â€

So we asked three experts, and two people who have been through the experience themselves, to answer the questions you need answering.

How soon should you discuss your mental health?

It might seem too personal to share on the first date, or even the second, but once you are more comfortable and committed to each other is probably the right time. â€œBring it up when the relationship starts to feel important to you,â€ says Relate counsellor, Barbara Bloomfield.

A spokesperson from Anxiety UK agreed that there is no deadline but it is about when you feel comfortable: â€œSome may feel ready to talk straight away, for others it may take weeks or even months.â€

Shea Wong, who has bipolar disorder, and is a supporter of â€˜Time To Changeâ€™ tells HuffPost UK: â€œEach relationship is different, so donâ€™t feel as though your medical disclosures have to occur on a certain time frame. I chose to approach it from an emotional standpoint - my feelings were strong enough and I was considering a future with someone - then is a good time to begin discussing your mental health issues, especially if they are chronic.â€

How should you bring up the conversation?

Dr Bhagat recommends that before you dive right in (or get drunk and decide to launch into an emotional rant), why not write down the things you want to share so you are prepared?

â€œAlways remember, those who havenâ€™t ever struggled with mental health issues wonâ€™t understand it fully, so it may take a while to explain.â€

Once you have your ideas together, find a time when youâ€™re not going to be interrupted and are in private, so you can be candid and explain fully.

How should you phrase that conversation?

â€œYou could start by discussing your relationship with your own mental health, how youâ€™ve learned to live with the condition and what makes you feel better,â€ says Bloomfield.

If you want to angle the conversation so you can gauge their reaction before putting all your cards on the table, then she suggests asking: â€œDo you know many people with mental health problems?â€

When you bring it up, speak with confidence and without shame.

Portra via Getty Images

How much should you be sharing with them?

Once youâ€™ve started sharing, you might find it difficult to know when to stop.

Wong, explains that based on her own experience, you should be thinking of yourself as an educator teaching a student.

â€œYou donâ€™t want to overwhelm them, but at the same time you donâ€™t want to be so stingy with details that they fill in the blanks with their own pre-conceived ideas,â€ she says.

â€œGive a general overview of the illness: What it does to the brain, how it generally affects you, how you handle it, and then encourage them to ask questions as they are ready to take on more info. Always leave them understanding that there are no bad questions, and you are here to help them understand.â€

What do you want to achieve by telling your partner?

One thing you might want to consider before telling your partner, is what you want their response to be, and how you hope this might help you or change the way you deal with your illness or relationship.

Gina Hadden, 33, who has OCD, says that telling her partner Sam helped her to gain knowledge and educate herself about getting the right help.

â€œHe encouraged me to be open about my illness so now I bring awareness to it and write about it publicly.â€

But one thing you must be aware of, is making sure you arenâ€™t looking for your partner to solve your problem. Dr Bhagat says: â€œUltimately, only you are responsible for your behaviour and for managing your mental health. Itâ€™s completely okay to ask your new partner for support, but donâ€™t make them feel responsible, as this could add pressure and strain to the relationship. The best thing to ask for is their patience and understanding, as you work out how to deal with it together.â€

How do you deal with your partnerâ€™s reaction?

Everyone hopes that the person will be accepting straight away, but thatâ€™s not always realistic. Some people may have prejudices and may not be willing to give you a chance, others may need a little time to comprehend what youâ€™ve told them.

Dr Bhagat said: â€œTry not to expect a certain reaction, but just be prepared for lots of questions and do your best to help them understand.

â€œIf the reaction isnâ€™t what you hoped for, donâ€™t blame yourself, and most importantly, donâ€™t let that put you off telling other prospective partners.â€

Useful websites and helplines:

Mind , open Monday to Friday, 9am-6pm on 0300 123 3393

, open Monday to Friday, 9am-6pm on Samaritans offers a listening service which is open 24 hours a day, on 116 123 (UK and ROI - this number is FREE to call and will not appear on your phone bill.)

offers a listening service which is open 24 hours a day, on (UK and ROI - this number is FREE to call and will not appear on your phone bill.) Get Connected is a free advice service for people under 25. Call 0808 808 4994 or email: help@getconnected.org.uk
TITLE: This Is How To Talk About Your Mental Health In A New Relationship

SUMMARY:
Education in emergencies continues to be neglected globally, despite world leaders pledging there would be â€˜No Lost Generationâ€™ of children as a result of the Syrian crisis.
As part of Theirworldâ€™s #YouPromised campaign, the charity provided video cameras to four Syrian refugee children who have not been to school since the start of the war, to document their daily lives over six months and highlight why urgent action is needed.
Asmah was married at just 12-years-old, to her 30-year-old neighbour.
She suffers from post traumatic stress disorder from her time in Syria.
Since fleeing the war-torn country, she has resettled in Turkey with her husband and two small children.
TEXT:
Education in emergencies continues to be neglected globally, despite world leaders pledging there would be â€˜No Lost Generationâ€™ of children as a result of the Syrian crisis.

As part of Theirworldâ€™s #YouPromised campaign, the charity provided video cameras to four Syrian refugee children who have not been to school since the start of the war, to document their daily lives over six months and highlight why urgent action is needed.

Asmah was married at just 12-years-old, to her 30-year-old neighbour. She is now 15. She suffers from post traumatic stress disorder from her time in Syria. Since fleeing the war-torn country, she has resettled in Turkey with her husband and two small children.

This is her story.
TITLE: Syrian Child Bride Documents Her Life As A New Mother

SUMMARY:
On World Mental Health Day, We Must Commit To Fair Funding For Mental Health Care Mental health is on the TV.
Labour MP for Bootle and Shadow Chief Sec to the TreasuryOnly Labour Can Deliver The Transport Investment Britain Needs The Conservatives are refusing to say precisely where the Â£400 million of transport investment will be spent.
Labour MP for Blaenau Gwent and party whipDisability Activists Challenging Labour Disabled people are making sure their voices and viewpoints are heard.
Conservative Justice Secretary David Lidington had an opportunity to show that he was getting a grip during his keynote speech at Conservative Party conference.
Labour MP for Hemsworth and Shadow Minister for the CabinetCorbyn's Labour Party Will Deliver A Fairer, More Compassionate Britain Jeremy Corbyn has made the Labour party more democratic - now he needs to take the next step to make the country's electoral system more representative of the nation's views.
TEXT:
On World Mental Health Day, We Must Commit To Fair Funding For Mental Health Care Mental health is on the TV. On the radio. In the tabloids, in the broadsheets, in the magazines. Online. Mental health is on everyone's lips; Prime Ministers and future kings. Mental health is what everyone seems to be talking about. It's time to talk. It's good to talk. That really is something to celebrate. We are all talking about mental health - and yet ... and yet the talk is increasingly of crisis. We must ring-fence mental health spending to close the gap between the rhetoric of parity and the reality of cuts on the front-line. We must keep talking. But if we want to see real equality for mental health now is the time for action. Labour and Co-operative MP for Liverpool Wavertree, President of Labourâ€™s Campaign for Mental Health

No Hope For Young People From Hapless Hammond The reality is that young people in this country have felt the brunt of seven years of Tory austerity. Rising house prices, slow economic growth, and a lack of stable employment have entrenched huge economic inequality between the younger and older generations. Under the Conservatives, the levels of debt young people find themselves in has risen dramatically. The decision to triple tuition fees and end grants for students attending university now means that young people are leaving university with on average Â£40,000 worth of debt. Labour MP for Bootle and Shadow Chief Sec to the Treasury

Only Labour Can Deliver The Transport Investment Britain Needs The Conservatives are refusing to say precisely where the Â£400 million of transport investment will be spent. Why make an announcement without a plan? The reason is that this is a government without a plan, and merely shows how out of the touch the Tories are with the needs and ambitions of the North. Shadow transport secretary and Labour MP for Middlesborough

7,000 Words And Not A Single Mention Of Wales After this conference season, it's becoming increasingly clear that Theresa May is content with providing "second best" solutions to the issues which face communities across Wales and the UK as a whole. Member of Parliament for Ogmore

Tory Conference Diary, Day 4: May's Disaster Of A Speech Proved The Tories Have No Plan As Tory Conference comes to a close many of the papers and broadcast channels have obviously focused in on the mishaps which plagued Theresa May's speech. But aside from the cough and the falling backdrop, the true disaster of the speech lies in the fact that we had final confirmation that the Tories really do have no plan. Labour MP for Hemsworth and Shadow Minister for the Cabinet

Southern Rail Dispute And Uber Debacle Shows Labour Will Fight For The Unions, Not You The strikes on Tuesday and Thursday by the RMT Union have caused yet more indignation for so many of my constituents in East Surrey who commute into London for work and all the other passengers reliant on the service. What makes it all the more galling for the passengers is the persistent support the unions receive from Jeremy Corbyn. Rather than condemning the union bosses for playing games, the Labour leader has made it abundantly clear he stands with the union barons. Prisons and probation minister and Conservative MP for East Surrey

Tory Conference Diary, Day 3: Do They Have Even A Semblance Of A Plan For Britain? With one day left, it's down to Theresa May to put forward her vision for the future and prove she has a semblance of a plan. If the last three days are anything to go by, I think the Tory faithful are going to be leaving Manchester very disappointed. Labour MP for Hemsworth and Shadow Minister for the Cabinet

Amazon's Tax Crackdown Is The First Step To Fairness This one-off payment means hundreds of millions more for public services and taxpayers across the continent. Schools, hospitals, front line services and infrastructure all benefiting from the success of these big companies. Surely that's how it should always work, and a state of affairs worth striving for? Labour MP for Blaenau Gwent and party whip

Disability Activists Challenging Labour Disabled people are making sure their voices and viewpoints are heard. There is no excuse for lack of accessibility and a failure to consult. Disabled people must advise on conference planning. I am involved in both groups, we are working together. Our activism and solidarity will enable us to succeed. Disability Blogger Activist & Information Guru. Wheelchair user passionate about equality inclusion & education. Lover of books & cats.

Help To Buy Will Help To Bury Home Ownership, And The Tories' Hopes For A Political Resurgence With It Tackling the housing crisis will take time, reform won't deliver immediate benefits and will need longer than one parliamentary term to make a real difference. Yet instead of offering the bold reform needed the Conservatives have gone for the easy option. But Help to Buy is not the answer, instead it will help to bury the next generation's aspirations for home ownership and the Tories' hopes for a political resurgence with it. Senior Research Fellow at IPPR, specialising in housing and infrastructure

The Conservatives Have Run Out Of Ideas Of How To Repair Our Broken Justice System Crisis after crisis rocked the justice system this summer. Conservative Justice Secretary David Lidington had an opportunity to show that he was getting a grip during his keynote speech at Conservative Party conference. Sadly for the millions who depend on a properly functioning justice system, he fluffed his chance. Labour MP for East Leeds, Shadow Justice Secretary

The Road To Hell Is Paved With Good Intentions On the face of it, Universal Credit is a good idea. The benefits system is ridiculously complex, simplifying it is common sense. Except people are not simple, they don't fit into boxes. My sister-in-law and my brother could not have more different needs, experiences and circumstances. The idea that one (fairly inflexible) thing could simply suit them both is a system designed by someone who has not met a very broad range of people. If the variation in my immediate family is so wide, imagine how many iterations are possible. Labour MP for Birmingham Yardley

Tory Conference Diary, Day 2: More Evidence That The Government Have Run Out Of Ideas Party Conferences are traditionally an opportunity for each side to have their moment in the sun. The Party presents their new policy ideas and sets out their vision on how they can take the country forward and tackle the great challenges ahead. Measured against this, it was clear the Tories had another bad day. Labour MP for Hemsworth and Shadow Minister for the Cabinet

Corbyn's Labour Party Will Deliver A Fairer, More Compassionate Britain Jeremy Corbyn has made the Labour party more democratic - now he needs to take the next step to make the country's electoral system more representative of the nation's views. Our first past the post electoral system is not fit for purpose and its time we moved to some form of proportional representation. Blogger who abhors injustice

Tory Conference Diary, Day 1: A Party With No Plan And No Vision For The Country The Tory Conference started yesterday after weeks of internal wrangling and backbiting. And for those Tory MPs and members who thought that they might have a gentler, more unified lead up to their conference, they were sadly disappointed. Labour MP for Hemsworth and Shadow Minister for the Cabinet

Â¿Alguien se imagina que en vez de que el Rey Juan Carlos pusiera en posiciÃ³n de firmes y a la orden a los Capitanes Generales y altos mandos de las FAS y el gobierno se subsecretarios, presidido por Francisco LaÃ­na, mandara entrar en el Congreso a liberar a los diputados secuestrados el 23-F el Estado hubiera negociado con Tejero una reforma de la ConstituciÃ³n para asemejarla al Fuero franquista?

La democracia es algo mÃ¡s prosaico y reglado: consiste en que se respeten las normas que caen en cascada, desde la ConstituciÃ³n hasta las leyes de la circulaciÃ³n.

Hay que acudir a los maestros de la ciencia polÃ­tica, por ejemplo, a los consejos de Maquiavelo: "El que tolera el desorden para evitar la guerra (o la revoluciÃ³n, apunto yo), tiene primero el desorden y despuÃ©s la guerra (o la revoluciÃ³n, insisto)".

Ante la hÃ¡bil campaÃ±a de intoxicaciÃ³n y propaganda de los nuevos golpistas, apoyados por el habitual pirateo informÃ¡tico ruso de la era digital, procede dejar clara una cosa principal: Es falso que el voto sea la Ãºnica exigencia democrÃ¡tica, la palomita de la paz constituyente. El espÃ­ritu santo democrÃ¡tico. Y que cualquier salida para atajar la rebeldÃ­a tiene que pasar por un consenso con los rebeldes para cambiar a su gusto las reglas del juego. DecÃ­a De Gaulle que lo importante en polÃ­tica es sentar un precedente. Y si en la polÃ­tica espaÃ±ola se sienta este precedente, el paÃ­s serÃ­a absolutamente ingobernable e imprevisible. Los actuales niveles de excentricidad se convertirÃ­an en simple subnormalidad. SegÃºn Paracelso, "el veneno es la dosis", y aumentar el porcentaje de estupidez mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de los lÃ­mites del postureo esnobista nos llevarÃ­a al caos irremediable. Pedro SÃ¡nchez deberÃ­a reflexionar sobre ello.

La democracia es algo mÃ¡s prosaico y reglado: consiste en que se respeten las normas que caen en cascada, desde la ConstituciÃ³n hasta las leyes de la circulaciÃ³n.

Llegados al punto de la insurrecciÃ³n, el Estado actÃºa siempre de la misma forma: advirtiendo primero, y empleando despuÃ©s la fuerza que el Gobierno de la naciÃ³n estÃ¡ legitimado para utilizar, de manera proporcional a la amenaza. Nunca la fuerza puede ser inferior al riesgo, porque en ese caso, el riesgo crece en proporciÃ³n directa, corregida al alza, a la incapacidad de disuasiÃ³n y neutralizaciÃ³n de la amenaza. Y ante una declaraciÃ³n unilateral de independencia por parte de los golpistas, sea a plazos o en diferido, que nadie se rasgue las vestiduras: es jurÃ­dicamente inevitable la detenciÃ³n de los cabecillas y sus colaboradores. Y, ver los tanques en la calle si la situaciÃ³n lo requiriera.

Â¿DÃ³nde estÃ¡ el cinismo insufrible de Pablo Manuel Iglesias y los suyos? En que actÃºan igual que los curas que le dicen a los feligreses que someten a controversia su comportamiento, "no hagas lo que yo hago, sino lo que yo digo".

Gracias a YouTube y al invento mÃ¡gico de los 'smartphones' no se ha podido ocultar por los conspiradores la realidad de las provocaciones, los insultos, la desobediencia, las agresiones tumultuarias de la masa convertida en populacho a los agentes de la Autoridad, el desacato abierto y desvergonzado a los tribunales, las leyes tomadas a pitorreo callejero, las amenazas y agresiones a policÃ­as y guardias civiles, los piquetes que empezaron a dividir en dos a la ciudadanÃ­a catalana, creando las condiciones objetivas para una guerra civil 'blanda'....

Ahora el desafÃ­o es imponer la Ley y el orden y revisar lo que se ha hecho mal para hacerlo bien, empezando por el principio: ajustar las tuercas del sistema autonÃ³mico.

Â¡Hay que dialogar!, claman aÃºn, pese a las evidencias, las almas puras y bondadosas. La policÃ­a, en todos los paÃ­ses, no estÃ¡ para dialogar. No es esa su funciÃ³n, sino la de los polÃ­ticos. El diÃ¡logo tiene sus cauces, que al agotarse abren la puerta a la disuasiÃ³n, primero, y a la represiÃ³n, despuÃ©s. El operativo del Estado cumpliÃ³ todos los trÃ¡mites: el presidente del Gobierno â€“con independencia del anÃ¡lisis sobre la gestiÃ³n de la crisis, que se remonta a hace mÃ¡s de una dÃ©cada- advirtiÃ³ repetidamente de que el Estado actuarÃ­a en defensa de la unidad de EspaÃ±a y de la ConstituciÃ³n y del Estatuto de AutonomÃ­a de CataluÃ±a, con todos los medios a su alcance. Si no le creyeron ese es el problema de los incrÃ©dulos, o los hipÃ³critas; lo mismo advirtiÃ³ el Tribunal Constitucional y la FiscalÃ­a General; luego, el gobierno enviÃ³ cuatro mil agentes antidisturbios de refuerzo, a bordo de dos buques de crucero utilizados como 'casas cuartel' flotantes. Los heridos o contusionados por las porras lo fueron porque se encontraban en franca rebeldÃ­a haciendo frente a las fuerzas de la ley y el orden.

No hay duda a estas alturas del enredo de que la progresiÃ³n de la desestabilizaciÃ³n era la estrategia diseÃ±ada por los 'autores intelectuales' de la subversiÃ³n, que consumaron el primer acto de la enÃ©sima parte del golpe en el preciso momento en que el Parlament aprobÃ³ las leyes que derogaban de facto la ConstituciÃ³n y el Estatuto, y encajonaron la democracia entre parÃ©ntesis.

Todos los paÃ­ses europeos han tenido, en algÃºn momento, que recurrir a la porra, a la formaciÃ³n policial cerrada, inventada por las legiones romanas, para defender el orden constitucional y la seguridad de todos sus ciudadanos. Lo tuvieron que hacer en la Europa crispada por las tÃ¡cticas desestabilizadoras y expansionistas de MoscÃº en la 'guerra frÃ­a. El Kremlin moviÃ³ como peleles a los bondadosos y altruistas pacifistas durante la 'crisis de los misiles' desatada por... la URSS al romper el 'statu quo'. Aquellas algaradas â€“ como las de Mayo del 68 en ParÃ­s- fueron reprimidas segÃºn mÃ©todos estrictamente profesionales, que, lÃ³gicamente, ocasionaron mÃ¡s lesiones y tropezones que el mÃ©todo bondadoso de isopos con agua bendita. La disoluciÃ³n de grupos neonazis en Alemania, siempre acaba con contusionados. Lo mismo que las protestas por los recortes en Atenas sin que Podemos, o los restos de IU, pidiera beato espÃ­ritu misionero. Cada reuniÃ³n del G-20 es una nueva ocasiÃ³n de comprobar cÃ³mo actÃºan las unidades especiales de la policÃ­a de los diferentes paÃ­ses sedes hasta conseguir el control absoluto de la situaciÃ³n. AhÃ­ tiene RufiÃ¡n un buen Ã¡lbum de fotos para ilustrarse, aunque lo que "natura non dat, Salamanca non prestat".

La verdad es que la porra al servicio de la democracia ha contribuido decisivamente a proteger las libertades de las sociedades europeas. El problema es que todo tiene que hacerse en su momento, y sin complejos. Y aquÃ­ se ha dejado pasar irresponsablemente el tiempo. Ahora el desafÃ­o es imponer la Ley y el orden y revisar lo que se ha hecho mal para hacerlo bien, empezando por el principio: ajustar las tuercas del sistema autonÃ³mico para que la descentralizaciÃ³n no desemboque en reinos de taifa y en anarquÃ­a. Porque la subversiÃ³n comenzÃ³, como un calabobos, cuando por simples cuentas de equilibrio electoral se tolerÃ³ el primer chantaje nacionalista y cuando se mirÃ³ para otro lado mientras se sembraba el odio y la mentira.

Ahora, a ajustar el Sistema, con 'seny'.

SÃ­guenos tambiÃ©n en el Facebook de HuffPost Blog
TITLE: La â€˜porraâ€™ llegÃ³ tarde: el delito lo es desde el primer plazo

India's Foreign Minister Sushma Swaraj at a press briefing on the launch of the Russian Department of the Indian Government's Invest India Investment Promotion and Facilitation Agency.

TEXT:
India's Foreign Minister Sushma Swaraj at a press briefing on the launch of the Russian Department of the Indian Government's Invest India Investment Promotion and Facilitation Agency.

ADVERTISEMENT

External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj has made a name for herself by coming to the help of Indians trapped in difficult situations in a foreign country, and foreigners with a similar plight in India. People have taken to tweeting at her, knowing that there's a good chance she will spot their appeal and direct her ministry to take action.

The latest beneficiary of this is a 24-year-old Russian who was forced to beg outside a temple in Kanchipuram, Tami Nadu, due to an unfortunate banking incident. According to a report in The Hindu, A. Evangelin has been travelling through India since 24 September. On Tuesday, 10 October, he arrived in Kanchipuram in Chennai. When he tried withdrawing some money from an ATM, somehow, his card got blocked, leaving Evangelin with no money to fend for himself.

Left with no option, Evangelin decided to join the beggars outside a temple so he could raise some money. The incident was reported to the local police, who promptly arrived at the temple to investigate.

On seeing his travel documents and a valid visa, a sub-inspector gave him Rs 500 to help him go back to Chennai and contact the Russian Consulate for help, reported India Today. On learning of Evangelin's plight through the papers, Swaraj quickly tweeted, "Evangelin - Your country Russia is our time-tested friend. My officials in Chennai will provide you all help."

Evangelin - Your country Russia is our time tested friend. My officials in Chennai will provide you all help. https://t.co/6bPv7MFomI â€” Sushma Swaraj (@SushmaSwaraj) October 10, 2017

However, yesterday, on 11 October, a Russian Consulate official told PTI that Evangelin had not contacted them, nor had he answered their calls to his mobile phone when they tried to contact him. If he gets in touch, "We will assist him in a proper way," PTI quoted Yury S Belov, Vice-Consul (press and public relations) of the Russian Consulate as saying.

In another incident, yesterday, Swaraj directed the Indian Embassy in Riyadh to reach out to an Indian woman who claims to be in danger in Saudi Arabia at the earliest after a video of her begging for help from Bhagwant Mann, the Aam Aadmi Party's MP from Sangrur district in Punjab, started circulating online.

In the video, the woman cries uncontrollably as she details her torture at the hands of her employers for the past one year. She claims that she has been living in Dawadmi, located about 200km from the capital city of Riyadh, as a slave and is ill-treated and fears for her life. She also alleges that when she managed to escape and went to the police for help, they too beat her up and took her back to her employers. She pleads with Mann to rescue her, the way he had helped other Indians trapped in a similar situation.

Earlier this year, in June, Mann had, with the ministry of external affairs, helped rescue and bring back 20 Indian youths stuck in Saudi Arabia in deplorable conditions after receiving an SOS video from them on Facebook.

Mann is aware of the woman's call for help â€” he retweeted an Aaj Tak news report about the video â€” but as of now, there has been no statement on the matter from him.
TITLE: Sushma Swaraj Comes To The Aid Of Russian Man Spotted Begging Outside Kanchipuram Temple
