SUMMARY:
Dr. Anne Davis, consulting medical director at Physicians for Reproductive Health, told HuffPost on Wednesday that medical professionals purposefully donâ€™t take a stance on the topic.
Itâ€™s a concept people maybe come to from a religious frame of mind, but it isnâ€™t medical,â€ Davis told HuffPost.
It doesnâ€™t happen then.â€Itâ€™s a concept people maybe come to from a religious frame of mind, but it isnâ€™t medical.
TrueLife, LifeMatters and National Right to Life all post countless articles â€œconfirmingâ€ that life begins at conception.
Including this language in the strategic plan, Davis said, â€œis setting the stage for turning things back, coming up with these justifications for refusing to coverâ€ reproductive health care.
TEXT:
The Department of Health and Human Services released its strategic plan for 2018 to 2022 last month. As Jezebel reported Tuesday, the introduction now includes: â€œHHS accomplishes its mission through programs and initiatives that cover a wide spectrum of activities, serving and protecting Americans at every stage of life, beginning at conception.â€ The concept of â€œlife at conceptionâ€ is mentioned four more times in the 65-page report.

This idea has long been used by the anti-abortion community as justification for its protests, constant attempts to pass anti-abortion legislation (like the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, which the House passed last week, that would ban abortions after 20 weeks) and remains a pillar of the religious far-rightâ€™s agenda.

But there is no medical determination that â€œlifeâ€ starts at conception.

Dr. Anne Davis, consulting medical director at Physicians for Reproductive Health, told HuffPost on Wednesday that medical professionals purposefully donâ€™t take a stance on the topic.

â€œThereâ€™s a reason that we donâ€™t provide a definition of when life begins because there isnâ€™t such a definition in medicine,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s not a medical concept.â€

Davis elaborated that there is a huge misunderstanding of how â€œconceptionâ€ (actually, fertilization) even works.

â€œThe confusion here is that people think that the moment of fertilization is when pregnancy starts. They conflate those two things as one â€¦ which isnâ€™t true,â€ she said. â€œFertilizations occur many more times than pregnancies occur, because they often donâ€™t wind up in pregnancies. Fertilization happens in the [fallopian] tube. Pregnancy happens in the uterus.â€

Basically, the anti-abortion community stakes the entire basis of its belief system on medically unsound facts.

â€œItâ€™s not a medical concept. Itâ€™s a concept people maybe come to from a religious frame of mind, but it isnâ€™t medical,â€ Davis told HuffPost. â€œPeople think there is a magic moment when they have sex, that thereâ€™s ejaculation, fertilization and pregnancy happening in seconds. It doesnâ€™t happen then.â€

Itâ€™s a concept people maybe come to from a religious frame of mind, but it isnâ€™t medical. Dr. Anne Davis, Physicians for Reproductive Health

In fact, itâ€™s difficult to even research the topic because so many resources are in biased publications.

TrueLife, LifeMatters and National Right to Life all post countless articles â€œconfirmingâ€ that life begins at conception.

One organization, the American College of Pediatricians, presents itself as a scientific resource claiming that life begins at conception, but it has actually been declared by the Southern Poverty Law Center as a hate group for its anti-LGBT agenda, among its other beliefs. In its mission statement, the organization says that it recognizes â€œthe basic father-mother family unit, within the context of marriage, to be the optimal setting for childhood development.â€ Its director, Dr. Michelle Cretella, has appeared on Fox News to criticize â€œtransgenderism.â€

Such sources are unlikely to provide unbiased medical research.

But more neutral sources, like Davis and the medical community at large, are rightly not interested in arguing about the moment â€œlifeâ€ starts. Davis told HuffPost that Americans, a majority of whom support the Roe v. Wade ruling that legalized abortion, â€œare being hijacked by a tiny number of people,â€ such as Tom Price (who resigned as HHS secretary last month after criticism of his costly use of private planes for official business) and other HHS appointees, who wish to chip away at reproductive health care. Including this language in the strategic plan, Davis said, â€œis setting the stage for turning things back, coming up with these justifications for refusing to coverâ€ reproductive health care.

â€œPeople who wish to restrict access are trying to take non-medical concepts and attach them to medical things, and patients and doctors live with the consequences.â€
TITLE: Health Department Draft Plan Declares Life Begins At Conception

SUMMARY:
Bhole Baba's blessings gave me immense strength, and this strength is the biggest gift I have received from this land," he said.
"The blessings of Bhole Baba (Lord Shiva) gave me the strength to drink and digest poison.
This ability gave me the strength to serve the motherland with dedication over these many years," he said.
On the second day of his visit to poll-bound Gujarat, Modi held a roadshow here.
It gave me new energy to serve the nation with more zeal," Modi said, addressing a public gathering after the roadshow.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

VADNAGAR -- On his first visit to his birthplace since occupying the top post, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday held a roadshow and visited his school in Vadnagar and said the town had taught him to "drink poison".

At the B N High School where he studied, he smeared sand from the premises on his forehead.

Modi, who once sold tea at the Vadnagar railway station, recalled his journey to Delhi from Gujarat where he was the chief minister for 13 years from 2001.

He said he has managed to serve the nation with the blessings of Lord Shiva since 2001 despite some people "spewing venom" at him during these years.

He was apparently referring to the attacks on him during his tenure as Gujarat chief minister after the riots of 2002 in the state.

"Vadnagar has taught me to drink poison," he said, while noting that his birthplace is the land of Shiva, like Kashi (Varanasi), his Lok Sabha constituency.

Modi was addressing a public meeting after inaugurating a newly-built medical college and launching an immunisation programme.

"I started my journey from Vadnagar and now I have reached Kashi. Just like Vadnagar, Kashi is also the town of Bhole Baba. Bhole Baba's blessings gave me immense strength, and this strength is the biggest gift I have received from this land," he said.

"The blessings of Bhole Baba (Lord Shiva) gave me the strength to drink and digest poison. Due to this ability, I was able to counter all those who spewed venom against me since 2001. This ability gave me the strength to serve the motherland with dedication over these many years," he said.

The prime minister did his schooling in Vadnagar, an ancient town, which was once home to a Buddhist monastery and has a centuries-old Shiva temple.

On the second day of his visit to poll-bound Gujarat, Modi held a roadshow here. A large number of people lined the road to greet him. There were chants of "Modi-Modi" and flowers were showered on him along the route.

Before inaugurating a newly-built medical college in the town, he visited the Hatkeshwar Mahadev temple where he performed puja along with Chief Minister Vijay Rupani.

"I am touched by the immense love showered by the people of Vadnagar today. It gave me new energy to serve the nation with more zeal," Modi said, addressing a public gathering after the roadshow.

"I saw many faces among the people who came to greet me. Those faces brought back many memories of my childhood," he said.

Also on HuffPost India:
TITLE: Lord Shiva Gave Me Strength To Digest Poison And Serve The Nation, Says Narendra Modi

Plus, Kesha's triumphant return sparked a discussion about the most effective pop comebacks of recent years, with Rihanna getting the thumbs up from the group (which is more than can be said for Lady Gaga). HuffPost UK's entertainment podcast

How Whitney Houston Taught Me To Forgive My life was ruined. I felt like a big piece of me had also died. No one wanted to work with me. The media made me out to be a horrible person. And my singing meant nothing. Because Whitney was dead. Singer, actress and Celebrity Big Brother Housemate 2017

The Voice vs. The X-Factor: A Fair Comparison In the UK, X-Factor 2016 ended a few days before the new year emerged. Some days after 2017, The Voice started. I have been watching talent shows for ... All-around freelance writer

The BBC must be secretly kicking themselves that no-one like Mo had deigned to audition while on their channel. Despite all The X Factor's misgivings, the show certainly knew how to launch a star and it seems that The Voice UK now has one of its own. Writer & Blogger who loves to comment about TV, music & entertainment

Are We Living In A 'Fame' Crisis? The industry is lacking in authenticity. Now, people want to be famous for the sake of being famous even though they don't necessarily have the talent in a particular area, so the world of 'celebrityism' has been filled up with Big Brother winners and X Factor dropouts. Founder and Director at Creative Industry Hub

Why Are We Getting Honey G For Life And Not Just For Christmas? For the sake of our intelligence, those of you that are a part of the Honey G 'machine', please stop force feeding us her shtick and put your time and efforts into those that are more deserving of such an opportunity. Writer & Blogger who loves to comment about TV, music & entertainment

Why the New Matt Is No Matt The judges loved Matt. He was a favourite from the start. Even at the audition stage he seemed like a shoo-in. At the end, he turned out to be the irr... Would be multi-millionaire, would be celebrated writer- sadly neither (yet)

Matt Terry Shone Too Much To Not Win The X-Factor There are some people who glow no matter what and Matt Terry is one of them. So, it was inevitable for him, to win the X-Factor. At first glance, he ... All-around freelance writer

Is Saara Aalto The Only One That Can Save This Series Of The X Factor? With The Voice looking to start the new year with a bang, it seems unfortunate that The X Factor has become a ministry of blandness this time but a Saara win could be enough to show the new singing competition in town that the old dog still have some bite and shouldn't be put down quite yet. Writer & Blogger who loves to comment about TV, music & entertainment

Predicting The Winner Of The X-Factor I believe that all of them will have a career in music, as well as singers that left the X-Factor before them. Winning a music competition secures a high prestige, but what matters most for an artist is his establishment for many years in the industry. This is the real winner. All-around freelance writer

What Mahatma Gandhi Would Say To Honey G Mahatma Gandhi and Honey G haven't got many things in common. The first was an Indian leader, born in 1869, and the second is an eccentric rapper from... All-around freelance writer

Post-Truth, Postscript So the Oxford English Dictionary's 2016 Word of the Year has been announced. Where last year the word was actually a pictogram, the 'crying laughing face emoji', this year the word is a two-word phrase: Post-Truth. English teacher, book-lover, @TweeterofWit, blogger, lifelong learner

Honey G Can Still Win The X-Factor Now that Honey G was a candidate to leave, X-Factor fans could think that this was the precursor of her departure and that she is not able to reach the final or win the show. My research demonstrates that those people are wrong. All-around freelance writer

The Tempestuous Journey Of Saara Aalto In The X-Factor Saara Aalto has faced hard times in this year's X-Factor, perhaps more than anyone else that is currently in the competition. However, she has overcom... All-around freelance writer

Honey G Is A Phenomenon. Period. Snapshot from the Official X-Factor Youtube Channel (https://www.youtube.com/user/TheXFactorUK) Honey G is much more than a rap music artist. She is... All-around freelance writer

SUMMARY:
The number of Queenslanders reporting sexual assaults has increased for a fifth consecutive year, new data has revealed.
The state's Domestic and Family Violence Minister Shannon Fentiman has told parliament the rate of reported sexual assault had increased by 24 per cent since 2011, according to recent Australian Bureau of Statistics figures.
Figures show 4349 cases were reported to Queensland's authorities in 2016, compared to 4199 in the previous year.
Ms Fentiman said the government had invested funds to establish new sexual assault services across the state, including Toowoomba, Redlands, Ipswich and Mount Isa.
National domestic violence helpline: 1800 737 732 or 1800RESPECT.
TEXT:
The number of Queenslanders reporting sexual assaults has increased for a fifth consecutive year, new data has revealed.

The state's Domestic and Family Violence Minister Shannon Fentiman has told parliament the rate of reported sexual assault had increased by 24 per cent since 2011, according to recent Australian Bureau of Statistics figures.

Figures show 4349 cases were reported to Queensland's authorities in 2016, compared to 4199 in the previous year.

Women or girls accounted for four out of five victims, or 3570 people, and more than half were aged between 10 and 19, while victims aged up to 14 made up 55 per cent of male victims.

A majority of the assaults took place at residential locations, and in more than two-thirds of cases the offender was known to the victim.

Ms Fentiman said the government had invested funds to establish new sexual assault services across the state, including Toowoomba, Redlands, Ipswich and Mount Isa.

Additional services are slated for Roma and north of Brisbane.

National domestic violence helpline: 1800 737 732 or 1800RESPECT.

In an emergency call triple-zero.
TITLE: Sexual Assault Reports On The Rise In Queensland

Was eine Ãœberwachungskamera nachts in einer Schule aufgenommen hat, erinnert an einen Horrorfilm

Was eine Ãœberwachungskamera nachts in einer Schule aufgenommen hat, erinnert auf den ersten Blick an einen Horrorfilm. Die Aufnahmen stammen aus der Deerpark Christian Brothers School im irischen Cork. In dem Ãœberwachungsvideo ist zu sehen, wie eine TÃ¼r plÃ¶tzlich zuknallt.

Dann fÃ¤ngt einer der Spinde an, sich zu bewegen und wackelt wild hin und her

Bei einem anderen Spind springt die TÃ¼r auf und BlÃ¤tter fliegen heraus. Zuletzt fÃ¤llt wie von Geisterhand noch ein Warnschild um. Der stellvertretende Schulleiter Aaron Wolfe sagte dem TV-Sender â€œFox 13 Newsâ€œ, dass er nicht glaube, dass es in der Schule spuke. Er kÃ¶nne sich aber auch nicht erklÃ¤ren, wie die seltsamen Ereignisse von statten gehen konnten.

Der Vize-Direktor glaubt nicht, dass es in der Schule spukt

Seiner Meinung nach sei die Schule ein gruseliger Ort. Einige SchÃ¼ler berichten, dass GegenstÃ¤nde verschwinden wÃ¼rden und sie angeblich ab und zu komische GerÃ¤usche hÃ¶ren wÃ¼rden. SUMMARY:
Die wahre Ursache von Sucht ist jedoch nicht die Droge an sich - es ist vielmehr eine schmerzhafte Erfahrung, die ein Ungleichgewicht im Leben auslÃ¶st.
â€œDie Wunde mag nicht sehr tief erscheinen und der Schmerz nicht unertrÃ¤glich - vielleicht ist die Verletzung sogar vollkommen verborgen - aber sie ist daâ€, sagte MatÃ©.
Der Mangel an freiem Spiel, der zu Fantasielosigkeit fÃ¼hrtEine lebhafte Fantasie kÃ¶nnte ein sehr effektiver Schutz vor der Entwicklung von Suchtkrankheiten sein.
Und sie wird es vor der Ã–de und Leere bewahren, die AbhÃ¤ngigkeit und Sucht - und sei es â€œnurâ€ eine Konsumsucht, Kaufsucht oder Spielsucht - begÃ¼nstigt.
â€œUnd das ist wegen der inneren Friedlosigkeit sucht- oder dopinggefÃ¤hrdet.â€Unsere Leistungsgesellschaft macht diejenigen zu Verlierern, die nicht mithalten kÃ¶nnen.
TEXT:
Wenn wir die Frage stellen, was die Ursache fÃ¼r Drogensucht ist, wÃ¼rden viele Menschen wahrscheinlich antworten: â€œNa selbstverstÃ¤ndlich Drogen!â€

Diese tiefe Ãœberzeugung ist der Grund fÃ¼r einen weltweiten und jahrzehntelangen Krieg gegen Drogen, der in vielen LÃ¤ndern bis heute andauert.

Die wahre Ursache von Sucht ist jedoch nicht die Droge an sich - es ist vielmehr eine schmerzhafte Erfahrung, die ein Ungleichgewicht im Leben auslÃ¶st. Und diese schmerzhafte Erfahrung lÃ¤sst sich zumeist auf Erlebnisse in der Kindheit zurÃ¼ckfÃ¼hren. Am hÃ¤ufigsten trifft das auf emotionalen und kÃ¶rperlichen Missbrauch zu, aber es gibt auch weniger offensichtliche AuslÃ¶ser. (Mehr dazu oben im Video)

â€œNicht alle AbhÃ¤ngigkeiten haben ihren Ursprung in Missbrauch oder Traumata, aber ich bin Ã¼berzeugt, dass sie alle auf schmerzhafte Erfahrungen zurÃ¼ckgefÃ¼hrt werden kÃ¶nnenâ€, sagte Gabor MatÃ©, ein kanadischer Arzt, der sich seit Jahrzehnten mit Sucht und der BekÃ¤mpfung von AbhÃ¤ngigkeiten beschÃ¤ftigt.

Schmerz im Zentrum der AbhÃ¤ngigkeit

MatÃ© glaubt, dass Schmerz im Zentrum jeder AbhÃ¤ngigkeit steht - egal, ob es Drogensucht, Internet-AbhÃ¤ngigkeit, Spielsucht, Kaufsucht, Magersucht oder Sucht nach Arbeit ist.

â€œDie Wunde mag nicht sehr tief erscheinen und der Schmerz nicht unertrÃ¤glich - vielleicht ist die Verletzung sogar vollkommen verborgen - aber sie ist daâ€, sagte MatÃ©.

Und wer Schmerz empfindet, der wird versuchen, diesem Schmerz zu entkommen.

Sucht ist die Krebserkrankung der Seele

â€œWer seelisch belastet ist, sucht nach Entlastung und findet diese unter anderem in Alkohol, Drogen oder Medikamentenâ€, schreibt Psychotherapeut Ralf Schneider in â€œDie Suchtfiebelâ€.

Das bedeutet aber nicht, dass jeder, der eine schmerzhafte Erfahrung in der Kindheit gemacht hat, spÃ¤ter auch eine AbhÃ¤ngigkeit entwickelt. Jeder Mensch geht mit Verletzungen ein wenig anders um.

Es gibt jedoch Erlebnisse in der Kindheit, die Schmerz verursachen und dadurch AbhÃ¤ngigkeiten begÃ¼nstigen. Sie kÃ¶nnen frÃ¼hzeitig von Eltern vermieden werden, indem sie sich bewusst machen, dass bestimmte Erziehungsmethoden Schaden verursachen.

6 Erlebnisse in der Kindheit, die Schmerz auslÃ¶sen:



1. Die fehlende Befriedigung von GrundbedÃ¼rfnissen

Geborgenheit, Schutz und Liebe sind ebenso wichtige GrundbedÃ¼rfnisse von Babys und Kleinkindern wie Hunger und Durst. Werden sie nicht befriedigt, gerÃ¤t das Kind in eine Notsituation: Es ist schlieÃŸlich von den Eltern abhÃ¤ngig und es hat nur seine Stimme und mÃ¶glicherweise noch keine Sprache, um sich mitzuteilen.

Wenn Eltern ihre Kinder zum Beispiel schreien lassen - etwa, weil sie glauben, dass Babys so lernen, allein einzuschlafen (was nicht der Fall ist - die Babys haben nicht aus der Erfahrung gelernt, sie haben schlichtweg aufgegeben), kÃ¶nnen sie damit unwissentlich erheblichen Schaden anrichten.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Das passiert mit Babys, die man schreien lÃ¤sst

Das Schreienlassen hat keinerlei pÃ¤dagogischen Wert

Babys und Kleinkinder sind geistig noch nicht weit genug entwickelt, um logische Schlussfolgerungen aus dem Verhalten ihrer Eltern zu ziehen. Sie weinen nicht, um ihre Eltern zu Ã¤rgern oder zu manipulieren, sondern weil sie irgendein Problem, irgendein BedÃ¼rfnis haben.

Viele Kinder fÃ¼hlen sich nur in der NÃ¤he ihrer Eltern sicher genug, um einschlafen zu kÃ¶nnen. Denn genau da, in der NÃ¤he ihrer Eltern, sind Kinder nunmal am sichersten aufgehoben und aus Sicht der Evolution am besten geschÃ¼tzt.

Schreienlassen schÃ¤digt KÃ¶rper und Seele

Wenn das Kind also weint, dann ruft es nach seinen Eltern. Reagieren die Eltern jedoch nicht darauf, entsteht Stress. Das Hormon Cortisol wird vermehrt ausgeschÃ¼ttet. Dies kann Experten zufolge das zentrale Nervensystem sowie die Gehirnentwicklung beeintrÃ¤chtigen. Und neben diesen kÃ¶rperlichen Auswirkungen bleiben natÃ¼rlich auch die Seelischen nicht aus.

Wenn Kinder das GefÃ¼hl haben, so viel schreien zu kÃ¶nnen, wie sie wollen und doch nicht gehÃ¶rt zu werden, entstehen Schmerz und Unsicherheit, in besonders schlimmen FÃ¤llen sogar Traumata.

Bindungsprobleme, SchlafstÃ¶rungen, Ã„ngste und Depressionen kÃ¶nnen mÃ¶gliche Folgen sein. Aber auch AbhÃ¤ngigkeiten und SÃ¼chte.

Schwere Versagungen in der Befriedigung von GrundbedÃ¼rfnissen, die Dauerstress und Hilflosigkeit hervorbringen, kÃ¶nnen sich laut Schneider auf die Bereitschaft zum Drogenkonsum auswirken. In der â€œSuchtfiebelâ€ schreibt er: â€œOffensichtlich erzeugt der frÃ¼he Stress eine VerÃ¤nderung im Gehirn.â€

2. Die Erfahrung, dass Liebe an Bedingungen geknÃ¼pft ist

Fast alle Eltern wÃ¼rden voller Ãœberzeugung behaupten, dass sie ihr Kind bedingungslos lieben. Es sind jedoch vergleichsweise wenige, denen das wirklich und in letzter Konsequenz gelingt.

â€œEs gibt ganz wenige Kinder auf der Welt, die das GlÃ¼ck hatten, um ihrer Selbst willen geliebt zu werdenâ€, sagte der bekannte deutsche Hirnforscher Gerald HÃ¼ther der Huffington Post.

Dabei ist genau das aus seiner Sicht die Grundvoraussetzung fÃ¼r eine glÃ¼ckliche Kindheit:

â€œEin Kind muss spÃ¼ren, dass es so wie es ist richtig ist. Dass es um seiner Selbst willen und bedingungslos geliebt wird. Das ist die wichtigste Erfahrung, die jedes Kind brauchtâ€, sagte HÃ¼ther der HuffPost.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Ein Hirnforscher erklÃ¤rt: Das ist das Geheimnis einer glÃ¼cklichen Kindheit

Zuneigung im Tausch gegen Gehorsam

Kinder sind dann am glÃ¼cklichsten, wenn sie nicht das GefÃ¼hl haben, sich anstrengen zu mÃ¼ssen, um von ihren Eltern geliebt zu werden.

Viele Kinder haben jedoch das GefÃ¼hl, dass ihre Eltern sie mehr lieben wÃ¼rden, wenn ihre Schulnoten besser wÃ¤ren. Oder wenn sie immer artig und hilfsbereit wÃ¤ren, nie widersprechen oder in Wut ausbrechen wÃ¼rden.

Es ist leider bis heute eine gÃ¤ngige Erziehungsmethode, Kinder mit Zuneigung zu belohnen, die sich so verhalten, wie ihre Eltern (oder auch Lehrer, Erzieher) das gerne hÃ¤tten. Und die meisten Erwachsenen meinen das nicht einmal bÃ¶se - ihnen ist schlichtweg nicht bewusst, dass dieses Verhalten extrem verletzend ist.

Ein Kind, das spÃ¼rt, dass es nicht bedingungslos geliebt wird, hat ein sehr groÃŸes Problem. Denn Kinder sind von der Zuneigung ihrer Eltern abhÃ¤ngig - das hat die Natur so vorgesehen.

Das empfindliche Band der Liebe

Aus diesem Grund kommen sie bereits mit einem sicheren Band des Vertrauens und der Verbundenheit zu ihren Eltern zu Welt. Weil sie ihre Eltern lieben und sie brauchen, sind Kinder bereit, alles zu tun, um ebenfalls geliebt zu werden, damit sie sich weiterhin auf den Schutz und die FÃ¼rsorge der Eltern verlassen kÃ¶nnen.

Doch diese besondere Verbindung, dieses natÃ¼rliche Band des Vertrauens zwischen Eltern und Kind, ist empfindlich.

â€œWenn ein Kind zum Objekt elterlicher Erwartungen, WÃ¼nsche, Ziele, Vorstellungen oder MaÃŸnahmen gemacht wird, dann zerreiÃŸt dieses Band zu den Elternâ€, sagte HÃ¼ther. â€œUnd das geht mit einem groÃŸen Schmerz einher.â€

Der Schmerz des unvollkommenen Kindes

Dieser Schmerz ist sogar messbar. In wissenschaftlichen Versuchen konnte nachgewiesen werden, dass dies derselbe Schmerz ist, den der KÃ¶rper auch bei physischem Schmerz signalisiert. Es werden dieselben Bereiche im Gehirn aktiviert, die auch betroffen sind, wenn wir kÃ¶rperliche Schmerzen erleben.

Diesen Schmerz, der entsteht, wenn wir als Kind das GefÃ¼hl haben, nicht vollkommen zu sein, verarbeitet jeder Menschen anders.

Manche Menschen werden ihr Leben lang versuchen sich anzustrengen, um geliebt und akzeptiert zu werden. Andere werden sich mÃ¶glicherweise mit schmerzlindernden Substanzen behelfen.

3. Ein Ã¼berfÃ¼rsorgliches Verhalten der Eltern, das zu Verunsicherung fÃ¼hrt

â€œWenn man Suchtkranke rÃ¼ckblickend fragt, welche seelischen Ursachen ihr Substanzkonsum gehabt hat, erhÃ¤lt man unzÃ¤hlig viele plausible Antworten. ÃœberreprÃ¤sentiert scheinen diejenigen zu sein, die sich nicht trauen, Risiken einzugehen, die sich â€˜Mut antrinkenâ€™ oder ihre Hemmungen durch Drogenkonsum herabsetzen, die also Angst verringernâ€, schreibt Schneider in der â€œSuchtfiebelâ€.

Die Bereitschaft, Risiken einzugehen und furchtlos auf Herausforderungen zuzugehen, wird zu groÃŸen Teilen in der Kindheit geformt.

Kinder mÃ¼ssen hinfallen dÃ¼rfen

Kinder mÃ¼ssen unbeaufsichtigt spielen, sie mÃ¼ssen sich sogar in gewissem MaÃŸe in Gefahr begeben, um zu erkennen, wo ihre eigenen Grenzen liegen.

â€œEs kann kein Kind lernen, wie man aufsteht, wenn es nie hinfÃ¤llt. Es kann kein Kind laufen lernen, wenn ihm die Steine weggerÃ¤umt werdenâ€, sagte Gerald HÃ¼ther der HuffPost.

So schwer es auch fÃ¤llt - man tut einem Kind wirklich keinen Gefallen, wenn man es vor jeder Gefahr beschÃ¼tzt.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: An alle Ã¼berfÃ¼rsorglichen Eltern: Was tut ihr euren Kindern an?

4. Der Mangel an freiem Spiel, der zu Fantasielosigkeit fÃ¼hrt

Eine lebhafte Fantasie kÃ¶nnte ein sehr effektiver Schutz vor der Entwicklung von Suchtkrankheiten sein. Zu dieser Erkenntnis kommt Eckhard Schiffer, Autor der Bestsellers â€œWarum Huckleberry Finn nicht sÃ¼chtig wurdeâ€.

Bei seiner jahrelangen Arbeit mit Suchtkranken stellte Schiffer fest, dass Ã–de und Langeweile Vorboten spÃ¤terer AbhÃ¤ngigkeiten sein kÃ¶nnen. Viele Patienten wÃ¼rden Suchtmittel benutzen, um einer inneren Leere zu entkommen.

Und diese Ã–de und Langeweile entsteht aus seiner Sicht durch einen Mangel an Fantasie, die wiederum auf einen Mangel des freien Spiels in der Kindheit zurÃ¼ckgeht - ein Problem, von dem heute immer mehr Kinder betroffen sind.

Der Angriff auf das freie Spiel

Das freie Spiel wird durch zwei entscheidende Entwicklungen beeintrÃ¤chtigt: Zum einen bleibt Kindern immer weniger Zeit zum Spielen, weil viele Eltern wollen, dass ihre Kinder neben der Schule in Sport-, Musik- oder Sprachkursen weiter gefÃ¶rdert werden.

Zum anderen wird heute immer mehr in das kindliche Spiel eingegriffen, sodass es seine SpontanitÃ¤t und Regellosigkeit verliert; Es wird weniger um des Spielens Willen gespielt und mehr, um ein bestimmtes Ergebnis zu erzielen. Wir greifen viel zu hÃ¤ufig in das kindliche Spiel ein, indem wir organisieren, zeigen, â€œwie es besser gehtâ€, erklÃ¤ren, dass BÃ¤ume grÃ¼ne und nicht blaue BlÃ¤tter haben.

KreativitÃ¤t schÃ¼tzt den Geist

KreativitÃ¤t und Fantasie entstehen jedoch genau da, wo das Kind frei sein darf. Wo alles erlaubt und alles mÃ¶glich ist. Ein Kind, das ausreichend spielen darf, wird sich nicht langweilen. Es wird immer neue MÃ¶glichkeiten finden, sich zu beschÃ¤ftigen und dafÃ¼r braucht es nicht einmal Spielzeug.

Die so gewonnene KreativitÃ¤t wird ihm ein Leben lang helfen, LÃ¶sungen fÃ¼r die komplexesten Probleme zu finden. Um die Ecke zu denken, sein Denken nicht durch andere einschrÃ¤nken zu lassen. Und sie wird es vor der Ã–de und Leere bewahren, die AbhÃ¤ngigkeit und Sucht - und sei es â€œnurâ€ eine Konsumsucht, Kaufsucht oder Spielsucht - begÃ¼nstigt.

5. Das Leistungsprinzip unserer Gesellschaft, dem Kinder unterworfen werden

Was Kinder heute leisten mÃ¼ssen, ist enorm. Schule um acht Uhr morgens, Konzentration und mÃ¶glichst rege Beteiligung in allen FÃ¤chern, anschlieÃŸend Hausaufgaben und auÃŸerschulische AktivitÃ¤ten - schon Kinder haben einen straffen Zeitplan, arbeiten also teilweise so viel wie Erwachsene.

Und das ist alles in Ordnung, sobald man nicht aus dem Raster fÃ¤llt, hinter den Erwartungen zurÃ¼ckbleibt oder das schnelle Tempo einfach nicht mitgehen kann.

Schon im Kindergarten wird den Kleinsten beigebracht: Nur wer hart arbeitet, kann erfolgreich sein. Und nur wer erfolgreich ist, kann glÃ¼cklich sein.

Kinder sollen funktionieren und Leistung erbringen

Wir blÃ¤uen unseren Kindern ein, dass sie gute Noten brauchen, um spÃ¤ter mithalten zu kÃ¶nnen. Kommen sie mit einer Drei nach Hause, machen wir ihnen klar, dass sie doch auch eine Zwei haben kÃ¶nnten, wenn sie sich nur ein bisschen mehr anstrengten. Was viele Kinder aber hÃ¶ren, ist: Du wÃ¼rdest uns besser gefallen, wenn du bessere Noten hÃ¤ttest. Eine FÃ¼nf auf dem Zeugnis wÃ¼rde uns sehr enttÃ¤uschen.

â€œ36 Prozent aller Eltern sind bereit, ihren zehnjÃ¤hrigen Kindern Arzneimittel zur Verbesserung der Konzentration zu gebenâ€, schreibt Schneider in der â€œSuchtfiebelâ€. Dieses Leistungsstreben fordert jedoch seinen Preis: â€œUnter den guten SchÃ¼lern ist der Anteil derjenigen, die regelmÃ¤ÃŸig Medikamente konsumieren, am hÃ¶chsten.â€

Ãœber solche karriere- und kulturbeflissenen Familien schreibt Schiffer:

â€œHier wird eine andauernde innere Friedlosigkeit erzeugt, denn die Leistung der eigenen Kinder steht im Vergleich zu der der jeweils anderen. Die Szene wird von Konkurrenz und Marktwert beherrscht. Was ist mein Marktwert? Wie steche ich meinen Konkurrenten aus?â€

Das falsche Selbst vergiftet die Seele

So entstÃ¼nde schlieÃŸlich ein falsches Selbst. â€œUnd das ist wegen der inneren Friedlosigkeit sucht- oder dopinggefÃ¤hrdet.â€

Unsere Leistungsgesellschaft macht diejenigen zu Verlierern, die nicht mithalten kÃ¶nnen. Wer die Erwartungen nicht erfÃ¼llt, versucht hÃ¤ufig, sich zu verbiegen - jenes falsche Selbst zu erschaffen, um nicht ausgeschlossen zu werden.

Der daraus resultierende Stress, das andauernde Streben nach Erfolg und GlÃ¼ck, das doch scheinbar nie wirklich erreicht werden kann, ist Gift fÃ¼r die Seele. FÃ¼r Kinderseelen noch viel mehr als fÃ¼r Erwachsene.

Das stÃ¤ndige GefÃ¼hl, nicht gut genug zu sein, lÃ¶st einen Schmerz aus. Vielleicht einen, der zunÃ¤chst unter der OberflÃ¤che schlummert, wie MatÃ© es ausdrÃ¼ckte, aber eben einen, der durchaus spÃ¼rbar ist.

Es ist genau dieses Leistungsstreben, das zu den neuen Volkskrankheiten wie Depressionen und Burnout fÃ¼hrt - und das ein BedÃ¼rfnis nach Ablenkung, Flucht und nach BetÃ¤ubung auslÃ¶sen kann.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Das wird spÃ¤ter aus Kindern, die ihren Eltern stÃ¤ndig widersprechen

6. Die Angst vor dem Versagen, die Eltern auf ihre Kinder Ã¼bertragen

Es ist nicht leicht, heute ein Kind zu erziehen und viele Eltern fÃ¼hlen sich stark unter Druck gesetzt. Hinzu kommt hÃ¤ufig die Angst, zu versagen. Was, wenn mein Kind in der Schule nicht gut genug ist? Was, wenn es in dieser globalisierten Leistungsgesellschaft nicht mithalten kann?

Viele Eltern wollen ihre Kinder beschÃ¼tzen und greifen deshalb sehr stark in ihr Leben ein. Sie planen ihre Freizeit, sie greifen in ihr Spiel ein, sie erwarten, dass ihr Kind ihre Erwartungen erfÃ¼llt. Sie glauben, dass sie es aus Liebe tun. In Wahrheit jedoch steckt Angst dahinter:

Elterliche Geborgenheit kÃ¶nne schnell in einen WÃ¼rgegriff umschlagen, schreibt Schiffer, â€œwenn die Eltern aus eigener Not heraus nicht mehr die BedÃ¼rfnisse und Interessen ihres Kindes im Auge haben, sondern vorwiegend ihre eigene Angst in Schach halten".

Leistung als magisches Mittel gegen die Angst

Das Heilmittel, das unsere Gesellschaft fÃ¼r diese Angst erfunden hat, heiÃŸt Leistung. Solange man nur hart genug arbeitet, wird man nicht untergehen.

â€œLeistung als magisches Mittel gegen Angst wird heute schon von Kindern eingefordertâ€, schreibt Schiffer. â€œUnd ebendies bedeutet eine erhebliche EinschrÃ¤nkung der Autonomie und des eigenen Weges.â€

Kinder, die nicht selbst bestimmen, nicht selbst ihre Umwelt entdecken und erleben, nicht ihren eigenen Interessen in ihrem eigenen Tempo folgen dÃ¼rfen, verlieren ihren Eigensinn.

DrÃ¶hnungen gegen die Langeweile

Der Verlust des Eigensinns bleibt jedoch nicht ohne Folgen:

â€œWenn Erwachsene die FÃ¤higkeit, sich in tagtrÃ¤umerischer Weise von ihrer Umwelt ansprechen zu lassen und so stÃ¶bernd, stutzend, und staunend innerlich viel zu erleben, verloren bzw. nicht ausreichend erworben haben, dann verlieren sie einen Teil ihres Eigensinns. Un diesem Augenblick sind sie auf Mittel, Medien, â€˜DrÃ¶hnungenâ€™ angewiesen, um etwas zu erleben.â€

Was Kinder also viel mehr brauchen als gute Zeugnisse und gradlinige LebenslÃ¤ufe sind FreirÃ¤ume. Platz fÃ¼r Abenteuer, RÃ¤ume zur Selbstentfaltung. Und die Chance, auch mal scheitern zu dÃ¼rfen.

Kindern helfen Seit Jahren schon warnen Experten, dass allein in Deutschland jedes fÃ¼nfte Kind in Armut lebt. Viel schwieriger noch die Situation von Kindern in SÃ¼deuropa, Afrika oder SÃ¼dasien. Wie ihr selbst aktiv werden kÃ¶nnt, erfahrt ihr bei unserem Kooperationspartner Betterplace

(lk)
TITLE: Die wahre Ursache von Sucht geht auf diese 6 Erlebnisse aus der Kindheit zurÃ¼ck

TEXT:
The original cast of â€˜The Hitchhikerâ€™s Guide To The Galaxyâ€™ have reunited to record a brand new episode of the cult sci-fi classic for the seriesâ€™ 40th anniversary.

Itâ€™s been 12 years since fans were treated to a big screen adaption of the show, starring Martin Freeman and Bill Bailey.

Now a sixth instalment, entitled â€˜Hexagonal Phaseâ€™, is set to air next spring on the seriesâ€™ original home of Radio 4.

#HitchhikersGuide returns to @BBCRadio4 for its Hexagonal Phase (with original radio cast) to mark 40th anniversary: https://t.co/OTLV3fG5r5 pic.twitter.com/C6iYMeqABp â€” BBC Press Office (@bbcpress) October 11, 2017

The BBC station first broadcast Douglas Adamsâ€™ sci-fi comedy in 1978. A further four series followed between 1980 and 2005, as well as a hit TV version in 1981.

â€˜Hexagonal Phaseâ€™ has been adapted from Eoin Colferâ€™s spin-off novel â€˜And Another Thingâ€¦â€™, which was commissioned to mark the 30th anniversary of the first novel.

Simon Jones will again play the quintessentially English Arthur Dent, who travels through space and time following the destruction of Earth.

Rex Martin Freeman starred in the 2005 big screen adaption of the classic cult sci-fi comedy.

Speaking about reprising his role, Simon Jones said: â€œIt seems extraordinary that itâ€™s been forty years since we recorded the first pilot episode for BBC Radio; how modest were our expectations then, and how amazing a worldwide phenomenon it became, and continues to be.

â€œI never expected to still be searching for a decent cup of tea and some kind of answer to Life, the Universe and Everything almost a lifetime later.

â€œStill, the dressing-gown and towel may be a little threadbare, like my hair, but my voice, much to my surprise, hasnâ€™t changed a decibel, and despite years in America, I can still talk Arthurâ€™s â€˜indignant-poshâ€™.â€

Samantha BÃ©art, who will co-star in the latest adaptation, tweeted a copy of the new script, captioning it: â€œBack to work.â€
TITLE: â€˜Hitchhikers Guide To The Galaxyâ€™ Original Cast Reunite To Record Brand New Episode Of Cult Sci-Fi Series For 40th Anniversary

SUMMARY:
Cuando tratas de determinar si una relaciÃ³n te conviene o no, en realidad ya conoces la respuesta.
Cuando una relaciÃ³n no funciona, muchas personas reconocen que tuvieron una corazonada desde el primer momento de que la cosa iba a acabar mal.
Â¿EstÃ¡n mÃ¡s contentos cuando piensan el uno en el otro o cuando pasan tiempo juntos?
Si supieran que la otra persona serÃ­a exactamente igual durante el resto de su vida juntos, Â¿aÃºn querrÃ­an estar juntos?
Â¿Se aferran mÃ¡s al pasado de su relaciÃ³n que a lo que les depara el futuro juntos?
TEXT:
Escrito por Brianna Wiest, autora de 101 Essays That Will Change The Way You Think.

Cuando tratas de determinar si una relaciÃ³n te conviene o no, en realidad ya conoces la respuesta. A veces solo necesitas plantearte la pregunta de otra manera para darte cuenta.

Cuando una relaciÃ³n no funciona, muchas personas reconocen que tuvieron una corazonada desde el primer momento de que la cosa iba a acabar mal. A veces, la esperanza y el cariÃ±o te ciegan, y la realidad, ya estuviera la relaciÃ³n destinada al fracaso o no, se convierte en un hecho aleccionador que hay que asumir.

Y mejor darse cuenta lo antes posible antes que perder el tiempo, Â¿no?

1. Â¿Discuten por tonterÃ­as o sobre si quieren seguir juntos?

2. Â¿Piensan en cortar solo cuando se enojan o tambiÃ©n cuando todo deberÃ­a ir bien?

3. Â¿EstÃ¡n mÃ¡s contentos cuando piensan el uno en el otro o cuando pasan tiempo juntos?

4. Â¿Se encuentran completamente a gusto y enamorados? Ambas cosas son fundamentales si quieren que funcione a largo plazo. DeberÃ­an gustarse y seguir enamorados.

5. Â¿Discuten porque les molesta no estar de acuerdo en un asunto importante y quieren estar en la misma onda, o directamente porque no se soportan y la burbuja les estalla en la cara una y otra vez?

6. Â¿Aprenden del otro porque intentan cambiarse o porque les interesa y entusiasma saber cÃ³mo piensa y vive su pareja?

7. Â¿Se desahogan con otras personas sobre los problemas de su relaciÃ³n o se desquitan entre ustedes sobre lo que sucede con otras personas?

8. Â¿Pasan el tiempo pensando si de verdad deberÃ­an seguir juntos o simplemente recorren juntos los altibajos que tiene cualquier relaciÃ³n?

9. Â¿Los inundan sentimientos inexplicables de ansiedad y dudas mÃ¡s que de felicidad, fortuna y pasiÃ³n?

10. Si tuvieran que escoger entre casarse maÃ±ana o nunca, Â¿quÃ© harÃ­an?

11. Si supieran que la otra persona serÃ­a exactamente igual durante el resto de su vida juntos, Â¿aÃºn querrÃ­an estar juntos?

12. Â¿Les suscita mÃ¡s dudas que orgullo presentarse a sus respectivas familias?

13. Â¿Les interesa el sexo, pero tratan de evitar otros contactos Ã­ntimos como los besos o los abrazos?

14. Â¿Es su pareja la primera persona a la que quieren llamar cuando les sucede algo importante?

15. Â¿Se tratan como prioridad o como una mera opciÃ³n?

16. Â¿Son sinceros con sus amigos sobre cÃ³mo va la relaciÃ³n o sienten a veces que es mejor ocultar la verdad?

17. Â¿A sus amigos les gusta estar con ustedes ahora que estÃ¡n juntos o parecen poco interesados en eso?

18. Â¿Piensan que no estÃ¡n preparados en este momento para tener una relaciÃ³n o se sienten desconcertados por no querer entregarse completamente a alguien que, en otras circunstancias, parecerÃ­a perfecto, de modo que hacen lo posible para que ese "sea el momento"?

19. Â¿Se dan cuenta del hecho de que nunca serÃ¡ el momento perfecto hasta que encuentren a la persona indicada y que, cuando llegue ese momento, no habrÃ¡ nada que pueda interponerse entre dos personas que de verdad quieran estar juntas?

20. Â¿Se aferran mÃ¡s al pasado de su relaciÃ³n que a lo que les depara el futuro juntos?

21. Â¿Coinciden en los asuntos mÃ¡s innegociables? (DÃ³nde quieren vivir, si quieren tener hijos, su grado de monogamia...).

22. Â¿Pueden pasar largos periodos de tiempo juntos y felices sin necesitar un descanso el uno del otro?

23. Si fueran a pasar el resto de su vida en una isla desierta y solo pudieran llevar a una persona con la que pasar ese tiempo, Â¿elegirÃ­an a su pareja?

24. Â¿Les agobia la incertidumbre? Â¿EstÃ¡n dispuestos a reconocer que no estar seguros de su futuro juntos es una forma de estar seguros de lo contrario y que tienen miedo de aceptarlo?

25. Â¿Se empeÃ±an en demostrar que no se necesitan? Â¿Se dan cuenta de que la actitud de "quiero estar solo" es una forma de decir "no eres la persona correcta aunque lo parezca"?

Consigue un ejemplar de la obra de Brianna Wiest,101 Essays That Will Change The Way You Think, aquÃ­.

Este post fue publicado originalmente en 'Thought Catalog' y 'Quote Catalog', apareciÃ³ posteriormente en el HuffPost Estados Unidos y ha sido traducido del inglÃ©s por Daniel Templeman Sauco para El HuffPost.

*Este contenido representa la opiniÃ³n del autor y no necesariamente la de HuffPost MÃ©xico.
TITLE: 25 importantes preguntas para saber si tu relaciÃ³n tiene futuro

SUMMARY:
The charities have called on the government to ensure all hospitals have accessible bereavement rooms and a member of staff to lead on bereavement care.
â€œI donâ€™t know what more the staff could have done to help us through that time,â€ Ferguson told HuffPost UK.
I had my own bathroom.â€Ferguson was assigned a specially trained bereavement midwife as soon as she arrived.
The midwife stayed with her and, even when she finished her shift, a second bereavement midwife took over.
The midwife stayed with them until after midnight, speaking to them and checking they were okay.
TEXT:
A mum has opened up about the â€œexemplaryâ€ quality of care she received from a NHS hospital in the hours before and after having a stillbirth.

Viki Ferguson, 45, hopes her experience at the Royal Victoria Infirmary, in Newcastle, will serve as an example to other hospitals who may not currently provide such a high standard of care.

The mother chose to share her story during Baby Loss Awareness Week (9-15 October) after charities revealed current levels of care offered to women after baby loss are â€œworryingly inconsistentâ€ across the UK.

The charities have called on the government to ensure all hospitals have accessible bereavement rooms and a member of staff to lead on bereavement care.

Ferguson believes these demands are achievable as she received a high standard of care after her stillbirth in 2013.

â€œI donâ€™t know what more the staff could have done to help us through that time,â€ Ferguson told HuffPost UK. â€œEverything they did was for our benefit.â€

VikiFerguson Viki Ferguson and her husband Colin.

In March 2013, Ferguson was 35 weeks pregnant with her first child when she went in for a routine scan.

She and her partner Colin knew their daughter had a heart condition, so she was having checkups on a more regular basis than most mothers-to-be.

At the appointment, she was told there was no heartbeat, her baby had died.

â€œThe rest of that afternoon was a bit of a blur,â€ Ferguson explained. â€œBut what I can remember is how supportive the staff were, they talked us through everything that was going to happen.â€

Ferguson was told she had a choice of being induced or waiting for labour to start. She chose to be induced.

What surprised Ferguson when she went back to the hospital to give birth on 16 March 2013, was that she was given a private room away from other pregnant women.

â€œWithin the maternity ward they have a bereavement suite,â€ she explained. â€œThere are two rooms especially for anyone who will have a stillbirth. It is away from the noise, you canâ€™t hear anyone else in labour or any crying babies.

â€œIt was really well thought out and very self-contained. I had my own bathroom.â€

Ferguson was assigned a specially trained bereavement midwife as soon as she arrived. The midwife stayed with her and, even when she finished her shift, a second bereavement midwife took over.

â€œIf you want them there, they are there,â€ Ferguson explained. â€œIf you wanted to be left alone, they left you alone.

â€œThey looked after us so well, they made sure Colin was looked after as well, he was part of it - they brought another bed in the room so he could stay with me overnight.

â€œThings like that really made a difference to me.â€

â€œThe care was exemplary. I donâ€™t know how it would have felt not to have that. If they want a model to work on, that was it." Viki Ferguson

When Ferguson gave birth, she was surprised how comforted she felt by the midwife and staff in the room with her.

â€œThey bathed my daughter, they put her in a babygro and treated her if she was still alive,â€ the mum explained.

â€œThey were talking to her and made it the nicest experience it couldâ€™ve been. It wasnâ€™t like it was all over as soon as she was born. How they treated her meant so much to us.â€

Ferguson gave birth at 8.20pm and she and her husband had a couple of hours with their baby that night. The midwife stayed with them until after midnight, speaking to them and checking they were okay.

â€œI really couldnâ€™t have faulted the care,â€ she said.

â€œThe next day we had another couple of hours with our daughter and then we had staff coming in to talk us through everything that happens with funerals, who would be in touch with us, and the counselling that was available. It was all the information we needed.â€

Ferguson said she didnâ€™t feel rushed to leave the bereavement suite - she was told she could stay as long as she wanted, but she decided to get discharged the next day.

On leaving the suite, she was given a memory envelope with photos, hair, footprints and handprints taken from her daughter, and knitted teddy bear twins - one that stayed with her daughter and one that stayed with the couple.

In the weeks following, Ferguson had a visit from a chaplain to talk through the funeral, two visits from the health visitor, a counselling session, and her GP ensured she didnâ€™t go back to work until she was up to it.

â€œThe care was exemplary,â€ she added. â€œI donâ€™t know how it would have felt not to have that. If they want a model to work on, that was it.

â€œThe staff were completely lead by us, I didnâ€™t feel like we were forced into anything. Everything was for our benefit.â€

Ferguson believes good care does â€œnot require a complete overhaul of the NHSâ€.

She said small gestures such as the memory box and the empathy shown by the midwives made her experience as good as it could have been.

â€œEvery hospital should have a midwife or midwives trained in bereavement,â€ she said. â€Just to have someone to know how to deal with death and what to expect - simple things like that made such a difference.

â€œItâ€™s shocking that there is a postcode lottery of care.

â€œIt helps so much to have support at a time like that. If there is a consistent level of care, it helps you through the grieving process.â€
TITLE: Mum's Account Of Care After Baby Loss 'Should Serve As An Example To Other NHS Hospitals'
Satire

Patel told the Mint newspaper that the economy was recovering after growth slowed to a three-year low of 5.7% in the April-June quarter.
"Growth is always there in the MPC's scheme of things; we don't lose sight of that, but not at the cost of inflation," Patel was quoted as saying in the interview.

TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

MUMBAI -- Fostering monetary conditions conducive to economic growth were a constant consideration for Indian policymakers, but would not take priority over achieving the central bank's inflation target, Governor Urjit Patel told a newspaper on Monday.

Patel told the Mint newspaper that the economy was recovering after growth slowed to a three-year low of 5.7% in the April-June quarter.

The slowdown had sparked some calls for lower interest rates, but with inflation rising the RBI left rates unchanged at a review by the monetary policy committee (MPC) last week.

"Growth is always there in the MPC's scheme of things; we don't lose sight of that, but not at the cost of inflation," Patel was quoted as saying in the interview.

"However, we have to be careful â€” we should aim at achieving the inflation target without losing sight of supporting economic growth."

Consumer inflation accelerated to 3.36 percent in August. India's central bank has a medium-term target for annual inflation of 4 percent with the flexbility of plus/minus 2 percent on either side to make room for food price volatility.

The (MPC) will strive to achieve its 4 percent inflation target on a "durable basis", Patel said.

Last week, the RBI kept its repo rate unchanged at 6.00 percent as expected last week, and raised inflation projections, cooling hopes for future rate cuts.

However, Patel said growth was already starting to recover. The RBI last week cut its projection for gross value added - an indicator of growth it prefers to 6.7 percent from 7.3 percent for the year ending in March - higher than some analyst forecasts.

"Our projections based on high frequency real economy indicators suggest that growth will pick up in the third and fourth quarters (of the current fiscal year) to above 7 percent," he told Mint.

"We have started seeing the upturn."

Patel has given only a handful of interviews since taking over as RBI Governor late last year.

Also on HuffPost India:
TITLE: Growth Important, But Not At The Cost Of Inflation, Says Urjit Patel

HuffPost-Autor Sebastian Christ schreibt, warum er Air Berlin vermissen wird

Liebe Air Berlin!

Meine Facebook-Timeline ist voll mit Abschiedspostings. Es ist die Zeit der letzten Air-Berlin-FlÃ¼ge. Ich finde es rÃ¼hrend, was da zu lesen ist: Viele meiner Freunde sprechen dem Personal ein letztes Mal Mut zu und wÃ¼nschen ihnen alles Gute fÃ¼r den Weg in eine ungewisse Zukunft.

Jetzt, da eine Ã„ra vorbei geht, scheint das geschÃ¤ftige Treiben an den FlughÃ¤fen dieser Republik, zwischen Rollkoffern und BusinessanzÃ¼gen, plÃ¶tzlich menschliche ZÃ¼ge zu bekommen. Das ist ein gutes Zeichen.

Andere schreiben wehmÃ¼tig Ã¼ber den Geschmack der Schokoherzchen, die es frÃ¼her beim Aussteigen gab. Zugegeben, ich fand die Teile auch lecker. Aber sie sind so ziemlich das Unwichtigste, was ich an Air Berlin vermissen werde.

FrÃ¼her war Fliegen noch auÃŸergewÃ¶hnlich

Seit Donnerstag ist klar, dass Air Berlin grÃ¶ÃŸtenteils von der Lufthansa Ã¼bernommen wird. Damit dÃ¼rfte sich der Flugverkehr, so wie wir ihn kennen, radikal Ã¤ndern. Jeder, der das Fliegen noch in den 1990er-Jahren erlebt hat, dÃ¼rfte da eine Vorahnung haben.

Ich habe meinen ersten Flug in einem Linienjet erst mit 22 Jahren machen kÃ¶nnen. Dabei hatte ich weder Flugangst noch war ich jemand, der keine Lust aufs Reisen hatte. Ich konnte mir es schlicht und einfach nicht leisten, fÃ¼r mittlere Strecken ein Flugticket zu erwerben.

Bis vor etwa 20 Jahren war Fliegen etwas Besonderes, wenn es um innerdeutsche Strecken ging. Preise von 600 oder 800 Mark fÃ¼r ein Flugticket von Hamburg nach MÃ¼nchen waren damals nichts AuÃŸergewÃ¶hnliches, sondern eher etwas ganz Normales.

Das war etwas fÃ¼r GeschÃ¤ftsreisende, deren Firmen bereit waren, teures Geld dafÃ¼r zu bezahlen, um fÃ¤hige FachkrÃ¤fte von A nach B zu transportieren. Aber kein echtes Konkurrenzangebot fÃ¼r die Bahn, die damals noch staatlich-gemÃ¤chlich durch Deutschland zockelte.

Das Aufkommen preisgÃ¼nstiger Flugangebote hat vieles verÃ¤ndert: bisweilen sogar die Infrastruktur unserer StÃ¤dte. Vor allem aber die Art und Weise, wie wir reisen.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Luftfahrtunternehmer Niki Lauda kritisiert die Ãœbernahme von Air Berlin durch die Lufthansa

Du warst bei allem der Dreh- und Angelpunkt

Es ist heute kein Problem mehr, morgens in Stuttgart und nachmittags in Hamburg zu sein. Es gibt heute sogar Studenten, die Fernbeziehungen per Flugzeug fÃ¼hren â€“ weil man es sich leisten kann, am Freitagmorgen von Berlin nach KÃ¶ln zu fliegen, und am Sonntagnachmittag wieder zurÃ¼ck. Vorausgesetzt, man bucht rechtzeitig.

Und Du, Air Berlin, warst bei allem der Dreh- und Angelpunkt. Wahrscheinlich beschÃ¤ftigt Dein Niedergang auch deswegen so viele Menschen: Wenn die Lufthansa fÃ¼r die Fernreisenden ein StÃ¼ck Alltagskultur geworden war, warst Du es fÃ¼r die Kurz- und Mittelstrecken.

Und wenn wir schon Ã¼ber die Lufthansa sprechen: Genau da fÃ¤ngt das Problem an. AuÃŸer Germanwings und Eurowings gibt es sonst auf dem deutschen Markt keine grÃ¶ÃŸeren Billigfluganbieter mehr. Beide Gesellschaften gehÃ¶ren zu Lufthansa. Und die schluckt jetzt eben auch noch Air Berlin.

Um das ganze mal mit Fakten zu illustrieren: Im Juni 2017 belegten die nunmehr vier Fluglinien der Lufthansa die PlÃ¤tze eins bis vier nach Abflugzahlen in Deutschland. Gut 46.200 FlÃ¼ge gehen auf das Konto des Lufthansa-Imperiums. Auf Platz fÃ¼nf folgt dann Ryanair mit 4.600 AbflÃ¼gen.

Man muss kein Wirtschaftswissenschaftler sein, um an dieser Stelle eine Gefahr fÃ¼r den Wettbewerb zu sehen.

Uns droht eine Saure-Gurken-Zeit

BilligflÃ¼ge kÃ¶nnten kÃ¼nftig wieder zu etwas werden, was in der Nische stattfindet. Zumindest hÃ¤tte die Lufthansa die nÃ¶tige Marktmacht, um das durchzusetzen.

Das hÃ¤tte nicht nur Folgen fÃ¼r den Flugverkehr.

Denn auch die Bahn hat sich unter dem zunehmenden Druck von Seiten des Flugverkehrs in den vergangenen 20 Jahren zusehends modernisiert. In einigen Wochen zum Beispiel wird die Strecke von Berlin nach MÃ¼nchen fÃ¼r den Personenverkehr freigegeben: Dann wird man in vier Stunden von der Hauptstadt nach SÃ¼ddeutschland fahren kÃ¶nnen.

Solche Trassen werden nicht gebaut, um den Bussen Konkurrenz machen zu kÃ¶nnen. Sondern, weil die Bahn gegen den Flugverkehr ankommen will. Vier Stunden â€“ das ist durchaus eine wettbewerbsfÃ¤hige Fahrtzeit. Leider bietet die Bahn viel zu wenige dieser Verbindungen an.

Im Gegensatz zu Frankreich Ã¼brigens. Dort war es offensichtlich mÃ¶glich, ein Hochgeschwindigkeitsnetz fÃ¼r die Schiene aufzubauen. In Deutschland droht uns nach dem Wegfall der Konkurrenz aus der Luft eine neue Saure-Gurken-Zeit.

Auch deswegen werde ich Dich vermissen, Air Berlin. Es geht nicht um die Schokoherzen â€“ sondern darum, einem bisweilen recht schwerfÃ¤lligen Land den Mut zur VerÃ¤nderung schmackhaft zu machen. Doch leider kÃ¶nnten wir uns bald schon wieder in Reisewelten befinden, die ein wenig streng nach den 90er-Jahren mÃ¼ffeln.

(ll)

Plus qu'un problÃ¨me d'image, le "cas Garrido" pose une question de cohÃ©rence programmatique. On ne peut prÃ©tendre l'exemplaritÃ© sans en Ãªtre soi-mÃªme l'acteur @RaquelGarridoFI https://t.co/ET0QvU4VHV â€” ZoliveğŸŒ¿ (@zoliveclerm) 3 octobre 2017

Le malaise BollorÃ©

A travers Raquel Garrido, c'est aussi la stratÃ©gie mÃ©diatique de la France insoumise, thÃ©orisÃ©e notamment par Jean-Luc MÃ©lenchon, qui est interrogÃ©e. "Faire masse" en ne dÃ©daignant aucune invitation dans un mÃ©dia trÃ¨s grand public a toujours Ã©tÃ© revendiquÃ© par le mouvement. L'arrivÃ©e sur C8 de Raquel Garrido s'inscrivait dans cette logique. Le 31 aoÃ»t, un rÃ©fÃ©rent de la France insoumise estimait que le nouveau job de l'oratrice posait "une ambiguÃ¯tÃ© qu'il faut rÃ©soudre", dans la mesure oÃ¹ elle "est considÃ©rÃ©e comme porte-parole du mouvement". DÃ©but octobre, alors que l'intÃ©ressÃ©e commence Ã  afficher plusieurs polÃ©miques Ã  son compteur, un autre adhÃ©rent propose qu'elle "verse ses Ã©moluments de Canal+" au mouvement pour l'achat de matÃ©riel. "D'ailleurs, ce serait bien que l'on sache combien elle gagne", ajoute-t-il suspicieux.

Un malaise qui se ressent aussi sur la plateforme Discord. "Je ne suis pas bourgeois, et je ne parle pas de puretÃ© d'un mÃ©dia. Mais Garrido sur C8, je trouve qu'il y a une association qui ne passe pas", s'interrogeait le 9 octobre un membre du rÃ©seau. "Si il y a bien une chose qui Ã©tait une belle connerie de la part de Raquel Garrido, c'est d'avoir acceptÃ© ce poste de chroniqueuse chez BollorÃ©. La thÃ©orie du complot mÃ©diatique

Face Ã  ces interrogations, d'autres militants continuent toutefois de lui accorder le bÃ©nÃ©fice du doute, voire de rejeter en bloc les accusations. SUMMARY:
Personal branding expertMen's Grooming Myths Busted Male grooming has never been so popular, with men paying more and more attention to their appearance.
Founder of Bulldog Skincare For MenA Round-Up Of London Fashion Week AW17 Street Style Nothing can stop the force that is Fashion Week.
Come rain or shine, this couldn't keep the fashion's street style stars at bay as they marched throughout the streets of London Fashion Week.
It was a chaotic few days, but London Fashion Week is officially over for another year (we'll for another six months) to be precise.
Fashion designer and young entrepreneur.
TEXT:
Modern Masculinity: Where Are We Going? Men's wardrobes have not always been the basic, machine washable visions we see when we walk down a typical British high-street. There was actually a time when pink silk and ruffled collars didn't make us question a man's "masculinity" (whatever masculinity is) -- the fashion choices represented power. Womenswear editor at WGSN

A Guide To Men's Hair-Styling Products From Shampoo To Styling Men are spending more on grooming than they have done historically, however this can be a lottery. Tesco, Boots and Superdrug may have rows and rows of brightly coloured inexpensive male grooming products on their shelves but try asking anyone in store to give you advice on razor burn or a dry flaky scalp. A good stylist could/should almost be prescriptive. Creative Director and Lead Educator at men-Ã¼

Distractive Or Attractive? Nowadays, when one walks into a clothing retailer, we can be overwhelmed by the plethora of styles, fabrics and colours. Begin by just perusing, and if something takes your eye, inspect the item further. Does it look right and feel right? Yes, by feeling the item, we often make a connection. Does it appear to be well made and do the details appear congruent? Personal branding expert

Men's Grooming Myths Busted Male grooming has never been so popular, with men paying more and more attention to their appearance. Despite this, there remains a few lingering groo... Creative Director and Lead Educator at men-Ã¼

You're So Vain: How Menswear Is Flexing Its Muscles So, what do male customers want? What's driving these preening peacocks? We know that shopping in itself is not the attraction, so it's down the clothes. As buyers prepare to open their order books, they might reflect on the words of the talent that was Alexander McQueen: Freelance writer, PR consultant and editor

5 Reasons Why You Won't See Me In A Male Romper You have probably already seen the "playsuit for men", on your timeline or on premiered on the runway at London Fashion Week, (If not, image search 'Male Romper') but I bet you didn't know it is now being marketed and available for purchase to the average Joe. I for one, will not be that average Joe. The Plastic Surgeon

Guide To Hair Styles For Spring/Summer 2017 This is about thinking smart and listening to your stylist. Right now, we are seeing the trend of dismantling the large heavy blocked quiffs that have dominated the industry for the past 5 years. This is showing itself in two ways. Firstly, guys have a lot of length on the top, versus what they have on the sides, we are seeing a lot of elastic band type haircuts (you know who you are!). Creative Director and Lead Educator at men-Ã¼

Men, Don't Fear The Mask Google has revealed that "Masking" is currently this year's most searched skincare trend. * Conventionally seen as a woman's domain, masks have come on a lot further than the gloopy green kinds that we associate with chick flicks and ice cream. Founder of Bulldog Skincare For Men

A Round-Up Of London Fashion Week AW17 Street Style Nothing can stop the force that is Fashion Week. Come rain or shine, this couldn't keep the fashion's street style stars at bay as they marched throughout the streets of London Fashion Week. It was a chaotic few days, but London Fashion Week is officially over for another year (we'll for another six months) to be precise. Blogger & Digital Influencer & Fashion Host

We Were Able To Create A Fashion Label Available To All - Things Aren't So Easy These Days Early on in building our first brand we developed a philosophy that went "Red or Dead would be the world's first affordable designer label for people that grew up not knowing what design was and if they did couldn't have afforded it anyway" Admittedly this was a bit of a mouthful and ultimately we shortened it to "The first affordable designer label". Iconic designer and Vintage Festival founder

London Fashion Week Mens Gets Political - Designers Create Fashion Antidotes To Brexit And Trump It's brave for a designer to be so gobby, especially with the pressure of commercial sales targets and constant burden of turning a profit and keeping the wheels turning, but Shannon's line of thoughtful and clever sloganeering is somewhat proven, with his current and previous collections bearing a corruption of Sports Direct as "Lovers Direct" and "Haters Direct", currently in store at Selfridges Fashion Tech Innovator. Co-Director, BR Innovation Agency (BRIA)

London College Of Fashion Sustainability Initiatives "Fired Up" By Professor Sandy Black It is the mandate of FIREup to allow designers space, time, academic support and funding to conduct reflective research and steer their business forward in a more successful and thoughtful way. Fashion Tech Innovator. Co-Director, BR Innovation Agency (BRIA)

The Importance Of Sustainable Fashion Many people do not realise that fashion is the second most pollutant industry in the world behind none other than the oil industry. From over farmin... Passion for fashion and all things British produced. Fashion designer and young entrepreneur.

Key Menswear Essentials For AW16 Don't be fooled by the mild autumn. Winter is coming. Which means you need a wardrobe overhaul, to counter rougher weather and fashion's fickleness, the usual suspects return to your wardrobe: a warmer coat, blazer, warm shoes. The chill brings a new world of layering that is, arguably, better looking than our summer lovin' months Blogger & Digital Influencer & Fashion Host

Is The Whole Concept Of The Bespoke Suit Actually A Con? Are you having the wool pulled over your eyes when you're being told you're getting a bespoke suit, when it's really made-to-measure? The answer is a resounding NO! according to award-winning Savile Row tailor Alexandra Wood whose clients appear on GQ's best dressed list. TV producer, freelance journalist
TITLE: HuffPost UK Men's Fashion: Style And Trend News, Galleries And Blogs For Men Of All Ages

SUMMARY:
And at the Tory conference in Manchester yesterday, Theresa May gave a speech with a lot of substance.
And Boris won't be quitting, because he will be joining David Davis and Philip Hammond in the audience in Florence.
We're On The Offensive, And Boris Johnson's Constituency Is Firmly In Our Sights The case against Boris Johnson is very clear.
Charity executive, fatherThe Days Of May Prime Minister Boris Johnson is now a distinct probability.
Once this deal has been agreed Theresa May will resign, and soon we will see Boris Johnson leading Britain's negotiations with the EU.
TEXT:
The Tory Party Is In Big Trouble Whatever the Tories do, things seem likely to fall apart. This is the inevitable consequence of building a house on rotten foundations. No amount of blue gloss will prevent inevitable collapse. The selfish individualism they preach cannot hold the party together, let alone society. Writer with a background in anthropology and mental health care

7,000 Words And Not A Single Mention Of Wales After this conference season, it's becoming increasingly clear that Theresa May is content with providing "second best" solutions to the issues which face communities across Wales and the UK as a whole. Member of Parliament for Ogmore

If You Dumb Down Politics, We All Lose I'm a lifelong Labour member. And at the Tory conference in Manchester yesterday, Theresa May gave a speech with a lot of substance. That doesn't make her someone I would vote for, but that does make her someone worth listening to. PR guru and Media Podcast presenter

Tory Conference Diary, Day 4: May's Disaster Of A Speech Proved The Tories Have No Plan As Tory Conference comes to a close many of the papers and broadcast channels have obviously focused in on the mishaps which plagued Theresa May's speech. But aside from the cough and the falling backdrop, the true disaster of the speech lies in the fact that we had final confirmation that the Tories really do have no plan. Labour MP for Hemsworth and Shadow Minister for the Cabinet

The Roaring Lion And The Dutiful Public Servant: Johnson And May's Wildly Different Views Of Brexit Britain In her speech, Theresa May said that "the Tories must win the battle of ideas again." But perhaps it is not only the Tories that must win the battle of ideas within the nation, but within their own party. For in this moment, these two competing ideas of post-Brexit Britain, the lion and the servant cannot sustain the standoff. Lions often eat unaware but dutiful servants and dutiful servants, often kill lions. Before the current prime minister can carry out her vision of dutifully serving the nation, she needs to win the battle of ideas within her own party. PhD student, Queen Mary University of London

The Art Of The Deal: How Not To Negotiate Brexit f you're the Commission you must be laughing. Why not leave the British to squabble amongst themselves, let the March 2019 deadline get closer and closer, and then force through an advantageous deal at the last minute? What possible incentive do the Europeans have to take the negotiations seriously? Why would they treat us with respect? We are proving ourselves to be incompetent and idiotic. We deserve what we will get. Chief Executive, Newgate Communications

Hurricane Season Is No Time To Plan Foreign Aid Cuts No one can deny that the UK government had ample warning that hurricane Irma, a Caribbean storm of unprecedented force, was heading for British territories. Comments by Mrs May and her cabinet, scapegoating rules on aid, are an unedifying attempt to distract from the government's inadequate preparedness. Lib Dem peer and international development spokesperson

EU Citizens' Rights, Wasting Time Climbing A Molehill Here we are, 15 months post referendum, the week after the Prime Minister's Florence Speech and at the end of the 4th round of negotiations with the EU on monetary obligations, Northern Ireland and EU nationals citizens' rights. As Michel Barnier said, the clock is ticking. This is the last chance to move on to the next stage of negotiations, progress is vital. The3Million campaign spokesperson

The Ego Has Landed For all the sound and fury, insiders say Boris has agreed he won't argue for time limit on the transition period, and crucially won't oppose the UK continuing to pay for access to the EU single market in a transition. What his critics saw as an ego-trip, but allies saw as valuable restoration of Cabinet consultation, looks to have abated. And Boris won't be quitting, because he will be joining David Davis and Philip Hammond in the audience in Florence. Executive Editor, Politics, HuffPost UK

Leavers Like Boris Johnson Harm Their Brexit Cause More Than Its Critics For all the many attacks on Brexit sceptics for how they talk down Britain's potential, this very public spat at the heart of government is even worse for weakening the government's already poor hand. If the PM thought she had a difficult time before, it's only worse now. Ironically, it's mostly because of meddling by pro-Brexit ministers like Boris rather than criticisms from pro-Remain sceptics. Award-winning author, broadcaster, columnist and public speaker, Brooks is Dean of Durham Law School. His latest book is 'Becoming British'.

Theresa May's Plans For Britain's Brexit Look Increasingly Like The Status Quo - But Worse Leave supporters will be least impressed of all. One by one virtually every promise made by Vote Leave looks set to be broken except for the vow to leave the EU. Empty promises will not be rewarded at the ballot box - and blaming Europe for failing to get Britain the best deal is not an option for Brexiteers who claimed their critics had nothing more than Project Fear. It's looking a lot more like Project Fact. Award-winning author, broadcaster, columnist and public speaker, Brooks is Dean of Durham Law School. His latest book is 'Becoming British'.

We're On The Offensive, And Boris Johnson's Constituency Is Firmly In Our Sights The case against Boris Johnson is very clear. Here is a man who was sacked for lying twice: once by a newspaper editor, another by his party leader. He opportunistically backed Brexit only because he felt it would further his political career. He recently had perhaps the most humiliating carcrash interview of any Cabinet minister in recent history. And as Foreign Secretary, he is reducing this great country to an international laughing stock. Guardian columnist and author

Democracy In The Time Of Brexit There are few things as important to our society, and our nation, as democracy. That is right and proper, because a country whose people are unable to periodically choose their leaders and - importantly - hold them to account beckons dictatorship, and dictatorship leads to conflict, oppression and isolation. Charity executive, father

The Days Of May Prime Minister Boris Johnson is now a distinct probability. Theresa May will form a loose agreement with the Democratic Union Party in Northern Ireland, one which allows the Conservatives to govern as a minority with behind-the-scenes support from the DUP. this will suit both parties. Once this deal has been agreed Theresa May will resign, and soon we will see Boris Johnson leading Britain's negotiations with the EU. Research Fellow at Kings College London

How To Win The General Election? Do A Greg Knight Sir Greg Knight - an obscure figure only known to the most devoted of political followers. Or that was the case until Tuesday morning when his campaign video went viral due to the catchy jingle that sent social media into a storm. Editor-in-Chief - Royal Central
TITLE: Boris Johnson, London Mayor, news, quotes, interviews

SUMMARY:
Editor-at-large for HuffPost South AfricaStanding Up To The Media And Their 'Muslim Problem' The post-7/7 scrutiny of Muslims is complex and many, including sections in the Muslim community, are responsible for the unhealthy situation.
But there is no denying the fact that some right wing news editors and politicians have directly contributed towards the so-called "Muslim Problem" in the country.
Green Party former leaderHow Can The UK Media Win Back Consumer Trust?
CEO and Co-Founder of Newsflare, a video marketplace platform that connects the worldâ€™s media with video shot by the public.
That's why I put my name to my colleague Naz Shah's recent letter to Tony Gallagher, calling out The Sun for publishing an article which referenced a "Muslim Problem".
TEXT:
I Wrote The Article About The AfD That Ukip Said Showed It Wasn't Far-Right. Here's Why They're Wrong Ukip thinks Germany's AfD isn't far-right. They seemed to learn this from a 'left wing Huffington Post' article I wrote, which was read out at conference as proof the AfD is perfectly sensible. Here's why I disagree. Assistant News Editor, HuffPost UK

My Media Storm Has Only Made Me More Determined To Get My Message Out To The World I took up every opportunity I had to state my case and stand in my truth. I didn't back down, despite immense backlash from the public and right-wing press. I've received threats of death, rape and violence, anonymous phone calls and friends selling me out. But it's only made me more and more determined to refine my message, educate people and get my true message out there into the world. That we live in a racist society and largely not owning up to it or discussing why things are the way they are for people of colour. Anti-racism activist and campaigner

Together We Can Change Society And Beat Bullying Once And For All At the age of 15, after years of telling the teachers and being isolated as the problem, I became publicly vocal about my experiences. I posted a bulletin on MySpace, which was the main social network at the time, to talk about my experiences. Overnight, I was inundated with other people from across the world who were either going through the same or had been through it. Today, we are now one of the largest anti-bullying charities in the world. We work globally to help thousands of young people to overcome bullying each month. Founder and CEO of anti-bullying charity Ditch the Label

My Brittle Bone Condition Won't Stop Me Living Life To The Full My name is Samantha Renke and I am a Lancashire-born actress and public speaker who currently lives in east London. I am a former teacher and trustee for the brittle bone society. I have a genetic condition called osteogenesis imperfecta, more commonly known as brittle bones condition which means I am a full-time wheelchair user, but this most certainly doesn't stop me from living life to the full. Actress and disability campaigner

I Want Everyone To Be Comfortable In Their Skin, Whatever Their Race, Gender Or Sexuality So a little bit about me: big hair, in your face-style and daily opinions on just about anything are what others might say about me. However, mostly that's just a platform for the thing I like to talk about the most - body positivity and personal empowerment. I believe and want everyone to be comfortable in their own skin, whatever your gender, race or sexuality. Model, student and body positivity activist

Ryanair And Customer Service - Finally I Understand What Oxymoron Actually Means People will take heed and vote with their wallets, but more robust compensation rules might have seen Ryanair chose a different path in the first place. Money talks, and they took the cheapest option, so let's look at the compensation rules to make sure next time the cheapest option is not to walk all over their passengers. Editor-in-chief, Daily Mirror

Karen Bradley Stands Up To The Murdochs - But Has Ofcom Lost Its Bottle? It's rare to see any cabinet minister being warmly congratulated by her opposition shadow in the House of Commons. On matters involving Rupert Murdoch, it is virtually unprecedented. Governments of all shades in Britain have an almost unbroken record of abject surrender when it comes to tackling the sprawling expansion of Murdoch's media empire. Professor of Communications at the University of Westminster, author and broadcaster on media issues

It's Really Not Very Difficult, Prime Minister - We Need More Organs In Britain three people die every day waiting for an organ transplant. And more than 6,000 patients are waiting for an organ which could transform their life. And that is why the Mirror has been campaigning for the past two years for a change in the organ transplant laws in England which would mean people are deemed to have consented to their organs being donated after death, unless they have said otherwise. We believe if our Change the Law for Life campaign is successful, the number of donors will increase by 25% and hundreds of lives will be saved every year. Editor-in-chief, Daily Mirror

Are WWE And ITV Poised To Take Over The London Wrestling Scene? With UK talent being quickly signed to WWE contracts, ITV's World Of Sport plans have now been indefinitely postponed. And with their toes firmly out of the water, WWE seem to have claimed the audience. Host of The World According To Wrestling

Good Riddance To The Colonisers - Why We Won't Miss Bell Pottinger Bell Pottinger strode the globe like a colossus making a mint from manipulation. It works in countries where accountability is not great and so it grew a shield of impunity. That was until it got to South Africa where a robust media and a cottage industry of internet sleuths quickly uncovered their campaign. Editor-at-large for HuffPost South Africa

Standing Up To The Media And Their 'Muslim Problem' The post-7/7 scrutiny of Muslims is complex and many, including sections in the Muslim community, are responsible for the unhealthy situation. But there is no denying the fact that some right wing news editors and politicians have directly contributed towards the so-called "Muslim Problem" in the country. Educationalist, community activist, author and parenting consultant

Why People With Dementia Deserve More From Science Last week a research story about lithium and dementia from Denmark caught the attention of the UK press and I have since been asked by a number of families about potential trials after I commented in the press. Dr James Pickett is the Head of Research at Alzheimer's Society.

The Fourth Estate Needs To Step Up To Prevent Governments Spreading Fake News This isn't good enough. The Fourth Estate is crucial in a democracy. We need one that works. It could start by refusing the return to sources that have demonstrably provided fake news. Although that might create a problem in finding government sources. Green Party former leader

How Can The UK Media Win Back Consumer Trust? It won't be solved by sweeping statements, or by picking a fight with political leaders. Instead it will be solved one step at a time and the first step has to be involving the public - asking where their frustrations are and what they'd like to see more of in reporting. CEO and Co-Founder of Newsflare, a video marketplace platform that connects the worldâ€™s media with video shot by the public.

Now More Than Ever We Must Call Out The Poisonous Rhetoric We Saw In The Sun Now more than ever, we must continue to celebrate our diversity, never shying away from calling out discrimination wherever we find it. That's why I put my name to my colleague Naz Shah's recent letter to Tony Gallagher, calling out The Sun for publishing an article which referenced a "Muslim Problem". Labour MP for Batley and Spen and Shadow Minister for Early Years
TITLE: Huffingtonpost.co.uk: Media news, comment and analysis blogs
